* The study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory has received significant attention in various areas of physics, particularly in cosmology. The work has been driven largely by inflation, the most successful known mechanism for explaining the large-scale homogeneity and isotropy of the universe. Inflationary models can lead to a variety of features unavailable in the case of a single field. Multi-field scenarios include the well-known hybrid inflation models.

* The dynamics of multi-field models of inflation involve the coupling of two or more dynamical, interacting scalar fields. An important aspect of such systems is the possibility of mixing between the fields. The problem of renormalization of time evolution equations in single field models was understood several years ago. However, going beyond tree level brings in the issue of renormalization, and the correct choice of the initial condition for the fluctuations guarantees that the theory is renormalizable.

* The authors work in the context of a closed time path formalism, which is appropriate for following the time-dependent evolution of the system. They construct the in-vacuum by diagonalizing the mass matrix of the system at the initial time. However, because of the time-dependent mixing, a system initially diagonalized in this way will generally not be diagonalized at later times. The authors take an alternative approach where the mass matrix is allowed to be non-diagonal for all times.

* The authors apply their formalism to a two-field case, where they study the behavior of the quantized mode functions and the effect of fluctuations on the zero mode equations of motion for various parameters. They also study a supersymmetric hybrid inflationary model, which is of particular interest in cosmology. The model predicts inflation, which comes to an end via a smooth phase transition, and robustness of the model is confirmed by a slightly tilted spectrum of scalar density fluctuations within the COBE limit.

* The authors find that the fluctuations in a supersymmetric hybrid model do not grow if the back reaction of the fluctuations are taken into account in the mean field evolution. This requires a careful revaluation of the successes of the production of weakly interacting massive particles and baryogenesis via out of equilibrium decay in supersymmetric hybrid inflationary models. The authors' study implies that exciting higher spin particles from the vacuum fluctuations of the coherent oscillations of the fields in a supersymmetric hybrid inflationary model demands careful reconsideration. The authors' results are robust enough to claim that the fluctuations in a supersymmetric hybrid model do not grow if the back reaction of the fluctuations are taken into

<summary>
* The existence of dark matter (DM) has been established, and its thermal relic abundance has been determined by the WMAP experiment. The Weakly Interacting Massive Particle (WIMP) is a promising candidate for DM. The WIMP DM candidate can be accommodated economically by introducing only an inert scalar field.

* The Higgs Triplet Model (HTM) is a simple model for generating neutrino masses, but it does not contain a DM candidate. The model can be extended to include a DM candidate by introducing a new scalar field. The lepton number conserving operator which results in the μ-term is of dimension-5.

* The model is extended by introducing a Z2-even neutral scalar s1 of L=2, a Z2-odd neutral real scalar s2 of L=0, and a Z2-odd doublet scalar field η of L=2. The DM candidate in the model is made from s2 and η. The μ-term is induced at the one-loop level while the λ5-term exists at the tree level.

* The characteristic feature of the model is that μ is much larger than λ5. The model gives small neutrino masses naturally without using very heavy particles. The suppression factor for λ5 is constrained by the DM relic abundance measured by the WMAP experiment.

* The DM candidate s2 comes dominantly from s2 if m2<mη. The coupling λs1 of the s1h interaction determines the annihilation cross-section of s2 and the scattering cross-section on nuclei. The parameter μ does not affect the λ5 parameter in the HTM.

* A favorable process to probe the large μ in collider experiments is the production of η±η± followed by η±→W±s2. The partial decay width of η± is determined by μ while the width of η±→W±η is proportional to λ5. The DM s2 can be light enough so that the Z2-even charged scalar η± can decay into η±W±s2.

* The model would be supported if experiments observe final states which include jets and only two leptons whose invariant mass gives mη. This potential signature might be disturbed by hadronic decays of η± because η±→W±s2 can result in the same final state. Realistic simulation is necessary to see the feasibility.

* The work of S.K. was supported by Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research Nos. 22244031 and 23104006. The work

<summary>
• Studying QCD at finite baryon density is crucial for understanding the structure of compact stars and conditions near the core of collapsing stars.
• The color superconducting phase is known to exist in sufficiently cold and dense baryonic matter, and it was proposed several decades ago by Frautschi and Barrois.
• The gapless 2SC (g2SC) phase and gapless CFL (gCFL) phase are two possible phases that can exist in neutral cold-dense quark matter, depending on the flavor structure of the system.
• The g2SC phase exhibits chromomagnetic instability, which is a puzzle since it is not understood why gapless color superconducting phases exhibit this instability.
• The g2SC phase is also unstable with respect to an external color-neutral baryon current, which suggests that a baryon current can be spontaneously generated in the system.
• The spontaneously generated baryon current breaks the rotational symmetry of the system and resembles the one-plane wave LOFF state.
• The 2SC phase can be described in the nonlinear realization framework, which naturally takes into account the contribution from the phase fluctuations or Nambu-Goldstone currents.
• The Nambu-Goldstone currents generation state can cover the gluon phase as well as the one-plane wave LOFF state, and it is equivalent to the gluon condensate state.
</summary>

<summary>
• The dynamics of a quantum many-body system out of equilibrium has been a subject of increasing interest in recent times, with extensive studies leading to many new findings and unresolved questions.
• The emergence of a current of a physical quantity generally renders a system to a nonequilibrium one, and transport properties have received attention as an important aspect of nonequilibrium dynamics.
• The study focuses on the dynamics of a quantum Ising chain, where the transportation of magnetization is induced by preparing an initial state that produces inhomogeneity in transverse magnetization.
• The system is found to relax with time, but the local magnetization at different sites does not attain the same value, and the underlying dynamics at each site possess two different timescales of oscillation.
• The smaller timescale contributes insignificant undulations, while the oscillations of the larger timescale exhibit generic power-law decay, with the exponent of the decay being independent of the strength of the external field.
• The frequency of the characteristic oscillation is a monotonic function of the external field as long as the system is in the ordered phase and becomes independent of the field when it crosses the critical value to the disordered phase.
• The transverse magnetization after infinite time at each site shows different functional behavior in the ordered and disordered phase, producing nonanalyticity at the critical point.
• The study raises questions about the behavior of non-local observables in integrable systems and the dynamics of non-integrable systems starting from such inhomogeneity, which may be interesting to investigate in the future.</summary>

<summary>
* The Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young (KTHNY) theory is a widely accepted theory that describes the melting transition of two-dimensional (2D) systems, but its validity has been questioned due to its assumption of a dilute, unstructured distribution of lattice defects. Recent studies have investigated the melting transition in various 2D systems, including those with different pair interactions, and have found conflicting results. The debate surrounding the KTHNY theory remains ongoing, with some studies supporting its predictions and others finding evidence for first-order or second-order phase transitions.
* The current study investigates the melting transition in a 2D system with repulsive screened Coulomb pair potential using microcanonical molecular dynamics simulations. The results show that the system exhibits a metastable hexatic phase, which can be mistaken for the true equilibrium configuration if the simulation time is not sufficient. The study highlights the importance of considering the equilibration time and system size in simulations of 2D melting transitions to avoid misleading conclusions.</summary>

<summary>
* The study of dipole moments of elementary particles has provided a wealth of information on subatomic physics over the past 83 years. This study has led to the discovery of spin, radiative corrections, and the renormalizable theory of QED.

* The magnetic moment of a charged particle with spin is given by the equation μ = g(S/2)μN(1 + a), where g is the gyromagnetic ratio, a is the anomaly, and μN is the nuclear magneton. The Dirac equation predicts that g = 2 for point-like particles.

* The anomaly arises from radiative corrections, which can be calculated using quantum electrodynamics (QED). The lowest-order correction gives the famous Schwinger result, which was verified experimentally by Foley and Kusch.

* The QED contributions to the electron and muon anomalies have been calculated through eighth order, and the tenth-order contribution has been estimated. The electron anomaly is now measured to a relative precision of about four parts in a billion.

* The muon anomaly is measured to 0.5 parts per million (ppm), which is sensitive to higher mass scale radiative corrections. The relative contributions of heavier particles to the anomaly scale as m^2, so the muon has an increased sensitivity to higher mass scale radiative corrections.

* The standard model value of the muon anomaly has measurable contributions from three types of radiative processes: QED loops, hadronic loops, and weak loops. A significant difference between the experimental value and the standard model prediction would signify the presence of new physics.

* The hadronic contribution to the muon anomaly cannot be calculated directly from QCD, but dispersion theory gives a relationship between the vacuum polarization loop and the cross section for e+e- annihilation. Experimental data are used as input to determine the hadronic contribution.

* The muon anomaly has been measured experimentally using a storage ring, where the spin precession frequency is measured relative to the momentum precession frequency. The difference frequency is proportional to the anomaly.

* The experimental results from the E821 experiment are shown in a figure, with the average value determining the "world average". The theory value is taken from Hocker et al., which updates their earlier analysis with the KLOE data.

* The muon electric dipole moment (EDM) is a sensitive probe of new physics beyond the standard model. A new experiment to search for a permanent EDM of the muon with a design sensitivity of 10^-

<summary>
• The study presents a theoretical framework for analyzing topologically biased random walks on graphs, which can be used to explore the environment and measure distances between vertices depending on the chosen bias strategy and bias parameters.
• The framework is applied to the problem of community detection, and a novel methodology is proposed for creating suitable topologically biased random walks for community detection, which can be used to create different community finding methods with different ad hoc strategies.</summary>

<summary>
* The stochastic formulation of open quantum systems is a unified approach to study dissipative quantum dynamics beyond the standard bosonic bath models, and it can be applied to various bath models, including bosonic, fermionic, and non-Gaussian baths. The formulation is based on the stochastic Liouville equation (SLE), which prescribes the exact dynamics for the reduced density matrix.
* The SLE can be solved using deterministic numerical methods, such as the generalized hierarchical equations (GHE), which can be applied to different bath models and provide numerically exact simulations for non-Gaussian, fermionic, and bosonic bath models with arbitrary spectral densities and temperature regimes. The GHE approach can also be used to study spin bath models, which can be mapped onto an enlarged Gaussian bath model of fermions via the dual-fermion representation.</summary>

<summary>
• The Kepler mission has discovered over 4100 planetary candidates in 3200 systems, revolutionizing our understanding of planet occurrence rates around stars of all types.
• Small planets are nearly ubiquitous, and some of the most common planets have sizes between Earth-sized and Neptune-sized, a type not found in our own solar system.
• The transition from "rocky" to "non-rocky" planets occurs near a planet radius of 1.5-2.0 Earth radii, and accurate planetary radii are crucial to understanding this transition.
• However, assuming all Kepler candidate stars are single can introduce a systematic uncertainty into the planetary radii and occurrence rate distributions.
• The presence of a stellar companion can dilute the observed transit depth, leading to underestimated planetary radii.
• The authors have explored the effects of undetected stellar companions on the observed transit depths and derived planetary radii for the entire Kepler candidate sample.
• They found that, on average, planetary radii are underestimated by a factor of 1.5, corresponding to an overestimation of the planet bulk density by a factor of 2.25.
• Radial velocity and high-resolution imaging vetting can reduce the planetary radius mean correction necessary to account for undetected companions to a factor of 1.1.
• The benefit of vetting is even more powerful for missions like K2 and TESS, where the targets are, on average, ten times closer than the Kepler objects of interest.
• The authors conclude that understanding the occurrence rates of Earth-sized planets requires taking into account the presence of stellar companions and the limits of the observations used to detect them.
</summary>

<summary>
• The paper proposes a holistic immunity system to defend against active P2P worms, which exploit popular P2P applications for rapid topological worm infection. The system utilizes a small subset of specially elected P2P hosts, called phagocytes, that have high immunity and can "eat" active P2P worms in the P2P overlay networks.

• The phagocytes monitor their managed P2P hosts' connection patterns and traffic volume to detect worm events, and invoke internal defense strategies for local isolation, alert propagation, and software patching. The phagocytes also provide access control and filtering mechanisms for communication establishment between the P2P overlay and external hosts.

• The system implements a novel adaptive and interaction-based computational puzzle scheme to prevent external hosts from attacking the P2P overlay. The scheme treats each external host distinctively by performing a lightweight interaction to flexibly adjust the puzzle difficulty according to the real-time statuses of the network environment.

• The paper evaluates the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed system through experiments on a massive-scale testbed with realistic P2P network traces. The results show that the phagocytes can effectively defend against internal attacks and prevent external hosts from attacking the P2P overlay.

• The system provides a total worm protection for P2P overlay systems, addressing the deadly threats posed by active P2P worms, and can be deployed in various overlay networks with different network scales. The phagocytes are effective and scalable in performing detection, local isolation, alert propagation, and software patching.</summary>

<summary>
• Quantum fluctuations can suppress or enhance chaotic motion in wave packets, depending on the system and the type of perturbation.
• The relationship between chaotic behavior and tunneling phenomena in classically chaotic systems is an important subject in quantum physics.
• The semiclassical description of tunneling phenomena in classically chaotic systems has been developed by several groups.
• Lin and Ballentine studied the interplay between tunneling and classical chaos in a double-well potential with an oscillatory driving force.
• The authors numerically investigated the relation between quantum fluctuation, tunneling, and decoherence in a one-dimensional double-well system driven by a polychromatic external field.
• The results show that the motion of the wave packet can be classified into coherent and irregular motions, depending on the perturbation strength and the number of frequency components.
• The transition from coherent to irregular motion is accompanied by a decrease in the degree of coherence and an increase in the uncertainty product.
• The growth of the uncertainty product is related to the growth of the energy of the wave packet, and the quantum interference suppresses the energy growth in the polychromatically perturbed cases.
• The semiquantal picture breaks down for the irregular quantum states, and the quantum fluctuation observed in the semiquantal picture is suppressed by interference effect in the fully quantum motion.
• The authors expect that the similar phenomena would appear by dynamical barrier in the system, and the details will be given elsewhere.
</summary>

<summary>
* The authors investigate the effects of quantum gravity on the Planck era of the universe, using various versions of the generalized uncertainty principle (GUP) to derive modifications to several quantities that characterize the Planck era.
* The results indicate that the Planck quantities predicted by the GUP extend nicely to those of the usual Heisenberg uncertainty principle (HUP) and connect smoothly to them, with potential implications for cosmology and the transition from the quantum gravitational regime to the classical regime.</summary>

<summary>
* The range of HI column densities in nearby galaxies is similar to those in damped Lyman-alpha (DLA) systems, making it an attractive experiment to map HI gas in DLA absorbing systems and measure their total gas mass, extent, and dynamics. However, this is impossible with present technology due to the weak 21-cm line emission. The identification of DLAs as absorbers in background QSO spectra is not distance-dependent, but the detection efficiency depends on the brightness of the background source.

* The lowest redshift Lyman-alpha absorbers cannot be observed from the ground due to the Earth's atmosphere being opaque to the UV wavelength range. The redshift number density of DLAs decreases rapidly towards lower redshifts, resulting in few known DLAs within the reach of present-day radio telescopes. This limits the possibility of bridging the information between local galaxies and DLAs.

* Most observers resort to optical wavelengths to study DLAs, but attempts to directly image their host galaxies have been notably unsuccessful. A few positive identifications exist, mostly from HST imaging, and the success rate for finding low-redshift host galaxies is better due to their expected brightness and larger separation on the sky. Early surveys for low-redshift DLA host galaxies consisted of broad-band imaging and lacked spectroscopic follow-up.

* Later studies aimed at measuring redshifts to determine the association of optically identified galaxies with DLAs, either spectroscopically or using photometric redshifts. There are now around 80 DLA galaxies known at low redshift, spanning a wide range in galaxy properties from inconspicuous LSB dwarfs to giant spirals and early-type galaxies. The galaxies that contribute to the HI cross-section above the DLA threshold are not just luminous, high surface brightness spiral galaxies.

* Blind 21-cm emission line surveys in the local universe have resulted in an accurate measurement of the HI mass function, which can be used as a reference point for higher redshift DLA studies. However, these surveys are not useful in constraining the column density distribution function of HI due to the large beam widths of the single-dish instruments. High-resolution 21-cm maps of a large sample of local galaxies observed with the Westerbork synthesis radio telescope are used instead.

* The sample, known as WHISP, consists of 355 galaxies spanning a large range in HI mass and optical luminosity. The total number of independent column density measurements above the DLA limit is around 100,000,

<summary>
* The Casimir-Lifshitz force is a quantum mechanical phenomenon that arises from the interaction between two uncharged, parallel plates in a vacuum. This force is a result of the zero-point energy of the electromagnetic field, which is a fundamental aspect of quantum electrodynamics. The force is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the separation between the plates and is always attractive in a vacuum. However, in certain situations, a properly chosen liquid can cause the two plates to repel each other.

* The Casimir-Lifshitz force has been extensively studied in the context of isotropic dielectrics, but less attention has been devoted to the torque between anisotropic materials. The torque between two parallel birefringent plates is a result of the anisotropy of the zero-point energy and can be calculated using the dielectric functions of the interacting materials. The torque is proportional to the area of the interacting surfaces and is a function of the angle between the optical axes of the two plates. The sign of the torque depends on the dielectric properties of the materials and the intervening medium.

* The authors of the paper calculate the magnitude of the torque induced by quantum fluctuations for specific materials and discuss possible experimental validations of the effect. They consider a small birefringent disk made of quartz or calcite placed parallel to a birefringent barium titanate plate in vacuum. The dielectric properties of the materials are described using a multiple oscillator model, and the torque is calculated as a function of the angle between the optical axes of the two plates. The results show that the torque is inversely proportional to the second power of the separation between the plates and is proportional to the area of the interacting surfaces.

* The authors also consider the case where the disk is immersed in liquid ethanol, which causes the retarded van der Waals force between the two birefringent slabs to become repulsive. The disk is expected to float on top of the plate at a distance of approximately 100 nm, where its weight is counterbalanced by the van der Waals repulsion. The static friction between the two birefringent plates is virtually zero, and the disk is free to rotate suspended in bulk liquid. The torque induced by quantum fluctuations is calculated as a function of the angle between the optical axes of the two plates, and the results show that the torque is proportional to the area of the interacting surfaces and is a function of the angle between the optical axes of the two plates.

<summary>
* The glass transition is a complex phenomenon that remains one of the largest unresolved problems in statistical physics. It is characterized by a sharp increase in relaxation times and a departure from equilibrium. Theoretical models, such as the mode-coupling theory (MCT), have been proposed to explain this transition.

* The MCT predicts a transition from a liquid to a glassy state at a critical temperature, known as the mode-coupling temperature. This transition is characterized by a rapid increase in relaxation times and a change in the dynamics of the system. The MCT has been successful in explaining many features of the glass transition.

* The nonergodicity parameters are a key concept in the MCT, and they are used to characterize the long-time behavior of the system. These parameters are defined as the non-vanishing asymptotic solution of the MCT equations. They are a measure of the degree of ergodicity of the system.

* The memory function is another important concept in the MCT, and it is used to describe the dynamics of the system. The memory function is a measure of the degree of correlation between the particles in the system. It is a key ingredient in the MCT equations.

* The MCT has been applied to a variety of systems, including hard-sphere systems and molecular liquids. The theory has been successful in explaining many features of the glass transition in these systems. However, there are still many open questions and challenges in the field.

* The present study uses molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the glass transition in a Ni-Zr alloy. The simulations are based on a realistic model of the interatomic potentials, and they are designed to mimic the experimental conditions. The study focuses on the dynamics of the system and the behavior of the nonergodicity parameters.

* The results of the simulations show that the system undergoes a glass transition at a critical temperature of around 1000 K. The nonergodicity parameters are found to be non-vanishing at this temperature, indicating a transition from a liquid to a glassy state. The memory function is also found to be consistent with the MCT predictions.

* The study also investigates the behavior of the diffusion coefficients in the system. The results show that the diffusion coefficients follow a critical power law above the critical temperature, consistent with the MCT predictions. The study also finds that the diffusion coefficients are affected by the glass transition, with a change in the slope of the Arrhenius plot.

* The present study provides new insights into the glass transition

<summary>
• The majority of stars are formed in star clusters, and during the collapse of a giant molecular cloud, only a modest percentage of gas is turned into stars. The resulting cluster is made up of a combination of gas and stars, but the gas is removed on timescales shorter than a crossing time due to stellar winds and supernovae explosions. This process leaves the cluster far out of equilibrium due to the rapid change in gravitational potential energy.

• The effects of this process have received little consideration in observational studies of young massive star clusters, which have attempted to constrain the initial stellar mass function (IMF) by studying the internal dynamics of young clusters. However, these studies have found discrepant results, with some reporting non-standard IMFs and others reporting standard IMFs. The discrepancy may be due to the youngest clusters being out of equilibrium.

• The present work investigates the detailed luminosity profiles of three young massive clusters, M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1, which reside in nearby starburst galaxies. The observations show that the clusters display an excess of light at large radii compared to King or EFF profiles. This excess light is a signature of violent relaxation after gas expulsion.

• Simulations of the effects of gas expulsion on massive young clusters produce exactly the same excess due to stars escaping during a period of violent relaxation. The simulations also show that gas expulsion can cause virial mass estimates to be significantly wrong for several tens of Myr. The signatures of gas expulsion are also seen in many other young star clusters.

• The observations and simulations presented in this work support the scenario of "infant mortality," where young clusters are destroyed due to rapid gas expulsion. The rapid dissolution of these clusters can also lead to "infant weight-loss," where a cluster loses a significant portion of its initial stellar mass. The current simulations do not include a stellar IMF or the evolution of stars, but these effects do not significantly affect the results.

• The inclusion of a stellar IMF and stellar evolution may lead to the preferential loss of low-mass stars, but this is not expected to occur in these young clusters. The effect of primordial mass segregation may also play a role, where the most massive stars are less likely to be lost due to their lower velocity dispersion. These points will be considered in more detail in a future paper.

• The observations and simulations presented in this work have implications for the dynamical state and longevity of young clusters. The results suggest that gas expulsion is an important phase in

<summary>
• Dyadic data are common in psychosocial and behavioral studies, where observations are related to both individuals in a dyadic relationship. This interdependence leads to correlated observations, making it essential to account for within-dyad correlation when analyzing longitudinal dyadic data. Repeatedly measuring dyads introduces two complications: within-subject correlation and nonignorable dropouts. The proposed method addresses these challenges by modeling the longitudinal outcome process using a transition model and accounting for correlation within dyads using random effects.

• The transition model allows a subject's outcome to depend on not only their own characteristics but also the characteristics of the other member in the dyad. This approach facilitates understanding interdependence within a relationship and designing more efficient prevention programs. The model parameters have appealing interpretations as "actor" and "partner" effects. The proposed method uses a discrete time survival model to link the dropout process with the longitudinal measurement process.

• The data augmentation method is used to address the complex missing data problem caused by dropout and interdependence within dyads. The simulation study shows that the proposed method yields consistent estimates with correct coverage rates. The method is applied to longitudinal dyadic data collected from a breast cancer study, identifying more "partner" effects than methods that ignore missing data. This extra information can be useful for designing more efficient depression prevention programs for breast cancer patients.

• The proposed method suggests significant "partner" effects for patients, indicating that a patient's depression increases with their spouse's MPI and previous CESD scores. There are also significant "actor" effects for patients, showing that a patient's depression is positively correlated with their own MPI and previous CESD scores. Similar significant "partner" effects are observed for spouses. The results highlight the interdependence between patients and spouses, suggesting that targeting both simultaneously may lead to better outcomes in depression prevention programs.

• The proposed approach is compared to complete-case and available-case analyses, which fail to detect some "partner" effects. The proposed method provides extra insights into the interdependence of dyads, which can be useful for designing more efficient prevention programs. The simulation study demonstrates the proposed method's performance when the nonignorable missing data mechanism is misspecified. The results show that the proposed method yields unbiased estimates and reasonable coverage rates when the missing data mechanism is correctly specified.

• A sensitivity analysis is conducted to examine how the inference changes with respect to the values of parameters linking the missing outcome with the dropout process. The results show that the estimates are quite stable, except for some variations in the estimate of cancer stage

<summary>
• The relativistic embedding scheme is a method for solving the Dirac equation within a limited region of a larger system, by replacing the external region with an additional term in the Hamiltonian that acts on the surface separating the two regions. This scheme is derived using a trial function with a discontinuous small component across the surface, which leads to a perfectly regular expectation value of the energy.

• The method is demonstrated to be stable and convergent through calculations of the spectrum of a confined hydrogen atom and the local density of states for a silver monolayer in a gold-silver-gold sandwich structure. The results show that the relativistic embedding scheme can accurately reproduce the behavior of an extended system, and that it can be used to study relativistic effects on the electronic structure of materials containing heavier elements.</summary>

<summary>
* The study investigates the accuracy of the 2D approximation of the Helmholtz equation for flat 3D dielectric resonators using an effective index of refraction. The experimental length spectra of two circular dielectric microwave resonators are compared to the semiclassical trace formula, and the results show good agreement. However, the peak positions in the experimental length spectrum are slightly shifted with respect to the geometrical lengths of the periodic orbits.
* The shift is attributed to two effects: the frequency dependence of the effective index of refraction and a systematic inaccuracy of the 2D approximation. The study also compares the experimental length spectrum with the exact trace formula for the 2D dielectric circle resonator, which shows that the semiclassical trace formula needs to be improved for periodic orbits close to the critical angle. The results provide a refinement of the techniques used to understand the spectra of realistic microcavities and lasers in terms of the 2D trace formula.</summary>

<summary>
* The analysis of dynamic processes in complex networks is a major research area with applications in social, biological, and technological systems.
* The spread of information in online social networks, the evolution of an epidemic outbreak in human contact networks, and the dynamics of cascading failures in the electrical grid are relevant examples of these processes.
* The effects of temporal structural variations in the dynamics of networked systems remain poorly understood, and there is a lack of effective methodologies for utilizing adaptation mechanisms to contain spreading processes.
* This paper studies adaptation mechanisms over arbitrary contact networks and derives an explicit expression for a lower bound on the epidemic threshold of the adaptive susceptible-infected-susceptible (ASIS) model.
* The paper also proposes an efficient algorithm for optimally tuning the adaptation rates of an arbitrary network to eradicate an epidemic outbreak in the ASIS model.
* Numerical simulations confirm the tightness of the proposed lower bounds, and the optimal adaptation rates are compared with popular centrality measures.
* The results show that degree-based and eigenvector-based edge-centralities are good measures for determining the amount of investment in tuning cutting rates, while betweenness centrality does not show a significant dependency on the optimal cutting rates.
</summary>

<summary>
• Debris disk systems provide a look at an intermediate stage of stellar system evolution, representing the transition between the early formation of stars and planets and the mature stage of an evolved system. They have lost most of their primordial material, but the observed infrared luminosity of circumstellar dust is typically several orders of magnitude larger than estimated for the Kuiper and asteroid belts in our solar system. Researchers have been looking for circumstellar gas phase absorption in these systems.

• The detection of dusty circumstellar material around main sequence stars via infrared excesses has led to the search for circumstellar gas phase absorption. Only a few edge-on debris disks have been found, including β Pic, AU Mic, and HD 32297. These systems provide a unique opportunity to simultaneously measure both the dust and gas components of a debris disk.

• High-resolution optical spectra of the D doublet toward HD 32297 and stars in close angular proximity were obtained using the Coudé spectrometer on the 2.7 m Harlan J. Smith Telescope at McDonald Observatory. The spectra were obtained at a resolution of 72,000, and the data were reduced using IRAF and IDL routines. Wavelength calibration images were taken using a Th-Ar hollow cathode before and after each target.

• Two absorption components are detected toward HD 32297, while only one is detected toward its proximate neighbors located at a comparable distance. The extra absorption component in the spectrum of HD 32297, which is also at rest in the stellar reference frame, is therefore likely caused by circumstellar material. The ISM absorption is similar among HD 32297 and its two closest neighbors.

• The radial velocities of HD 32297, BD+07 777s, and BD+07 778 are measured and differ significantly, indicating that they are likely not physically associated. Some indication of temporal variability is detected over several epochs of observations. Instrumental resolution variations and masking by the strong ISM absorption make a definitive detection of circumstellar variability difficult.

• The measured circumstellar feature toward HD 32297 is the strongest such absorption measured toward any nearby main sequence debris disk, 45 times greater than the column density of the prototypical edge-on debris disk, β Pic. If the morphology and abundances of the stable gas component around HD 32297 are assumed to be similar to β Pic, an upper limit to the gas mass in the circumstellar disk surrounding HD 32297 of 0.3 M⊕ is estimated. The gas mass

<summary>
• The acoustic oscillations in the matter power spectrum at recombination can be used as a "standard ruler" to constrain the matter and energy content of the universe.
• The interpretation of the low-redshift acoustic oscillations is robust if the CMB correctly tells us the baryon-to-photon ratio and the epoch of matter-radiation equality.
• The actual densities of matter and radiation drop out of the calculation, and only their ratio matters, making the inferences for dark energy from the combined CMB and low-redshift survey data sets unchanged.
• Knowledge of the actual densities translates into improved constraints on the Hubble constant.
• The acoustic peak method depends on measuring the sound horizon, which is the comoving distance that a sound wave can travel between the end of inflation and the epoch of recombination.
• The sound horizon is robustly determined by the baryon-to-photon ratio and the redshift of equality, and is insensitive to the cosmology.
• The standard ruler defined by the acoustic oscillations can deal gracefully with uncertainties in the matter density, provided that the redshift of matter-radiation equality is well measured.</summary>

<summary>
* The considered bidirectional relay network consists of two users exchanging information via a relay node, with no direct link between the users.
* The network operates under a half-duplex constraint, where a node cannot transmit and receive at the same time and in the same frequency band.
* The goal is to develop an optimal mode selection and power allocation policy to maximize the average sum rate of both users.
* The proposed protocol requires the instantaneous channel state information (CSI) of the involved links in each time slot and their long-term statistics.
* The protocol jointly optimizes the selection of the transmission mode and the transmit powers of the nodes to achieve the maximum sum rate.
* The optimal mode selection and power allocation policy is derived using a Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) necessary condition approach.
* The proposed protocol outperforms existing protocols in terms of average sum rate, as confirmed by simulation results.
* The optimal values of the thresholds used in the protocol can be obtained offline and used as long as the channel statistics remain unchanged.
* The proposed protocol achieves the maximum sum rate in the considered bidirectional network and can be used as a reference for other low-complexity suboptimal protocols.</summary>

<summary>
* The paper discusses the computation of 3-point correlation functions in a conformal field theory (CFT) using the operator product expansion (OPE) and the anomalous dimension matrix. The authors focus on the case of N=4 super Yang-Mills (SYM) theory, which is a CFT with a known spectrum and 3-point correlation functions. They use integrability techniques to compute the couplings in the 3-point function of the Lagrangian with any two operators of the theory.

* The authors start by considering the deformation of a CFT by a marginal or irrelevant operator, which introduces new divergences in the renormalized operators of the critical theory. They show that the entries of the deformed anomalous dimension matrix between operators are determined by the couplings in the 3-point function. They also derive the Callan-Symanzik equation for correlation functions in the deformed theory.

* The authors then apply their results to the case of N=4 SYM theory, where they use integrability to compute the couplings in the 3-point function of the Lagrangian with any two operators of the theory. They consider the simplest case of the exact Lagrangian deformation, where the action of the matrix on the basis of operators represented as a spin chain is known.

* They also discuss the computation of 3-point correlation functions at strong coupling using the AdS/CFT duality. They consider the case of a heavy string state propagating between two boundary points and interacting with a light field sourced at the boundary point. They show that the 3-point function can be computed using a saddle point approximation to the string path integral.

* The authors then apply their results to specific examples, including the point particle, circular rotating string, and giant magnon. They show that the 3-point function can be computed using a saddle point approximation to the string path integral, and that the result agrees with the expected result from renormalization group arguments.

* They also discuss the computation of 3-point correlation functions with more general string configurations, including the spinning string solution with angular momenta both in the AdS and S^5 factors. They show that the 3-point function can be computed using a saddle point approximation to the string path integral, and that the result agrees with the expected result from renormalization group arguments.

* The authors conclude by discussing the implications of their results for the computation of correlation functions in N=4 SYM theory. They note that their approach can be

<summary>
• The neutrino mass matrix is a crucial component in understanding neutrino oscillations and the behavior of neutrinos in various experiments. Researchers have proposed an ansatz for the 3-generation neutrino mass matrix, which can be motivated from an SO(10) grand unified model.

• The ansatz is based on the assumption that the mass matrix is hermitian, and it can be brought to real diagonal form via a real rotation. The diagonalizing matrix can be parameterized using three angles and three phases, which can be used to describe neutrino oscillations.

• The ansatz can be combined with experimental results on neutrino oscillations to learn more about the neutrino mass matrix. By analyzing the results of various experiments, researchers can reconstruct the neutrino mass matrix and determine the neutrino masses.

• The reconstructed neutrino mass matrix can be used to make predictions about neutrinoless double beta decay, which is a process that can provide insight into the nature of neutrinos. The predictions can be compared with experimental results to test the validity of the ansatz.

• The ansatz can also be extended to the case of a complex neutrino mass matrix, which allows for CP-violating phases in the lepton mixing matrix. This can lead to a larger number of solutions and a more complex neutrino mass matrix, which can be tested against experimental results.</summary>

<summary>
* The merger of two neutron stars, two black holes, or a black hole and a neutron star are among the most important sources of gravitational waves due to the huge energy released in the process. The coalescence of double neutron stars may radiate about 10^6 erg in the last seconds of their inspiral trajectory, at frequencies up to 1.4-1.6 kHz. The rate at which these events occur in the local universe is another parameter characterizing if these mergings are potential interesting sources of gravitational waves. In spite of the large amount of work performed in the past years, uncertainties persist in estimates of the DNS coalescence rate.

* Numerical simulations based on Monte Carlo methods were performed to determine the critical redshift beyond which the duty cycle condition required to have a continuous background is satisfied. The simulations indicate that a truly continuous background is formed only when sources located beyond z=1.5 (z=1.2 for SFR1), including 96% (94% for SFR1) of all events. The density parameter Ωgw has a maximum around 670 Hz (630 Hz for SFR1), attaining an amplitude of about 6.0 × 10^-9 (4.5 × 10^-9 for SFR1). The low frequency cutoff around 1.2 kHz corresponds essentially to the gravitational redshifted wave frequency associated to last stable orbit of sources located near the maximum of the coalescence rate.

* The computed signal is below the sensitivity of the first and the second generation of detectors. However, using the planned sensitivity of third-generation interferometers, we found that after one year of integration, the cross-correlation of two EGO-like coincident antennas gives an optimized signal-to-noise of 1.5. The "popcorn" contribution is one order of magnitude higher with a maximum of 4.5 × 10^-8 (3.5 × 10^-8 for SFR1) at 1.2 kHz. This signal can be distinguished from the instrumental noise background and adequate data analysis strategies for its detection are currently under investigation.</summary>

<summary>
• Quantum information processing has attracted significant interest in recent years, with applications in quantum computing, quantum cryptography, and quantum networks.
• The transmission of quantum information through a communication channel is affected by environmental influences, leading to distorted qubits and the need for channel estimation.
• Channel estimation involves determining the properties of the quantum channel, which is essential for reliable quantum information transfer and the construction of quantum codes.
• The article discusses various protocols for estimating the parameters of different quantum channels, including the depolarizing channel, phase damping channel, and amplitude damping channel.
• The use of entangled qubit pairs is shown to enhance the estimation of the Pauli channel, a widely discussed channel in the context of quantum error correction.
• The article also extends the estimation strategy to higher-dimensional Hilbert spaces, considering the generalized Pauli channel and its estimation using entangled pairs.
• The results highlight the importance of entanglement as a non-classical resource in quantum information processing and the need for efficient channel estimation protocols in quantum communication.</summary>

<summary>
* The Levi-Civita (LC) spacetime has two essential constants, @xmath3 and @xmath0, which cannot be removed by coordinate transformations. The constant @xmath3 is related to the topology of spacetime and the deficit angle, while @xmath0 is the parameter that presents the most serious obstacles to its interpretation. The LC spacetime becomes flat if @xmath0 is 0 or @xmath11, and it has no horizons, indicating an upper limit to the mass per unit length of the line sources. The absence of circular test particle orbits for @xmath16 and the fact that most known material sources for LC require @xmath17 led to the interpretation that LC describes the field of a cylinder only if @xmath0 ranges within the (0, @xmath10) interval.

* However, interior solutions matching to LC exist with @xmath16, and the absence of circular test particle orbits for @xmath16 may be due to the fact that the centrifugal force required to balance the gravitational attraction implies velocities larger than the speed of light. The interpretation of LC as the spacetime generated by a cylinder whose radius increases with @xmath0 and tends to infinity as @xmath0 approaches @xmath11 has been proposed. The analysis of the total precession per revolution of a gyroscope circumventing the axis of symmetry in LC and the c-metric spacetimes provides additional elements for the interpretation of LC, and the results suggest that the meaning of @xmath2 in LC with @xmath130 is different from its usual interpretation as an angle.</summary>

<summary>
* The universe is currently in an accelerating phase, and this result is ascribed to the existence of a dark energy sector, an exotic energy source characterized by a negative pressure. The simplest candidate for dark energy is the cosmological constant, but it is plagued by some difficulties related to the small observational value of dark energy density. Several dark energy models have been proposed, such as quintessence, phantom, k-essence, tachyon, quintom, Chaplygin gas, and holographic dark energy.

* A possibility to explain the accelerated phase of the universe is to consider a theory of gravity based on the Weitzenböck connection, instead of the Levi-Civita one, which deduces that the gravitational field is described by the torsion instead of the curvature tensor. Teleparallel gravity possesses a number of attractive features related to geometrical and physical aspects. One can start from the teleparallel equivalent of general relativity (TEGR) and construct various gravitational modifications based on torsion.

* The aim of this paper is to explore the implications of f(T) gravity to the formation of light elements in the early universe, i.e., to the Big Bang Nucleosynthesis (BBN). BBN has occurred between the first fractions of a second after the Big Bang, around 1 sec, and a few hundred seconds after it, when the universe was hot and dense. The primordial mass fraction of 4He can be estimated by making use of the relation between the neutron abundance and the temperature.

* The authors investigate the bounds that arise from the BBN constraints on the free parameters of three f(T) models, namely the power-law, exponential, and square-root exponential models. Concerning the power-law f(T) model, the obtained constraint on the exponent n is n < 0.18. Concerning the exponential and the square-root exponential models, the authors show that, for realistic regions of free parameters, they always satisfy the BBN bounds.

* The authors conclude that viable f(T) models, namely those that pass the basic observational tests, can also satisfy the BBN constraints. This feature acts as an additional advantage of f(T) gravity, which might be a successful candidate for describing the gravitational interaction. The authors also note that this kind of constraints could contribute to the debate of fixing the most realistic picture that can be based on curvature or torsion.</summary>

<summary>
• The backreaction of accelerated particles on the shock is a nonlinear phenomenon that affects the shock structure and the spectrum of the accelerated particles. The most important issue is the violation of the test particle approximation, which occurs when the acceleration process becomes efficient enough to generate pressures of the accelerated particles comparable with the incoming gas kinetic pressure. This phenomenon is intrinsically nonlinear and changes both the spectrum of the particles and the structure of the shock.

• There are three viable approaches to account for the backreaction of the particles upon the shock: numerical simulations, a fluid approach, and an analytical approach. The analytical approach is helpful to understand the physics of the nonlinear effects, but it has limitations, such as providing an answer only for weakly modified shocks. Recently, some promising analytical solutions of the problem of nonlinear shock acceleration have appeared in the literature.

• The paper presents a generalization of the analytical method introduced in a previous work to describe the nonlinear shock acceleration with monochromatic injection of quasi-thermal particles. The approach is extended to account for both thermal particles and seed nonthermal particles. The case of interest is the study of supernova shocks propagating through the interstellar medium (ISM) where pressure balance exists between gas and cosmic rays.

• Nonlinear effects in shock acceleration of thermal particles result in the appearance of multiple solutions in certain regions of the parameter space. This behavior resembles that of critical systems, with a bifurcation occurring when some threshold is reached. The physical parameters that play a role in this approach to criticality are the maximum momentum achievable by the particles, the Mach number of the shock, and the injection efficiency.

• The paper investigates the shock modification due to the backreaction of the accelerated particles. The discussion is split into two parts: the case of pre-existing seed particles populating the region where the shock is propagating, and the case of acceleration of particles from the thermal distribution. The results show that the critical behavior found for shock acceleration also takes place in the case of reacceleration of seed particles.

• The presence of seed particles can change the critical behavior of shocks. The shock may be modified by the backreaction of the accelerated particles even for very low values of the injection efficiency, because of the presence of seed particles. The nonlinearity of the shock can be dominated by the presence of preaccelerated particles rather than by the acceleration of particles from the thermal pool.

• The paper proposes a semi-analytical approach to show that the backreaction of particles accelerated at a shock is able to affect the

<summary>
* The principle of quantum superposition plays a crucial role in quantum mechanics, and its destruction and preservation are central to issues like the quantum-to-classical transition and quantum information processing. The loss of coherence in quantum systems is rooted in the environmental action upon the system.
* A novel approach to derive master equations (MEs) using stochastic methods and operator techniques is developed, allowing for both Markovian and non-Markovian regimes. The main idea is to build random evolution operators containing the decohering effect of the environment and take the stochastic expectation value.
* The Jaynes-Cummings model (JCM) is used to illustrate the method, and the phase-damping master equation is solved using the stochastic approach. The solution is compared to existing methods and found to be more efficient.
* The stochastic approach is also applied to non-Markovian situations, providing a common language for both Markovian and non-Markovian evolutions. The method is used to generalize intrinsic decoherence models and propose a novel generalization of the JCM.
* The stochastic approach is compared to dynamical collapse models, and it is found that the random unitary operators used do not produce state vector reduction. The method is also used to propose a generalization to the JCM, which is compared to experimental results in cavity QED and ion traps.</summary>

<summary>
* The contact pattern among individuals in a population plays a crucial role in the spread of infectious diseases, and network analysis methods can be used to investigate the contact structure and its effects on disease spread. Scale-free networks, which exhibit a power-law degree distribution, are commonly found in real-world networks, including human sexual contacts. These networks can have significant epidemiological implications, as epidemics can propagate faster in scale-free networks than in single-scale networks.

* Epidemic models, such as the susceptible-infected (SI) and susceptible-infected-susceptible (SIS) models, have been used to model the transmission dynamics of various diseases, including sexually transmitted diseases and vector-borne diseases. These models can be used to simulate the spread of diseases on networks and provide insights into how to prevent and control them. By analyzing the structural properties of networks, researchers can better understand how diseases spread and identify potential targets for intervention.

* The study generated scale-free networks using different algorithms, including the Barabasi-Albert (BA) algorithm, and varied the number of vertices, edges, and directionality of the networks. The networks were then used to simulate the spread of acute and chronic diseases using the SI and SIS models. The simulations were run multiple times, and the average prevalence of the disease was calculated for each network.

* The results of the simulations showed that the disease spread independently of the value of the transmission probability used, and that an increase in the transmission probability led to an increase in the prevalence of the infection. The prevalence of the disease also tended to stabilize at a certain level, despite the addition of vertices. The study found that the networks generated using the BA algorithm presented the lowest values of prevalence in the spreading simulations.

* The study also found that the directed networks had a lower prevalence of the disease compared to the undirected networks, due to the limitations imposed by the direction of the movements. The prevalence of the disease in the directed networks was also found to be smaller than in the undirected networks. The study suggests that the directionality of the networks can have a significant impact on the spread of diseases.

* The study's results have implications for the prevention and control of diseases, particularly in cases of sanitary emergency. The study suggests that the prevention of potentially infectious contacts may contribute to controlling a disease. The study also highlights the importance of considering the structural properties of networks when modeling the spread of diseases.

* Overall, the study demonstrates the importance of using network analysis methods to understand the spread of infectious diseases. By analyzing the

<summary>
* The study focuses on the behavior of polyampholytes (PAs), which are flexible chains with quenched charges, and their phase diagrams in various dimensions.
* The results show that the behavior of PAs is similar to that of random chains with short-range interactions in dimensions d ≤ 4, while in dimensions d ≥ 5, the spatial conformations of a PA strongly depend on its excess charge.
* The study also explores the phase diagram of PAs in three dimensions, where a finite fraction of PAs have excess charges exceeding the Rayleigh charge, leading to a controversy about the behavior of PAs in this case.
* The results of the study provide insight into the behavior of PAs in general space dimensions and suggest that the borderline case of three dimensions is the most controversial.
* The study also discusses the possibility of a glass transition in PAs, where the molten globule freezes into its ground state, and suggests that additional studies are needed to establish this transition.</summary>

<summary>
• The paper discusses the thermal instability and ionization structure of the transition layers in an X-ray illuminated disk, and how it affects the X-ray line emission and reflection from the disk.
• The authors find that the existence of an intermediate stable layer enhances the emission in the 0.5-1.5 keV band, and that the equivalent widths of the emission lines are less than 1.0 eV, with respect to the ionizing continuum.
• The detectability of these recombination emission and reflection lines depends on whether the primary continuum is viewed directly, and the signal-to-noise ratio can be greatly enhanced when the primary continuum is obscured, making these lines observable.</summary>

<summary>
* The localization length of light in one-dimensional disordered systems has been studied, focusing on homogeneous and mixed stacks of layers with different indices of refraction and thickness. The positions of the layer boundaries have been randomly shifted with respect to ordered periodic values, and the refraction indices present no disorder. The transmission bands modulate the localization length, and this modulation decreases with increasing disorder.

* For homogeneous stacks, the parabolic behavior of the localization length in the limit of long wavelengths has been recovered, and the localization length saturates for very low values of wavelength. The localization length is practically independent of the disorder at the first gap and is enhanced at the center of each allowed band. The localization length has been characterized in terms of the reflection coefficient of alternating layers and the optical path across one grating period.

* When left-handed metamaterials are introduced in the system, the localization length behavior presents some differences with respect to traditional stacks formed exclusively by right-handed materials. For low-disordered mixed stacks and wavelengths of several orders of magnitude greater than the grating period, the localization length depends linearly on the wavelength with a slope inversely proportional to the modulus of the reflection amplitude between alternating layers. The localization length saturates for low wavelengths, and this saturation constant is proportional to the inverse of the reflection coefficient.

* The localization length has been studied in the case of both homogeneous and mixed stacks with non-symmetric band distribution, and the results show that the localization length presents an irregular form in all the transmission spectrum. These changes in the localization length are more sensitive in mixed stacks than in homogeneous structures. The final expression for the localization length in the linear region has been derived, taking into account losses and absorption terms.</summary>

<summary>
• The standard cosmological model, also known as the concordance model, suggests that ordinary matter makes up only 4% of the universe's total mass-energy, while dark matter and dark energy make up 23% and 73%, respectively. Dark matter is thought to be composed of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs) and plays a crucial role in the formation of large-scale structures. However, the nature of dark matter remains unknown.

• The modified Newtonian dynamics (MOND) theory proposes that the law of gravity needs to be modified at low accelerations, rather than invoking dark matter. This theory has been successful in explaining the rotation curves of galaxies without the need for dark matter. However, it is not a fundamental theory and requires a more complete explanation.

• One approach to explaining MOND is through the concept of "gravitational polarization," which is analogous to the polarization of electric dipoles in a dielectric material. This idea suggests that the gravitational field is modified by the presence of a "dipolar" medium, which could be composed of negative masses. However, this idea is still highly speculative and requires further development.

• Another approach is to consider a "dipolar" dark matter model, which proposes that dark matter is composed of particles with a dipole moment. This model has been shown to reproduce the phenomenology of MOND at the level of galaxies and is also consistent with cosmological observations. However, it is still a descriptive model and requires a more fundamental explanation.

• The dipolar dark matter model also contains dark energy in the form of a cosmological constant and offers a unification between dark energy and dark matter. The model is consistent with observations and provides a possible explanation for the observed acceleration of the universe's expansion. However, it is still a developing area of research and requires further testing and refinement.</summary>

<summary>
• The hadronic final state of 200 GeV collisions may provide a reference for other high-energy nuclear collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Claims for novel physics at higher energies or in different collision systems should be based on an accurate and self-consistent phenomenology for conventional processes at 200 GeV. Current theoretical and experimental descriptions of high-energy collisions appear to be incomplete. Several unresolved aspects of collisions are notable, including the role of collision centrality and the nature of the underlying event.

• The two-component (soft+hard) model (TCM) of hadron production in high-energy nuclear collisions has been reviewed for collisions and collisions. The TCM serves as a mathematical framework for data description and then, after comparisons with theory, as a basis for physical interpretation of data systematics. The TCM has been interpreted to represent two main sources of final-state hadrons: longitudinal projectile-nucleon dissociation (soft) and large-angle-scattered (transverse) parton fragmentation (hard). In collisions, the two processes scale respectively proportional to participant nucleons and binary encounters.

• The TCM has been extended to include the nonjet (NJ) quadrupole as a third component of all high-energy nuclear collisions. An effective TCM should be complete and self-consistent, capable of describing all aspects of data from any collision system. The joint single-charged-particle 2D (azimuth integral) density on and is denoted by. The dependence of on was determined, and minimum-bias (MB) spectra were decomposed into soft and hard components according to the TCM. Soft and hard spectrum components have fixed forms but their relative admixture varies with.

• The measured hard components of spectra, densities, and 2D angular correlations presented in this study complete a unified experimental and theoretical picture of MB dijet production established previously for collisions. The combined dijet and quadrupole results from the present study convey important implications for claims of collectivity, centrality, UE studies, and the mechanism of the CMS ridge. The term "collective" or "collectivity" is ambiguous, and introducing the term "collectivity" as synonymous with "flow" may produce confusion. Dijet production and the NJ quadrupole amplitude follow characteristic trends on precisely over a large range of amplitudes.</summary>

<summary>
• The iron pnictide superconductor BaFe2As2 exhibits strong in-plane anisotropy in its electronic structure, which is difficult to study experimentally due to twinning effects, but can be well-reproduced by angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) calculations using the Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker Green function (KKR-GF) approach.
• The calculations reveal a strong dependence on the polarization of light, indicating a multiorbital character, and identify steep bands along the antiferromagnetic axis as surface states, which are only visible near the Fermi level for an As-terminated surface, leading to the conclusion that an As-terminated surface is the most likely surface termination for BaFe2As2.</summary>

<summary>
• Half-metallic ferromagnets with high Curie temperatures are ideal for spintronics applications, and much experimental and theoretical effort has been devoted to designing and searching for such materials. Among these, Cr-doped dilute magnetic semiconductors and Cr-based alloys have attracted particular attention. Theoretical calculations have verified the half-metallic character of these compounds.

• The high value of the Curie temperature has also been supported by some of these studies. Thin films of CrSb grown by solid-source molecular beam epitaxy on GaAs, (Al,Ga)Sb, and GaSb have been found to be of zinc blende structure and ferromagnetic with Curie temperatures higher than 400 K. Galanakis and Mavropoulos have examined the possibility of half-metallic behavior in ordered zinc blende compounds of transition metals V, Cr, and Mn with the 3d elements N, P, As, Sb, S, Se, and Te.

• Their theoretical study shows that the half-metallic ferromagnetic character of these compounds is preserved over a wide range of lattice parameters. They also found that the half-metallic character is maintained for the transition element terminated (001) surfaces of these systems. Yamana et al. have studied the effects of tetragonal distortion on zinc blende CrAs and CrSb and found the half-metallicity to survive large tetragonal distortions.

• The ground states of many of these compounds in the bulk are known to be different from the zinc blende structure, the most common structure being the hexagonal NiAs-type. Zhao and Zunger have argued that zinc blende MnAs, CrAs, CrSb, and CrTe are epitaxially unstable against the NiAs structure, and zinc blende CrSe is epitaxially stable only for lattice constants higher than 6.2 Å, remaining half-metallic at such volumes.

• These results reveal the challenge experimentalists face in synthesizing these compounds in zinc blende structure. However, the possibility remains open that such difficulties will be overcome with progress in techniques of film-growth and materials preparation in general. Recently, Deng et al. were successful in increasing the thickness of zinc blende CrSb films to 3 nm by molecular beam epitaxy using (In,Ga)As buffer layers.

• Li et al. were able to grow 4 nm thick zinc blende CrSb films on NaCl (100) substrates. In view of the

<summary>
* A graph is considered closed if it has a closed labeling, which is a bijection between the vertices and the set of integers from 1 to n, where n is the number of vertices. A labeling is closed if whenever there are distinct edges with either a common vertex or a common label, then the vertices or labels are connected by an edge.

* Closed graphs were first encountered in the study of binomial edge ideals, and a key result is that the binomials form a Gröbner basis of the ideal if and only if the labeling is closed. The name "closed" was introduced in a later paper.

* A connected graph is narrow if every vertex is distance at most one from every longest shortest path. Narrowness is a key property of connected closed graphs, and every connected closed graph is narrow.

* Algorithm [alg:labeling] is introduced, which labels the vertices of a connected graph. The algorithm works by selecting an endpoint of a longest shortest path with minimal degree and labeling it as 1, then going through the vertices in increasing order of distance from 1 and labeling them.

* The labeling produced by algorithm [alg:labeling] allows us to define the layers of the graph, which interact with the function f as follows: if i is in layer l_q and j is in layer l_{q+1}, then f(i) < f(j).

* The main result of the paper is that a connected graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and narrow. One direction is proved, and the proof of the converse is harder.

* The proof of the converse involves showing that the labeling produced by algorithm [alg:labeling] is closed when the input graph is chordal, claw-free, and narrow. This is done by induction on the number of vertices.

* The paper concludes by noting that the chordal hypothesis can be replaced with the weaker hypothesis that all cycles of length 3, 4, or 5 have a chord, and that the theorem is based on the senior honors thesis of the second author.</summary>

* The wormlike chain model is a standard coarse-graining model for semiflexible polymers, which takes into account the penalty for bending energy and local inextensibility. This model was proposed by Kratky and Porod and has been extensively studied in the last half century.

* The transverse distribution function of a polymer embedded in two-dimensional space has been found to possess a bimodal shape for short polymers, which is considered a manifestation of semiflexibility. This bimodal shape has also been found in recent exact calculations for the related distribution function of the 2D polymer.

* In this paper, the authors study the transverse distribution function of the three-dimensional wormlike chain with a fixed orientation of one polymer end using the exact representation of the distribution function. The exact solution of the Green's function made it possible to compute various quantities such as the structure factor and the end-to-end distribution function.

* The authors present analytical results for short and long wormlike chains based on the exact formula, which are in complete agreement with previous results obtained using different methods. The short chain expansion is obtained by replacing the matrix element with the leading order term in the expansion.

* The authors also present results of numerical computations of the distribution function for polymers with different numbers of monomers. The results show that the distribution function possesses a bimodal shape at intermediate chain lengths within a certain interval.

* The origin of the bimodal behavior of the projected distribution function of the free end of the wormlike chain is discussed qualitatively. The very short wormlike chain behaves similarly to a weakly bending stiff rod, resulting in a Gaussian distribution function.

* For larger contour lengths, the curvature fluctuations are small and controlled by the bending energy, resulting in a roughly uniform distribution function within a certain range. The inhomogeneities of curvature fluctuations in the vicinity of the clamped end are responsible for the maximum at a finite value of the transverse displacement.

* The authors compare the onset of bimodality in 2D and 3D chains and find that the difference is marginal for short chains. The number of segments for 3D and 2D chains at the onset is recomputed using the dependence of the persistence length on dimensionality.

* The accuracy of the calculations is checked by verifying that at large contour lengths, the numerical evaluation of the distribution function gives the Gaussian distribution with high accuracy. The sufficient level of matrix truncations and the number of terms in the expansion over Legendre polynomials increase

<summary>
* Cosmic rays are elementary particles that arrive at Earth from outside, discovered in the early 20th century as a main source of natural radiation. The cosmic ray spectrum has been observed as a continuum at all energies since their discovery. Cosmic rays have always been the source of the highest energy elementary particles known to mankind, giving birth to particle physics. The high-energy tail of the spectrum corresponds to energies up to 3 x 10^20 eV and rates of a few particles per km^2 per century.

* The observation of high-energy cosmic rays has been reviewed, showing good agreement between different experiments, including the low and high-energy regions of the spectrum. There is increasing evidence for a different component of the high-energy end of the cosmic ray spectrum. Composition studies have also given indications of a change to light element composition for energies above 10^19 eV. The highest energy events detected present a serious challenge to theory, and little is known about their origin.

* The conventional approach to explaining cosmic rays involves acceleration through stochastic acceleration, as suggested by Fermi in 1949. However, few known astrophysical objects satisfy the minimum requirements to accelerate particles to 10^20 eV. Alternative scenarios are being discussed, including acceleration in young pulsars, gamma-ray bursts, and active galaxies. The power supply needed to keep the observed cosmic rays at the highest energies is consistent with the known power and distributions of these objects.

* The study of inclined showers can contribute to the composition issue, and recent progress has been made in understanding different features of inclined showers. The Haverah Park array has been used to analyze inclined shower data, and the results have been compared to simulations. A fairly robust bound on the photon composition at ultra-high energies can be established, assuming a two-component proton-photon scenario. The photon component of the integral spectrum above 4 x 10^19 eV must be less than 30% at the 95% confidence level.</summary>

<summary>
* The calculation of energy and lifetime of a resonance state is a complex problem, and various methods have been proposed to address it, including the complex scaling method and the density of states (DOS) method.
* The DOS method relies on the calculation of Ritz-variational eigenfunctions and eigenvalues for many different values of a non-linear parameter, but it has some drawbacks, such as the difficulty in assessing the accuracy of the results.
* A new optimization rule is proposed to supplement the DOS method, which results in a convergent series of approximate values for the energy and lifetime of resonance states.
* The method is based on the selection of a set of eigenstates that are particularly affected by the presence of a resonance, using a prescription that takes advantage of the variational eigenvalues and the scaling properties of the spectrum.
* The method is tested on two models, a one-particle model and a two-particle model, and the results show that the energy and lifetime of the resonance state can be accurately calculated using the proposed method.
* The method is robust and can be applied to systems with more than three particles, but the applicability may be restricted due to the difficulties in handling large basis sets.
* The calculation of the resonance width is more subtle, and a golden-rule-like formula is used to calculate the width, but the results show that the width does not converge to a definite value.
* The method presented in this work provides a new approach to calculate the energy and lifetime of resonance states, and it can be used to improve the accuracy of the results obtained using other methods.</summary>

<summary>
• The no-core shell model with the resonating group method (NCMS/RGM) has been extended to include three-body dynamics, allowing for the study of systems with three-body configurations.
• This new approach has been applied to the study of both bound and continuum states of 6He within a basis of 4He+n+n, with the obtained wave functions featuring an appropriate asymptotic behavior.
• The results for the ground state energy of 6He are compared to NCMS calculations, showing a difference of approximately 1 MeV due to the excitations of the 4He core.
• The inclusion of the excitations of the core will be achieved in a future work through the use of the no-core shell model with continuum approach (NCMSC).
