• The use of three-cluster dynamics is essential for describing 6He states in the continuum, and preliminary results have obtained the experimentally well-known 2+ resonance as well as a second low-lying 2+ resonance.
• The obtained wave functions feature a large extension of the system, with the probability distribution of the main component of the wave function showing two characteristic peaks corresponding to the di-neutron and cigar configurations.
• The extension of the NCMS/RGM approach to properly describe three-cluster configurations is essential for the study of nuclear systems that present such configurations, such as two-nucleon halo nuclei and resonant systems.</summary>

<summary>
• Cold atoms in optical lattices is a field that combines quantum gases from atomic physics and laser theory from quantum optics. Optical lattices are artificial crystals of light, created by the interference of two or more laser beams. Atoms can be cooled and trapped in these optical lattices, allowing for the study of quantum behavior. This field has led to the observation of phenomena such as Bloch oscillations, Wannier-Stark ladders, and tunneling.

• The success of the superfluid to Mott insulator (SF-MI) transition in cold atoms in optical lattices has given rise to the possibility of using it as a test laboratory for phenomena in condensed matter physics. The SF-MI transition is an important phenomenon in condensed matter physics. The observation of this transition has led to a deluge of studies, bringing together atomic physicists, quantum opticians, and condensed matter physicists. This field has reached a stage where it can be used as an instructional means.

• The history of Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) began in 1924 when Satyendra Nath Bose first gave the rules governing the behavior of photons. Einstein extended these rules to other bosons, giving birth to the Bose-Einstein distribution. Einstein predicted that when the temperature goes down, almost all particles in a bosonic system would congregate in the ground state. This physical state is called Bose-Einstein condensation.

• The observation of BEC led to the observation of the SF-MI transition, opening the possibility to investigate various phenomena in condensed matter physics by mimicking them with ultracold atoms in optical lattices. Theoretical papers have investigated these phenomena with fermionic cold atoms, but cold bosons are used in actual experiments for testing spin ordering. The recent observation of the MI with fermionic atoms has overcome this limitation.

• The possibility of using cold atoms in optical lattices as a test laboratory for condensed matter physics is no longer speculative. It has become an aspect of physics with its own methods and approaches. This field has reached a stage where it should start having some introductory impact on our curriculum. The purpose of this study is to present a pedagogical study of investigating spin ordering in an isolated double-well-type potential.

• The double-well potential can be created by superposing two standing waves with different periods and depths. The potential bias or tilt of the double-well is introduced by changing the relative phase of the two potentials. This can be realized by applying a magnetic field gradient

<summary>
* The M31 globular cluster B158 contains a bright X-ray source, XB158, which was discovered by the Einstein Observatory and has been observed in every X-ray observation of the region since. XB158 exhibited strong intensity modulation on a 12.78 hr period during the 2002 January XMM-Newton observation. The amplitude of modulation decreased with increasing source intensity, and no modulation was found in the 2001 June XMM-Newton observation. Assuming this represents the orbital period, XB158 is likely a neutron star binary with a low mass donor.

* XB158 is analogous to 4U 1916-053, a high inclination neutron star low mass X-ray binary (LMXB) with an X-ray period of 50.00 min and an optical period of 50.458 min. 4U 1916-053 exhibits periodic X-ray intensity dips due to absorption by material in the outer disk, and the amplitude of these dips varies over 10-100% on a 14 day period, the precession period of the disk. XB158 appears to be a persistent superhumping source, and its disk precession period was estimated to be 29±1 times the orbital period, i.e., 81±3 hr. However, this estimate may be affected by the mass ratio of the donor to the accretor.

* The authors conducted three-dimensional smoothed particle hydrodynamical (SPH) modeling, assuming a 1.4 M⊙ neutron star, a 2.78 hr period, a total system mass of 1.8 M⊙, and a luminosity 80% of the Eddington limit. The disk precession period was estimated to be 29±1 times the orbital period, i.e., 81±3 hr. However, the actual super-orbital period may be longer than predicted due to the mass ratio of the donor to the accretor being lower than assumed. The mass of a Roche lobe filling main sequence star may be approximated as M2 ≈ 0.11 M⊙, where P is the orbital period in hours.

* The authors obtained 30 Swift observations over 2013 February 8 - March 9, each with 2.5 ks exposure and spaced 1 day apart. XB158 was one of two main targets for this survey, and the pointing was chosen to optimize the results from both targets. However, the actual pointings varied significantly over the

<summary>
• The core entropy of a polynomial is a measure of the complexity of its dynamics, and it is defined as the topological entropy of the restriction of the polynomial to its Hubbard tree. The Hubbard tree is a forward-invariant, finite topological tree that contains the critical points of the polynomial. The core entropy is a continuous function that extends to a continuous function from the Mandelbrot set to the real numbers. The main goal of the paper is to prove the continuity of the core entropy function.

• The paper uses a combinatorial approach to study the core entropy, by associating a labeled wedge to each external angle and constructing an infinite graph from it. The growth rate of the graph is related to the core entropy, and the paper proves that the growth rate is continuous as a function of the angle. The paper also proves that the core entropy is Hölder continuous at angles that are not purely periodic, and that the entropy function is actually Hölder continuous at angles such that the external ray lands at a Misiurewicz parameter or at the root of a hyperbolic component.</summary>

<summary>
• The cataclysmic variable HU Aqr is a binary system consisting of a 0.80 white dwarf and a 0.18 main-sequence companion star, with two planets in orbit around them. The presence of these planets allows for the reconstruction of the binary's evolution and the determination of its initial conditions. The planets' orbits are affected by the mass loss from the primary star during the common-envelope phase, which can be either adiabatic or impulsive. The rate of mass loss can be constrained by the eccentricity of the inner planet.

• The initial binary orbit and the core mass of the primary star can be constrained by the requirement that the mass transfer in the post-common-envelope binary should be stable. The orbital solution for the inner planet is insensitive to the semi-major axis of the zero-age binary, and each of these solutions was tested for dynamical stability. The calculations were repeated with different initial conditions to verify the results, and the stable systems were identified. The eccentricity of the outer orbit of the stable systems is somewhat smaller than the observed value for HU Aqr.

• The presence of two planets in orbit around HU Aqr allows for a precision reconstruction of the evolution of the binary system. The initial conditions of the binary system, including the primary mass, secondary mass, orbital separation, and the orbital separations of both planets, can be derived. The rate of mass lost in the common-envelope parameters can also be measured. The binary parameters at birth and after the common-envelope phase can be compared to calculate the two parameters α and λ.

• The measured rate of mass loss for HU Aqr is consistent with numerical common-envelope studies, and the derived value of α is somewhat smaller than earlier studies. The alternative λ-formalism for common-envelope ejection gives a value consistent with the determination of λ in other cataclysmic variables. The inner planet in HU Aqr formed at a distance consistent with planets found to orbit other binaries. It is possible that additional planets formed further out, which would have even higher eccentricity than those already found.</summary>

<summary>
* The concept of parity-time (PT) symmetric systems was introduced by Bender and collaborators as an alternative to standard quantum theory, where the Hamiltonian is postulated to be Hermitian. PT-symmetric systems can have real spectra, making them suitable for physical descriptions. Recent developments in optics have led to experimental realizations of PT-symmetric Hamiltonians. The controllable imposition of symmetrically set and globally balanced gain and loss can render optical waveguiding arrays a fertile territory for constructing PT-symmetric complex potentials.

* The authors propose generalizations of one-dimensional PT-symmetric nonlinear oligomers into two-dimensional plaquettes, which can be used as fundamental building blocks for constructing PT-symmetric two-dimensional lattices. They introduce four basic types of plaquettes, three of which are in the form of four-site squares, and the final one is in the form of a five-site cross. The analysis is restricted to modes that can be found in analytical form, while their stability against small perturbations is analyzed by numerical methods. Many effects are found, including the existence of solution branches that terminate at critical points of the respective linear PT-symmetric systems.

* The authors examine the spectral stability of the different configurations and find that most stationary modes are unstable, although stable branches are found in some cases. They also study the perturbed dynamics of the modes and find that the evolution of unstable ones typically leads to the growth of amplitudes at gain-carrying sites and decay at lossy ones. Passive sites without gain or loss might be tipped towards growth or decay, depending on the particular solution and possibly on specific initial conditions. The next relevant step in the analysis may be to search for more sophisticated stationary modes produced by symmetry breaking.

* The authors note that the issue of potential existence of isolated solutions versus branches of solutions in PT-symmetric systems is already being addressed in the literature. They also mention that the present work may pave the way for further considerations of two-dimensional PT-symmetric lattice systems and even three-dimensional ones. The natural generalization is to construct periodic two-dimensional lattices of the building blocks presented here and identify counterparts of the modes reported here in infinite lattices, along with new modes that may exist in that case. The examination of a PT-symmetric cube composed of eight sites and the nonlinear modes it can support may be a preamble towards constructing full three-dimensional PT-symmetric lattices.</summary>

<summary>
• The independence number of a graph is the cardinality of a largest set of independent vertices, and the maximum independent set problem is to find an independent set with the largest number of vertices in a given graph.
• The paper studies the maximum independent set problem for generalized Petersen graphs, which are defined by a vertex set and an edge set, and provides upper and lower bounds for the independence number.
• The authors prove that the independence number of generalized Petersen graphs with fixed k can be found in linear time, and provide a table of independence numbers for certain values of n and k.
• The paper also proves Behsaz-Hatami-Mahmoodian's conjecture for some cases, which states that the independence number of a generalized Petersen graph is at least (n+1)/2.</summary>

<summary>
• The spin resonance in iron-based superconductors (FeBS) is analyzed, and it is found that the resonance appears below the indirect gap scale, which is determined by the sum of gaps on two different Fermi surface sheets connected by the scattering wave vector. The indirect gap is either Δ0 + Δ1 or 2Δ0, depending on the Fermi surface geometry.

• The peak frequency in inelastic neutron scattering (INS) is compared with the maximal and minimal gap sizes, and it is found that the peak frequency is less than the indirect gap in most cases, indicating that the peak is the true spin resonance. However, in some cases, the peak frequency is greater than the indirect gap, and the calculation of the dynamical spin susceptibility is required to make a final conclusion.

• The analysis of experimental data on the peak in INS and gaps extracted from various techniques shows that the peak in INS is the true spin resonance in most cases, and the superconducting state has the s± gap structure. However, there are some cases where the peak frequency is greater than the indirect gap, and further calculations are required to determine the gap structure.</summary>

<summary>
• Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are brief, intense explosions of energy that can be detected from great distances, and their afterglows can be observed in X-rays for several hours or days after the burst. The XMM-Newton satellite has observed the afterglows of two GRBs, GRB 011211 and GRB 001025, and detected X-ray sources at the locations of these bursts.

• The X-ray spectrum of GRB 011211 can be described as a simple power-law with a photon index of 2.16, modified by galactic absorption, and no significant spectral evolution was found during the observation. The X-ray flux of GRB 011211 declined significantly during the observation, providing additional evidence for its identification as the afterglow of the burst.

• The X-ray spectrum of GRB 001025 is also consistent with a power-law model, with a photon index of 2.01 and galactic absorption, and its flux was much lower than that of GRB 011211. Although no optical afterglow was detected for GRB 001025, the X-ray spectrum is typical of GRB afterglows, supporting its identification as the afterglow of the burst.

• The lack of significant absorption above galactic values in the X-ray spectra of both GRBs is consistent with the lack of detected reddening in the optical spectrum of GRB 011211, and suggests that the bursts may not have occurred in high-density star-forming regions. The X-ray spectra of both GRBs are consistent with a common physical process, such as synchrotron emission, and do not depend on the differences in the burst environments.</summary>

<summary>
• The presence of impurities in a quantum system can significantly modify its coherence and transport properties, and the introduction of correlations in the impurity distribution can lead to the appearance of delocalized states. This has been demonstrated in one-dimensional systems, but the effect of correlations in two-dimensional systems is still largely unexplored.

• A 2D generalization of the dual random dimer model (2D-DRDM) has been introduced, where impurities cannot be first neighbors and each impurity modifies the hopping with its nearest neighbor sites. The model exhibits a resonance energy at which the structured impurity is transparent, and states around this energy are delocalized.

• The introduction of weak interactions in the 2D-DRDM system leads to a non-monotonic behavior of the condensate fraction as a function of the disorder strength, and its enhancement for values close to the resonance condition. This effect is due to the resonance energy, which drives the density spatial fluctuations and introduces a coherence length that affects the system's behavior. The results suggest that short-range correlations in a disordered potential can modify and enhance the coherence of a many-body system in the weak interacting regime.
</summary>

<summary>
* The layered organic material 3 (ai3) has been studied since the 1980s and has recently attracted renewed interest due to its low-energy massless Dirac fermions under hydrostatic pressure.
* Compared to graphene, ai3 has a lower average Fermi velocity and a larger effective coupling constant for Coulomb-type electron-electron interactions.
* The material ai3 has additional massive carriers in the vicinity of the Fermi level, which has been pointed out in ab-initio band-structure calculations.
* Magneto-transport measurements of ai3 crystals under hydrostatic pressure have been performed to study the interplay between massless Dirac fermions and massive carriers.
* The measurements show the existence of high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes, in agreement with recent band-structure calculations.
* The interplay between both carrier types at low energy is the main result of the studies, and the measured mobilities hint at scattering mechanisms due to strongly screened interaction potentials or other short-range scatterers.
* The carrier density can be calculated from the Fermi-Dirac distribution and the density of states for massive and Dirac carriers.
* Thermopower measurements under pressure have been performed, showing a sign change for the Seebeck coefficient around 5 K, indicating a two-carrier scenario.
* The mobility of the Dirac carriers reaches 10^4 cm^2/Vs at low temperatures, a value comparable to already published values, while the mobility for massive carriers is two orders of magnitude smaller.
* The coexistence of massive and Dirac carriers holds with little perturbation in the whole range of pressure under study, and complementary studies such as spectroscopic measurements are highly desirable to confirm this picture.
</summary>

<summary>
• The experimental evidence of skyrmions in non-centrosymmetric compounds with Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction has intrigued many scientists, and the preparation of thin films of B20 type MnSi on silicon substrates has offered promising prospects for future spintronic devices. MnSi films offer a variety of interesting magnetic phases and are easy to integrate into devices due to the use of silicon as substrate material. However, the low magnetic ordering temperature of MnSi films is a drawback.

• A suitable candidate to overcome this limitation is the B20 compound MnGe, which has a magnetic ordering temperature of 170 K. The magnetic ground state of MnGe is a helical spin structure with a helix length between 3 nm at lowest temperatures and 6 nm near the ordering temperature. The helix axis is pinned along the [100] direction due to magnetic anisotropy.

• Recently, a large topological Hall effect was observed in MnGe, which was attributed to a skyrmion phase in analogy to MnSi. Further evidence for the existence of skyrmions was given by small-angle neutron scattering experiments. However, the synthesis of MnGe is laborious, as it forms only under high pressure and temperatures between 600 and 1000°C.

• Molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) allows for thin film growth under strong non-equilibrium conditions, but there has been no successful attempt to grow MnGe on Ge, as Mn and Ge tend to form Mn4Ge5. The use of Si(111) as a substrate offers the opportunity to prepare a seed layer of MnSi, which realizes the B20 crystal structure for MnGe growth.

• In this paper, a preparation method for MnGe thin films on Si substrates with the aid of a MnSi seed layer is presented. The structure and morphology of the films have been investigated by reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The physical properties of the samples have been determined by magnetization and magnetoresistance measurements.

• The MnGe films have been found to adopt the B20 structure from the MnSi seed layer, and the lattice parameter was determined to be 1% smaller than in bulk MnGe due to compressive strain imposed by the Si substrate. The magnetic properties of MnGe thin films are qualitatively similar to bulk, but the ordering temperature is enhanced to 200 K. No critical fields were observed up to 5 T

<summary>
• The detection of X-ray, optical, and radio afterglows from gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) suggests that most long GRBs are of cosmological origin. The fireball model is strongly favored, but the puzzle of GRBs remains unresolved. A major problem is determining whether GRBs are due to highly collimated jets or isotropic fireballs. The energetics involved cannot be determined without knowing the degree of beaming.

• Three methods may help determine the degree of beaming in GRBs. The first method involves analyzing the light curve of optical afterglows from a jetted GRB, which should be characterized by a break in the light curve during the relativistic phase. However, detailed numerical studies show that the break is usually quite smooth, and other factors can also result in light curve breaks. The first method is not conclusive due to these complexities.

• The second method involves measuring the polarization of optical afterglows from a jet, which can be strongly polarized in principle. Some positive observations have been reported, but polarization can only be observed under specific conditions. The third method involves searching for orphan afterglows, which are not associated with any detectable GRBs. The ratio of the orphan afterglow rate to the GRB rate might allow measurement of the GRB collimation angle.

• However, the absence of large numbers of orphan afterglows in many surveys has been regarded as evidence that the collimation cannot be extreme. Recently, it was argued that measurement of the GRB beaming angle using optical orphan searches is extremely difficult due to the low optical flux density of orphan afterglows. The detection limit needs to be improved to overcome this problem.

• Another difficulty associated with the third method is the existence of "failed gamma-ray bursts" (FGRBs), which are baryon-contaminated fireballs with initial Lorentz factors much less than 100. FGRBs can produce long-lasting afterglows that are detectable, manifesting themselves as orphan afterglows. The concept of FGRBs is based on the fact that most popular progenitor models for GRBs are baryon-rich.

• The derivation of a satisfactory light curve for an orphan afterglow is difficult due to the unknown trigger time. However, some possible solutions may help determine the onset of an orphan afterglow, such as improving the detection limit, identifying FGRBs with fast X-ray transients, observing the rising phase of the orphan, and using radio observations and gravitational wave

<summary>
* Massive stars play a crucial role in the evolution of galaxies, but their formation process remains unclear due to the difficulty of observing individual protostars. Recent advances in instrumentation have enabled high-resolution imaging of massive protostellar systems, providing new insights into their formation.

* Observations of four massive young stellar objects have revealed Keplerian disks surrounding them, suggesting an accretion formation scenario for massive stars. Further studies of hot molecular cores and their properties can help discriminate between competing models of massive star formation.

* The mid-infrared window offers a powerful view of hot molecular cores, allowing for the observation of class II methanol masers that exclusively trace regions of massive star formation. Recent observations have found that maser sites with weak radio continuum flux are associated with massive, luminous, and deeply embedded cores.

* High-resolution observations of three star-forming complexes have revealed multiple point sources at close angular separations, which may be physically bound or simply close due to projection effects. The mass distribution of stars in these clusters is difficult to generate using a standard form of the initial mass function.

* Monte Carlo simulations suggest that it is unlikely that the mass distribution of the most massive stars can be produced by sampling a standard form of the initial mass function from the reservoir of gas available for star formation. However, a larger sample of young, massive protoclusters is required to draw general conclusions.</summary>

<summary>
• Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) is often said to be unconditionally secure, but in practice, it is difficult for devices to meet the requirements, leading to security breaches.
• To combat practical attacks, counter-measures such as device-independent security proof and measurement-device-independent QKD (MDIQKD) have been proposed.
• MDIQKD removes potential loopholes of detectors without sacrificing performance, and it has been shown to cover about twice the distance of standard decoyed QKD.
• The only assumption needed in MDIQKD is that the preparation of quantum signal sources by Alice and Bob is almost perfect and carefully characterized.
• Two phase encoding MDIQKD schemes have been proposed, one employing phase locking of two separate laser sources and the other using conversion of phase encoding into polarization encoding.
• The security of these schemes with basis-dependent flaw has been proven by generalizing the quantum coin idea.
• Simulation results imply that the first scheme covers shorter distances and may require less accuracy of state preparation, while the second scheme can cover much longer distances with precise state preparation.
• The key generation rate of each scheme has been simulated assuming typical experimental parameters, and the effect of imperfect state preparation has been evaluated.
• The results highlight the importance of very accurate preparation of states to avoid basis-dependent flaws in MDIQKD.
• The study concludes that very precise state preparation is crucial in the security of not only MDIQKD but also in standard QKD.
</summary>

<summary>
• Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are brighter than most other types of supernovae and exhibit uniform light curves, making them useful as a standard candle to measure distances to remote galaxies. A plausible explosion model for SNe Ia is the accreting white dwarf (WD) model, in which a white dwarf in a binary system accretes material from the companion star and eventually explodes. The accreting WD model predicts that there are two main evolutionary paths leading to SNe Ia, the super soft X-ray source (SSS) channel and the symbiotic channel. The model also predicts which companion stars lead to SNe Ia.

• To confirm the evolutionary scenario for SNe Ia, it is necessary to identify the companion star that should remain in the vicinity of the explosion site. A direct method to prove that the companion star is located inside the SN ejecta is proposed, which involves observing the absorption lines in the spectrum of the companion star. The absorption lines with broad blue wings can be used to identify companion stars of SNe Ia. However, there are some factors that might reduce or erase these distinct absorption features, such as the uncertainty in the explosion model and the ionization of ions in the shocked region.</summary>

<summary>
* The first evidence of time reversal symmetry violation was found in the kaon system, but no other signals have been detected to date, despite strong efforts.
* Studying time reversal symmetry has become a cornerstone of the search for physics beyond the standard model of elementary particles.
* Theories beyond the standard model, such as dynamical symmetry breaking and supersymmetric theories, imply specific ways of time reversal symmetry violation.
* To extract hadronic degrees of freedom from observables, effective one-boson exchange potentials can be introduced, which have been proven useful in treating nuclear structure and extracting effective hadronic coupling constants.
* The absence of a complete solution of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) at low energies hampers the comparison of upper bounds on time reversal symmetry violation at a more fundamental level.
* Quark models, such as the constituent quark model, can be used to estimate hadronic matrix elements that arise when relating quark operators to effective hadronic parameterizations of time reversal symmetry violation.
* The results of the calculations show that the factors arising from quark structure effects reflect nucleon structure effects, which are due to spin, isospin structure, and different mass scales.
* The study concludes that the hadronization process does not substantially differ for time reversal symmetry violating and conserving interactions, and the factors arising reflect nucleon structure effects.</summary>

<summary>
• The security of continuous-variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) systems is compromised by local oscillator (LO) intensity fluctuations, which can be exploited by an eavesdropper (Eve) to gain partial or total secret keys.
• Eve can launch a LO intensity attack (LOIA) by attenuating the LO intensity, which can reduce the channel excess noise and allow her to intercept secret keys without being detected.
• The secret key rate of CVQKD systems is severely compromised when Bob does not monitor the LO intensity or scale his measurements with the instantaneous LO intensity values.
• For reverse reconciliation, Eve can obtain full secret keys without being found by controlling the LO transmission, even with a small attenuation of LO intensity.
• The effect of LO intensity fluctuation on the secret key rate is more severe for reverse reconciliation than for direct reconciliation.
• To ensure the security of CVQKD systems, it is essential to monitor the LO intensity carefully and scale the measurements with the instantaneous intensity values of the LO.
• Alternatively, scaling with the lowest intensity value of the LO can also ensure security, but it may lead to a reduction in the efficiency of key distribution.</summary>

<summary>
• Quantum entanglement is a fundamental feature of quantum mechanics that has garnered significant attention due to its crucial role in quantum information processing. It can be characterized and manipulated independently of its physical realization and is subject to a set of conservation laws. As such, it is regarded and treated as a physical resource.

• The quantification of entanglement becomes less clear when dealing with mixed states, which arise from the interaction of quantum systems with their environment. Various measures have been proposed to address this issue, including the entanglement of formation and the entanglement of distillation. These measures satisfy the requirements for a physical entanglement measure and provide a way to quantify entanglement in mixed states.

• The problem of bipartite entanglement in an open system is inherently related to the problem of tripartite entanglement in a closed system. The state of the environment is complex and unknown, and the partial trace with respect to the environment yields a mixed state for the bipartite system. To better characterize the entanglement, one must consider the way in which information about the system is read from the environment.

• Quantum trajectory theory provides a way to examine the entanglement dynamics of an open system by considering the conditional evolution of the system state based on the measurement record. This approach allows for the extraction of more entanglement from the system and provides a way to quantify entanglement in a contextual manner. The results of this paper demonstrate the importance of considering the conditional dynamics of an open system when quantifying entanglement.</summary>

<summary>
• Modified theories of gravity have gained attention after the discovery of the expanding accelerated universe, with dark energy being the mysterious force driving this acceleration. The Lovelock theory of gravity is a direct generalization of general relativity in higher dimensions, and the Gauss-Bonnet (GB) invariant is a quadratic curvature invariant that is free from spin-2 ghost instabilities. The GB invariant is a topological term in 4-dimensions, and to discuss its dynamics, it can be coupled with a scalar field or added to the Einstein-Hilbert action. This modified theory of gravity is an alternative to dark energy and has a rich cosmological structure. The curvature-matter coupling is another approach to modified gravity, and the authors have introduced the curvature-matter coupling in GB gravity. The authors have also reconstructed various cosmological models, including de Sitter universe, power-law solutions, phantom or non-phantom eras, and ΛCDM model in this gravity.

• The authors have used the reconstruction technique to reproduce some known cosmological solutions in this gravity, including de Sitter universe, power-law solutions, phantom or non-phantom eras, and ΛCDM model. The de Sitter cosmic evolution is interesting and well-known, and the authors have obtained the energy density of the form ρ = ρ0e−3λ(1+ω)N. The authors have also reconstructed the power-law solutions, which describe the decelerated and accelerated cosmic eras. The authors have also reconstructed the phantom and non-phantom cosmic history in this gravity. The authors have applied the usual reconstruction technique to reproduce the ΛCDM cosmology in this gravity. The authors have found that the considered gravity fails to reproduce ΛCDM cosmology for both cases.

• The authors have analyzed the stability of some cosmological evolutionary solutions about linear homogeneous perturbations in this modified gravity. The authors have constructed the perturbed field and continuity equations using isotropic and homogeneous universe models for both general and particular cases, including de Sitter and power-law solutions. The authors have assumed a general solution that satisfies the basic field equations for the FRW universe model in this gravity. The authors have used the numerical technique to solve the perturbed equations for the model. The authors have found that the de Sitter model is unstable, while the power-law solution is stable.

• The authors have investigated the stability of power-law solutions, which describe the accelerated and decelerated cosmological evolutionary phases in the background of the FR

<summary>
* The formation of supershells in galaxies, particularly in the context of NGC 3556, is a complex phenomenon that cannot be fully explained by traditional models such as starbursts or infalling gas clouds. The energy requirements for creating these supershells are too high, and there is no evidence of recent star formation or interacting companions in NGC 3556.
* A new model is proposed, where radio jets ejected during an active nuclear phase in the life of a large spiral galaxy could inflate out of the disk exceptionally large shells of neutral hydrogen gas. This model can account for the observed features of the supershells in NGC 3556, including their size, energy, and symmetry.
* The jet-ISM interaction scenario could effectively supplement the other two mechanisms already proposed for the supershell phenomenon, with a greater relevance whenever the shells are extraordinarily large and energetic and occur at large galactocentric distances. This model can also account for the symmetric HI features in galaxies and the presence of nonthermal radio halos.</summary>

<summary>
• The Leo I galaxy is a dwarf spheroidal (dSph) galaxy with unique characteristics, including a young stellar population and a lack of detectable quantities of HI. Its color-magnitude diagram (CMD) shows a broad main sequence turnoff and a wide range in luminosity of the red clump, indicating that star formation has extended from at least 10-15 Gyr ago to less than 1 Gyr ago. The CMD also suggests that star formation proceeded in a more or less continuous way, with possible intensity variations over time.

• The galaxy's metallicity range is estimated to be between z=0.0001 and z=0.004, with the upper limit varying from z=0.0004 to z=0.004, increasing with time. The width of the RGB can be accounted for by the dispersion in age alone, making the metallicity dispersion negligible. Further analysis using synthetic CMDs is needed to gain more insight into the galaxy's star formation history and chemical enrichment law.</summary>

<summary>
* The paper discusses the principal eigenvalue of the fractional Laplacian with a drift term, and its relation to the existence of first integrals of the drift. The authors prove that the principal eigenvalue remains bounded as the drift term increases, if and only if there exists a non-trivial first integral of the drift. They also show that the infimum of the principal eigenvalue is attained, and provide a characterization of the first integrals in terms of the flow generated by the drift.
* The authors use a variety of techniques, including the Krein-Rutman theorem, compactness arguments, and the properties of the Green function and heat kernel of the fractional Laplacian. They also employ a conditioning technique, inspired by previous work, to prove the upper bound for the principal eigenvalue. The paper concludes with an example, where the authors compute the principal eigenvalue and the first integral for a specific drift term, and show that the infimum is attained.</summary>

<summary>
• Majorana fermions (MFs) are real solutions of the Dirac equation and are their own antiparticles. They have been predicted to occur as quasi-particle bound states in engineered condensed matter systems. MFs obey non-Abelian statistics, which is important for potential applications in decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing. The possibility of hosting MFs in exotic solid-state systems has focused on topological superconductors.

• Various realistic platforms, including topological insulators, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains, have been proposed to support Majorana states based on the superconducting proximity effect. However, observing unique Majorana signatures experimentally is still a challenging task. MFs are predicted to appear in tunneling spectroscopy experiments as characteristic zero-bias peaks (ZBPs). Theoretical predictions of ZBPs have been observed experimentally in semiconductor nanowires.

• However, these experimental results cannot serve as definitive evidence to prove the existence of MFs in condensed matter systems. It is also a major challenge in these experiments to uniquely distinguish Majoranas from conventional fermionic subgap states. The zero-bias conductance peaks can also appear due to other mechanisms, such as the zero-bias anomaly due to Kondo resonance and disorder or band bending in the nanowire.

• Andreev bound states in a magnetic field can also exhibit a zero-energy crossing as a function of exchange interaction or Zeeman energy, giving rise to similar conductance features. Most experimental evidence for Majorana bound states relies on measurements of tunneling conductance, and the observation of Majorana signatures based on electrical methods remains a subject of debate. Identifying MFs only through tunnel spectroscopy is somewhat problematic.

• Therefore, alternative setups or proposals for detecting MFs are necessary. An all-optical scheme to detect MFs is proposed, benefiting from recent advances in nanotechnology and nanofabrication. Nanostructures such as quantum dots (QDs) and nanomechanical resonators (NRS) have made significant progress in modern nanoscience and nanotechnology. QDs, as simple stationary atoms with well-defined optical properties, lay the foundation for numerous possible applications.

• The interaction between MFs in iron chains and QDs in hybrid QD-NR systems is mainly due to dipole-dipole interaction, and the distance between the two systems can be adjusted by several tens of nanometers. The QD is considered as a two-level system rather than a single resonant level with spin-s

<summary>
• The unification scheme of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) explains the difference between type 1 and type 2 AGN as being due to angle-dependent circumnuclear obscuration of the accretion disk and broad-line region. This obscuring dusty medium, commonly referred to as the "dust torus," is optically and geometrically thick and extends from sub-parsec scales to several tens of parsecs.

• The dust in the torus absorbs incident UV/optical radiation and re-emits the received energy in the infrared. Observations have shown that type 1 AGN show significantly more emission in the near-IR than type 2 AGN for the same given intrinsic luminosity. This is consistent with the picture where the face-on view onto the torus in type 1 AGN exposes the innermost hot dust to the observer.

• The sample used in this study comprises 11 quasars and 8 radio galaxies at z = 0.4, which were selected isotropically and are complete. The average spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of each subsample were calculated to study the intrinsic anisotropy of the IR emission of the dust torus.

• The ratio between type 1 and type 2 AGN in the sample gradually decreases from 20 to 2 at wavelengths 2 to 8 μm. Within the 10 μm silicate feature, the ratio raises slightly, and at longer wavelengths, the mid-IR emission becomes more isotropic. The intrinsic ratio between type 1 and type 2 AGN is 1.4 at 15 μm.

• The observed IR anisotropy is probably reflecting the "intrinsic anisotropy" as caused by the dust torus. The isotropic and complete selection of the sample helps to minimize any biasing effects on the anisotropy. The findings are consistent with upper limits derived from the X-ray/mid-IR correlation of local Seyfert galaxies.

• The overall relatively small degree of anisotropy is consistent with the torus being clumpy rather than smooth. The clumpy torus model reproduces the observed type 1/type 2 ratio reasonably well. The model parameters used in the clumpy torus model fit are reasonable in comparison to fits to local AGN.

• The results suggest that the observed anisotropy is a measure for the intrinsic anisotropy of luminous type 1 and type 2 AGN at z

<summary>
• The goal of the development of the code was to have a simple and efficient tool for the computation of adiabatic oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions for general stellar models. The code offers considerable flexibility in the choice of integration method and the ability to determine all frequencies of a given model. The choice of variables describing the equilibrium model and oscillations was inspired by previous work. The code provides fairly extensive documentation and is based on a minimal set of dimensionless variables.

• The code solves the equations of adiabatic stellar oscillations in terms of the following variables: the perturbation to the gravitational potential, the eulerian perturbation to pressure, and the radial and horizontal components of the displacement vector. The equations are solved on the interval from the center of the star to the surface, with boundary conditions obtained from a series expansion at the center and a simple condition of vanishing lagrangian pressure perturbation at the surface. The code also has the option of considering truncated models. The numerical problem can be formulated as that of solving a system of differential equations with boundary conditions.

• The code uses two techniques to improve the precision of the computed frequencies: a variational principle and Richardson extrapolation. The variational principle implies that any error in the eigenfunction induces an error in the frequency that is second-order in the error. Richardson extrapolation uses the fact that the truncation errors in the eigenfrequency and eigenfunction scale as the square of the mesh spacing. The code also has the option to output the eigenfunctions and the displacement eigenfunctions in a form indicating the region where the mode predominantly resides.

• The code calculates the normalized inertia of a mode, which is a powerful measure of the characteristics of a mode. The code also has the option to compute kernels for first-order rotational splitting in the special case where the angular velocity depends only on the radial distance from the center. Several revisions of the code have been implemented, including the installation of a fourth-order integration scheme and the implementation of a new classification scheme for dipolar modes of low order in centrally condensed models. The code is being supported by the Danish Natural Science Research Council and the European Helio- and Asteroseismology Network (HELAS).</summary>

<summary>
• Inferring macroscopic properties of physical systems from their microscopic description is an ongoing work in many disciplines of physics, and phase transitions often involve a symmetry breaking process. The theory of such phase transitions was formulated by Landau as a phenomenological model and later devised from microscopic principles using the renormalization group. One can identify phases by knowledge of an order parameter which is zero in the disordered phase and nonzero in the ordered phase.

• Machine learning techniques, particularly unsupervised learning algorithms, can be employed to identify parameters capable of describing phase transitions. Variational autoencoders, a modern version of autoencoders, impose additional constraints on the encoded representations and can learn a latent variable model for the input data. They have shown promising results in encoding and reconstructing data in the field of computer vision.

• The authors use unsupervised learning to determine phase transitions without any information about the microscopic theory or the order parameter, and they transition from principal component analysis to variational autoencoders. The algorithms are able to find a low-dimensional latent representation of the physical system which coincides with the correct order parameter. The decoder network reconstructs the encoded configuration from its latent representation.

• The authors apply the variational autoencoder to the Ising model and the XY model, and they find that the reconstruction loss can be used as a universal parameter to identify phase transitions. The latent parameter and the reconstruction loss can serve as indicators of a phase transition, and the authors establish the reconstruction loss as a new universal indicator for phase transitions. The variational autoencoder can handle nonlinear features in the data and scale very well to huge datasets.</summary>

<summary>
• The paper discusses the concept of "partial" quantum cloning, where only one component of a two-partite pure state is cloned, and its application in eavesdropping of quantum channels.
• The authors propose a quantum cloning machine (QCM) that can clone mixed qubit states by using the "purification" of the mixed state and then applying the "partial" cloning machine, and demonstrate its effectiveness through numerical simulations.</summary>

<summary>
• Aql X-1, a soft X-ray transient, was observed to undergo a transition from an accretion-powered outburst to a propeller regime and eventually to a radio pulsar regime as it approached quiescence, providing a possible link between low-mass X-ray binaries and recycled millisecond pulsars.
• The observed spectral and luminosity changes during the outburst decay of Aql X-1 are consistent with a neutron star magnetic field in the range of 10^8-10^9 G, and the quiescent X-ray luminosity can be explained by a radio pulsar enshrouded by matter outflowing from the companion star.</summary>

<summary>
• The supernova SN 2006jc was discovered on October 9, 2006, and its observations showed a bright blue continuum in early epochs, a rapid decline of the optical light curve, and a brightening of the infrared light curve.
• The progenitor of SN 2006jc is thought to be a Wolf-Rayet star with a thick carbon-rich envelope and circumstellar matter, which is consistent with the formation of amorphous carbon grains in the supernova ejecta and circumstellar matter.
• The bolometric light curve of SN 2006jc can be explained by a hypernova-like supernova explosion model with a large explosion energy and a small ejected mass, which is powered by the radioactive decay of 56Ni.
• The circumstellar matter interaction and X-ray light curve of SN 2006jc can be reproduced by a model with a flat density profile in the inner circumstellar matter, indicating a drastic change of the mass-loss rate and/or wind velocity before the explosion.</summary>

<summary>
* The micro-quasar GRS 1915+105 is a black hole binary known for its extreme variability, and recently, IGR J170913-624 has been found to exhibit similar variability patterns, making it a unique object of study.
* The apparent faintness of IGR J170913-624 is difficult to explain, even considering the smallest possible mass and largest possible distance, leading to an investigation of the possible reasons for this faintness.
* Simultaneous fitting of spectra at different phases of the 'heartbeat' oscillations in IGR J170913-624 suggests that the system parameters, such as mass, distance, and inclination, cannot change over the phase of the oscillations.
* The results of the analysis indicate that the most likely difference between GRS 1915+105 and IGR J170913-624 is in the spins of the respective black holes, with IGR J170913-624 having a very low spin, possibly even retrograde.
* The findings suggest that the black hole spin may not play a significant role in generating the observed extreme variability, which is instead mainly caused by a high accretion rate.</summary>

<summary>
• The article discusses the rank stratification of the exceptional arrangement of a weakly toric module, which is a refinement of its stratification by the rank of the hypergeometric system. The authors introduce the concept of ranking slabs, which are strata in the coarsest stratification of the exceptional arrangement that respect certain arrangements. They show that the rank jump of the hypergeometric system is constant on each ranking slab.

• The authors also introduce the concept of ranking toric modules, which are constructed via their degree sets, and show that these modules can be used to compute the rank jump of the hypergeometric system. They define simple ranking toric modules, which are maximal Cohen-Macaulay toric modules, and show that their euler koszul homology modules have easily computable ranks. The authors also provide a formula for the rank jump of the hypergeometric system in terms of the combinatorics of the ranking lattices.</summary>

<summary>
* A triangular triple quantum dot (tqd) system is proposed as a qubit, where the qubit states are encoded in the doublet subspace and controlled by the applied gate potentials that break the triangular symmetry. The calculations are performed in the Heisenberg model, where the exchange couplings are modified by the orientation of the electric field with respect to the triangular axes.
* A new method for read-out of the qubit state is proposed by the current measurement in the doublet blockade regime, and the analysis of the qubit dynamics in the presence of decoherence processes caused by interaction with the electrodes is performed. The doublet blockade effect is related with an asymmetry of tunnel rates between the doublet states and the electrodes, and for some specific symmetry of tqd, one of the doublet states is a dark one and the electron transport is blocked.
* The time-dependent electron transport in the doublet blockade regime is studied, and the dynamics of the qubit, the coherent oscillations, and the relaxation processes due to the presence of the electrodes are investigated. The role of the leakage processes from the doublet to two-electron states is also studied, and the driven case where the mixing parameter between the doublet state is time-dependent is considered, showing strong Rabi oscillations in the resonance condition.</summary>

<summary>
• The article analyzes a two-genotype system with nonlinear fitness functions and asymmetric mutation probabilities, using the Moran process as a model to study the interplay of selection, mutation, and genetic drift in evolutionary dynamics.
• The authors derive the Fokker-Planck equation describing the dynamics of the system and find that nonlinear frequency-dependent selection and asymmetric mutation rates can induce complex evolutionary dynamics, including multiple stable points and stochastic switching between them.
• The study suggests that nonlinear fitness may be the cause of multiple stable states observed in experimental data and provides a theoretical framework for understanding the effects of nonlinear interactions in complex environments.</summary>

<summary>
• The proposed scheme implements a three-qubit Grover's algorithm using four-level superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs) coupled to a single-mode superconducting resonator. The algorithm involves three-qubit phase gates and single-qubit gates, and the implementation time is significantly faster due to the use of resonant and off-resonant interactions. The scheme does not require adjustment of level spacing during the operation or slowly changing Rabi frequencies.

• The effects of imperfections in the system, including the decay of the cavity field and the relevant level, are considered. The results show that the marked state can be searched with high fidelity even in the presence of imperfections in the system. The influence of unwanted off-resonant interaction during the gate implementation is also incorporated.

• The estimated time for the implementation of the three-qubit Grover algorithm performing two iterations is approximately 26 ns. The scheme is compared to a recent study by Yang et al., which proposed a physical implementation of three-qubit Grover's algorithm in cavity quantum electrodynamics (QED) using flying qubits. The proposed scheme has the advantage of using stationary qubits and generating single microwave photons in a high-Q cavity using SQUIDs.</summary>

<summary>
• The nature of dark matter remains one of the outstanding questions of modern astrophysics, with the cold dark matter cosmological model suggesting a major component of dark matter is in the form of an elementary particle. However, the inventory of baryons observed locally falls short of the total inferred from observations of the cosmic microwave background fluctuations. This leaves open the possibility that there may be a significant baryonic component of dark matter.

• Many papers have dealt with the possibility that cold, self-gravitating molecular clouds constitute a major component of dark matter. These clouds would have dense gas of high column-density, in contrast to the diffuse gas in the interstellar medium. The gamma-ray emission resulting from cosmic-ray interactions within the clouds is a fundamental prediction of models featuring dense gas clouds.

• The gamma-ray spectra arising from cosmic-ray interactions with gas clouds of various column-densities have been calculated using a Monte Carlo event simulator, GEANT4. The calculations reproduce the analytic result in the low column-density limit but exhibit significant differences for clouds of column-density where the emissivity declines substantially for photon energies. The low emissivity of dense gas means that the baryonic content of the galaxy's dark halo is not so tightly constrained by the gamma-ray data as had previously been thought.

• The existing gamma-ray data, taken in isolation, do not exclude purely baryonic models for the galactic dark halo. For high column densities, the emissivity falls, and the gamma-ray data on the inner galactic disk thus indicate that all of the galaxy's dark halo could be made of dense clouds of column-density. The constraint is based on the mean spectrum of the inner galactic disk, in contrast to those given by previous authors who employed limits based on the angular structure of the observed gamma-ray intensity.

• The gamma-ray constraints on high column density gas clouds in the dark halo are much weaker than those on low column density gas because the emissivity of the latter is much greater. The constraints discussed make reference only to the low-energy gamma-ray data, but the observed intensity of the inner galactic disk at high photon energies is substantially greater than expected. Much effort has been expended on explaining this discrepancy, but none of the models offer a satisfactory explanation of the observed mean gamma-ray spectrum of the galactic disk.

• The galactic diffuse emission model used contains contributions from cosmic-ray interactions with diffuse atomic hydrogen, ionized and molecular components of the interstellar medium, inverse Compton emission, and an isotropic extragalactic background flux.

<summary>
• The extinction curve describes how extinction changes with wavelength and is necessary to understand the physical properties of dust grains. The curve is different in diffuse and dense interstellar media, and its characteristics depend on the presence of dust grains. The knowledge of the extinction curve is necessary to deredden magnitudes and colors of astronomical objects.

• Cardelli, Clayton, and Mathis (CCM) derived a mean extinction law that depends on only one parameter, R(V), which characterizes the dust properties in the region that produces the extinction. The CCM law is a powerful tool that allows one to determine the extinction in some spectral region based on the extinction in a different spectral region. The R(V) parameter ranges from about 2.0 to about 5.5, with a typical value of 3.1, when one goes from diffuse to dense interstellar medium.

• The authors extend the method used by GS to compute R(V) values for a sample of stars with UV extinction data using the linear relation. They use a weighted χ2 minimization to compute the R(V) values, taking into account the observational errors. The authors also compute the maximum errors and the errors in quadrature for R(V) and A(V) taking into account mismatch errors.

• The authors use the data taken from the CCM catalog of ultraviolet color excesses for stars of spectral types B7 and earlier. They exclude some lines of sight using the same method of selection as GS and also exclude those stars that do not have spectral type classification. The sample contains 782 lines of sight, and the authors compute the R(V) and A(V) values for each line of sight.

• The authors present the sky distribution of R(V) values and show their behavior as a function of galactic coordinates. They also compare their results with those obtained using the Wegner's (2002) calibration of E(B-V) and find a systematic difference in R(V) values. The authors emphasize the importance of considering systematic errors in extinction curve determination.

• The authors conclude that their determination of R(V) values with their errors is made using the GS method improved through the consistent treatment of observational errors. They also emphasize the importance of extending their study into wavelength regions beyond ultraviolet to provide a check on the universality of the CCM law in various parts of the spectrum.</summary>

<summary>
* Colloidal suspensions have the potential to develop novel materials through self-assembly, with colloidal crystals being of particular interest due to their optical properties and ability to generate iridescent colors. These crystals can be used to produce photonic crystals, lasers, and display devices. Recent advances have demonstrated tunable colors through control of lattice spacing with an external field. The well-defined thermodynamic temperature of colloidal dispersions allows them to be viewed as mesoscopic "model atoms".

* The ability to tune colloid-colloid interactions has led to the observation of various structures, including exotic crystal structures not observed in atomic and molecular systems. External control of these interactions allows for direct observation of phase transitions. Direct microscopic observation at the single-particle level provides an unprecedented level of detail, enabling the study of long-standing problems in condensed matter, such as freezing. The introduction of a rotating AC field opens up more possibilities for structure formation.

* A rotating AC field induces dipolar interactions between colloidal particles, leading to anisotropic interparticle potentials and exotic crystal structures. The dipolar interactions result in an attraction in the plane of rotation and repulsions above and below. Studies with a rotating magnetic field on granular matter have produced disc-like patterns consistent with expectations. Unlike granular matter, colloidal dispersions exhibit Brownian motion, allowing for the formation of thermodynamic equilibrium structures, such as crystals.

* The interparticle dipolar interactions in the plane of the electric field can be treated as a circularly symmetric attraction due to the time-averaging effect of a rapidly rotating field. The asymmetry between the colloids and smaller molecular and ionic species must be addressed, and coarse-graining schemes have been developed to integrate out the smaller components. This generates a one-component picture, where only the effective colloid-colloid interactions are considered, reducing the complexity of the description.

* A simple numerical treatment is used to predict the lattice spacing in the quasi-2D crystal from the electric field strength. A model system of charged colloids in a rotating electric field is considered, and the knowledge of electrostatic repulsions and dipolar attractions is used to present a direct, quantitative comparison of a tunable interaction and a material property of the crystalline "rafts" formed. Experimental measurements of the crystal lattice constant are combined with Monte-Carlo simulations, using pairwise interactions and a screened Coulomb repulsion plus dipolar attraction.

* The simulations use a free parameter, the Debye screening length, which is taken as a fitting

<summary>
* The many-body effects on XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) spectra in metals were a topic of interest in the 1970s, with a focus on the effects of core holes on the conduction-band electrons. The core-hole potential can lead to a shift of the peak to higher kinetic energy or lower binding energy of the core level.
* The excitation process can be considered adiabatic or sudden, with the latter resulting in shake-up effects and the creation of plasmons or electron-hole pairs. The shake-up effects can be described using the sudden approximation and the creation of bosons.
* The boson propagator can be replaced by the dynamical structure factor, which describes the excitation spectrum of the electrons. The coupling constant between the core hole and the boson excitation can be used to calculate the XPS spectrum.
* The XPS spectrum can be written as a function of the energy, with the energy shift of the adiabatic peak and the shake-up structure of the spectra. The spectrum can be broadened by introducing a Lorentzian and Gaussian broadening.
* The dielectric function of graphene can be used to calculate the XPS spectrum, with the dielectric function depending on the doping concentration. The XPS spectrum of pristine graphene shows a peak tailing, characteristic of metallic systems.
* The peak shape changes with doping concentration, with important doping effects showing up at concentrations exceeding 10^12 cm^-2. The XPS spectrum can be used to estimate the degree of doping of a sample.
* The theoretical results have been compared to experimental spectra from two experimental groups, with good agreement between theory and experiment. The XPS spectrum can be used to study the electronic structure of graphene and other 2D systems.</summary>

<summary>
• The symbiotic system Z Andromedae (Z And) consists of a cool giant and a hot compact component, with a temperature of 150,000 K. The system has experienced many periods of activity, including nonuniform eruptions of classical outbursts. The 1984-1986 event is of particular interest, with two maxima in the visual magnitude profile.

• The main characteristics of the 1984-1986 event are the two maxima in the visual magnitude profile, leading to an ambiguous interpretation of the outburst as a double or a disturbed single one. A drop in the white dwarf (WD) radiation flux could provoke the observed trend of the light curve in 1986. A shell of material was ejected during each of the two outbursts at 1984 and 1986.

• The stellar wind of the cool giant has a velocity of 25 km/s, and varying the wind velocity from 25 to 30 km/s changes the accretion regime from disk to wind accretion. This is accompanied by a jump in the accretion rate, increasing the hydrogen burning rate. An optical thick wind forms from the WD, revealed by observations of UV and optical spectra during the 2000-2002 outburst.

• The shocks derived from WD and red giant (RG) wind collision yield an increase in the luminosity of the system. The collision of the winds leads to two shock fronts between the stars, with the strong one propagating in reverse towards the WD. A shock front expands out of the system throughout the circumbinary medium.

• The line spectra are calculated in the frame of the wind collision model, adopting the code SUMA, which accounts consistently for shocks and photoionization. The input parameters include the shock velocity, preshock density, preshock magnetic field, color temperature of the hot star, and ionization parameter. The geometrical thickness of the emitting nebula, dust-to-gas ratio, and abundances of elements are also accounted for.

• The observations at different epochs of the continuum spectral energy distribution (SED) are reproduced by models constrained by the fit of the line ratios. The adjustment factors determine the distance of the nebulae downstream of shock fronts from the system center, providing a detailed picture of the Z And components. The fit of calculated to observed data is good enough to confirm a strong self-absorption of free-free radiation from the nebulae.

• The 1984-1986 outburst of

<summary>
• Single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) networks are emerging as novel materials for various applications, particularly as electronic materials. The accurate determination of their fundamental electrical properties is crucial. SWCNT networks can be viewed as a two-dimensional network of conducting one-dimensional rods, which are either metallic or semiconducting. The junction resistance between nanotubes is much larger than the nanotube resistance itself, leading to a system with randomly distributed barriers for electrical transport.

• The frequency-dependent and electric-field-dependent conductivity of individual SWCNTs and some types of SWCNT networks have been investigated. However, there is a lack of investigation for systematic variation of network densities, and no correlation study between the onset frequency and the length scale determined from nonlinear transport. The frequency- and electric-field-dependent conductivity investigation of different network densities is essential for understanding the electrical transport properties of SWCNT networks. This knowledge is also important for the applications of these networks.

• In this paper, the authors investigated the frequency- and electric-field-dependent conductivity for SWCNT networks with systematically varying densities. They found that the onset frequency extracted from the frequency dependence measurement increases with the film thickness, while the length scale extracted from the electric field dependent measurement decreases at the same time. The authors developed an empirical relation between the two transport measurement methods. The SWCNT networks on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate were prepared by the spraying method.

• The network density was controlled by the solution concentration and the spraying time. The nanotubes formed bundles with a size of 4-7 nm and a length of 2-4 μm. The thicknesses of the films range from submonolayer to 200 nm, corresponding to room temperature sheet conductance ranging from 10^(-4) to 10^3 S/square. The Corbino reflectometry setup was used to investigate the conductivity of the SWCNT networks. The measurement procedures are similar to the authors' previous work.

• The data of conductance vs. frequency are shown in Fig. 1(a). The films decrease in thickness from sample 1 (200 nm) to sample 5 (sub-monolayer). For all the films, the real parts of the conductance keep their DC value up to a characteristic frequency and start to increase at higher frequency. This kind of behavior has been widely observed for disordered systems. The extended pair approximation model can be used to describe the real part of the AC conductance.

• The obtained frequency-dependent conductance fits

<summary>
* The phase-field method has become a popular choice for simulating microstructure formation during solidification due to its algorithmic simplicity and ability to avoid tracking moving solid-liquid interfaces or grain boundaries.
* The method's foundations and application to solidification have been reviewed in several recent articles, but some fundamental questions remain open, including the thin-interface limit of two-sided phase-field models and the inclusion of microscopic fluctuations.
* The thin-interface limit is a crucial aspect of the phase-field method, as it allows for the analysis of the equations under the assumption that the interface thickness is much smaller than any other physical length scale present in the problem.
* The introduction of an antitrapping current has been proposed as a solution to eliminate the temperature jump at the interface, but this approach is not valid in the limit of zero interface velocity.
* The phase-field method also struggles to accurately model the evolution of polycrystals, particularly in the context of coherent crystalline matter, where the connectivity of the crystal structure must be taken into account.
* The orientation-field method, which uses a single phase field, an orientation field, and the temperature field, has been proposed as an alternative approach, but its evolution equation for the angle field is not consistent with the coherent crystalline structure of matter.
* The inclusion of fluctuations in the phase-field equations is also a topic of ongoing research, with the standard approach being to include fluctuations as Langevin terms in the field equations, but this approach has been shown to be insufficient for quantitative simulations of nucleation processes.
* The renormalization of the phase-field model by fluctuations is a well-known fact in statistical field theory, but its implications for phase-field modeling are not yet fully appreciated, and further research is needed to understand the effects of fluctuations on the phase-field variables.
* The development of more efficient and robust models for materials modeling will likely benefit from the pursuit and confrontation of both the physical and mathematical aspects of the phase-field method.</summary>

<summary>
• The fundamental atmospheric and physical parameters of stars are crucial for understanding the chemical and dynamical properties of the Milky Way and other galaxies. These parameters can be determined through spectroscopic methods, which are more accurate than photometric calibrations. The spectroscopic parameters can then be used to fit individual stars to theoretical isochrones or evolutionary tracks to determine the stellar mass, age, and distance of a star.

• The spectroscopic atmospheric parameters can be estimated from a spectrum in a consistent and efficient way, avoiding the problem of reddening inherent in photometry. A common method for deriving the spectroscopic atmospheric parameters is to use the information from Fe and Fe absorption lines under the assumption of hydrostatic equilibrium and local thermodynamic equilibrium. However, systematic biases are present within such analyses due to the breakdown of the assumption of LTE.

• The authors developed a new method to determine the fundamental parameters of FGK stars, which utilizes the sample of stars selected from the RAVE survey. They used three different methods to compute the effective temperature, including the Balmer line method, which is the most reliable among the different methods presently available. The authors also developed the necessary tools to apply on-the-fly NLTE corrections to Fe lines.

• The authors verified their method using a sample of standard stars with interferometric estimates of effective temperature and/or Hipparcos parallaxes. They then performed a comprehensive comparison to standard 1D, LTE techniques for the spectral analysis of stars, finding significant systematic biases. The NLTE effects in iron are most prominent in low-metallicity stars.

• The authors found that the NLTE-opt stellar parameters lead to far less stars that lie on or above the tip of the red giant branch, and more stars occupy the middle or lower portion of the RGB. The NLTE-opt parameters also lead to stars at the turn-off and subgiant branch being more consistent with stellar evolution calculations. The implications of the very large differences between the NLTE-opt and LTE-FE estimates of atmospheric parameters extend beyond that of just the characterization of stars by their surface parameters and abundance analyses.

• The authors concluded that reliable effective temperatures are necessary to avoid substantial biases in a spectroscopic determination of surface gravity and metallicity. They also found that NLTE effects on ionization balance are necessary to eliminate the discrepancy between Fe and Fe lines, an effect that is present, regardless of the adopted effective temperature. The authors' new method provides robust estimates of atmospheric parameters, which can be used to study the chemical and dynamical properties of the Milky Way.

<summary>
* The periodic Anderson lattice model is a canonical model for understanding heavy fermion metals, kondo insulators, intermediate valence, and related materials. The local moment approach within a dynamical mean-field theory framework is used to investigate optical conductivities, d.c. transport, and single-particle dynamics of the paramagnetic phase. The strongly correlated kondo lattice regime is characterized by a single, exponentially small coherence scale, in terms of which physical properties scale universally. This regime is of primary interest, and the theory handles all relevant energy and temperature scales.

* The theory captures the crossover from low-temperature lattice-coherent behavior to high-temperature effective single-impurity scaling physics, and the scaling behavior is independent of the interaction strength and hybridization matrix element. The optical conductivity exhibits a thermal evolution of the optical drude peak, which broadens and eventually merges into an optical pseudogap. The low-energy scale intrinsic to heavy fermion systems is distinct from the direct gap, and optics on the direct gap scale do not lie in the scaling regime. The theory also captures the thermal erosion of the direct gap, which occurs on temperature scales much higher than the coherence scale.

* The local moment approach is a non-perturbative theory that handles strong interactions and respects the asymptotic dictates of fermi liquid behavior. The theory is compared to experiment in the following paper, where direct comparison of theory and experiment is made for three heavy fermion materials and a classic intermediate valence compound. The theory is found to capture the experimental results well, and the comparison provides valuable insights into the physics of heavy fermion systems. The theory also provides a framework for understanding the behavior of heavy fermion systems in different regimes, from weak to strong coupling. The results of the theory are also compared to other approaches, such as the renormalized band picture, and are found to provide a more accurate description of the physics. The theory is also found to be consistent with the luttinger integral theorem, which provides a constraint on the behavior of fermi liquids.</summary>

<summary>
• The effects of weak gravitational lensing by large-scale structure have been detected in various samples of high-redshift quasars, intermediate-redshift galaxies, and BATSE GRBs. Weak lensing manifests itself as angular correlations between these sources and foreground inhomogeneously distributed mass. In principle, there is another way of detecting weak lensing, which uses fluxes of standard candles.

• The best example of a cosmological standard candle is supernovae type Ia (SNe Ia), which have been extensively observed to determine the global geometry of the universe. Nuisance effects like evolution, variations in individual SNe, and gray dust extinction have been studied theoretically and observationally. Weak lensing, another nuisance effect, has been addressed theoretically and found to be unimportant given the current uncertainties.

• The main goal of this work is to determine if the observed fluxes of cosmologically distant SNe Ia have suffered significantly from lensing-induced amplifications. The largest homogeneous compilation of SNe Ia has been recently published, containing 74 SNe at redshifts up to 1. The authors use four different light curve fitting methods to estimate distances to SNe.

• The analysis presented yields values of the global cosmological parameters, assuming a flat model. The authors use these values in all the analysis of the present paper. As tracers of foreground mass density, they use APM galaxies, which provide near-full coverage of the sky in the northern and southern hemispheres.

• The median redshift of the 55 SNe is 0.47. Since most of the SNe have rather low redshifts, care must be taken to ensure that galaxies are foreground to the SNe. The optimal lens redshift will depend on the source redshift much more compared to a typical case where sources are at high redshift.

• The authors explore the dependence of the results on the choice of parameters, such as the radius of the circle around SNe and the galaxy magnitude limit. They conclude that significant anti-correlation between SNe magnitudes and foreground galaxy number density occurs for galaxies with median redshifts between 0.1 and 0.3.

• The authors adopt the weak lensing interpretation of the observed correlation and proceed to model the effect using a simple lensing model. They find that the slope of the correlation depends on the amount and distribution of matter, but does not depend on the specifics of the biasing scheme.

• The authors conclude that weak lensing of standard candles

<summary>
* The realization of a gate-induced band-gap in Bernal stacked bi-layer graphene has brought the possibility of a graphene-based transistor closer to reality, but the sub-gap conductance measured in experiments has introduced a new puzzle. The authors propose that the topological gapless channel of transport along the recently imaged AB-BA tilt boundary network solves this puzzle.
* The predicted topological edge state holds the promise of the first realization of a topological surface(edge) state hosted by a structural topological defect.
