<summary>
• The zero-range potential (ZRP) approach has been developed to widen the limits of traditional treatments, allowing for the exact solution of scattering problems.
• The ZRP can be represented as a boundary condition on the matrix wavefunction or as a pseudopotential, and can be used to construct exactly solvable potentials using the Darboux transformation (DT).
• The DT technique can be used to correct the ZRP model, and can be applied to multi-center scattering problems to construct dressed potentials with arbitrarily disposed discrete spectrum levels.
• The dressed potential can be used to study electron scattering by polyatomic molecules, and can be improved by taking into account higher partial waves.
• The ZRP model can be used to study slow electron scattering by molecules, but is not expected to be correct for low impact energies where polarization effects are important.
• The integral cross sections (ICS) can be corrected by dressing the ZRP, and the DT can be used to add or remove poles of the S-matrix.
• The DT can be used to induce long-range forces depending on angular momentum, leading to singularity in the cross section at zero energy.
• The ZRP approach has been applied to study electron scattering by various structures, including regular tetrahedra and polyatomic molecules, and has been shown to be a useful tool for studying scattering problems.</summary>

<summary>
• The order parameter in high-temperature superconductors (HTS) has been found to have mainly a d-wave pairing symmetry. Thermal transport measurements have shown the predominance of this symmetry for the gap function. The longitudinal thermal conductivity shows a fourfold oscillation when a magnetic field is rotated parallel to the CuO planes, which can be explained by Andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices and Doppler shift in the energy spectrum of the quasiparticles. This oscillation has been resolved up to 20 K, above which no direct evidence for this type of symmetry has been published.

• The variation of the thermal conductivity as a function of angle between the heat current and the magnetic field applied parallel to the CuO planes depends mainly on the heat transport by quasiparticles, their interaction with the supercurrents, and the symmetry of the order parameter. An angular pattern showing properties of the order parameter symmetry can only be achieved when the temperature is low enough so that the quasiparticle momentum is close to the nodal directions of the gap. The thermal activation of quasiparticles with increasing temperature can explain the experimental results in the whole temperature range. The change of symmetry of the thermal conductivity as a function of temperature can also be explained by this model.

• The experimental results have been compared with a model involving Andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices and the two-dimensional BRT expression for the thermal conductivity, assuming a d-wave pairing symmetry. The model reproduces remarkably well the symmetry of the curves in the whole measured temperature range. The factor used to fit the experimental oscillation amplitude is related to the inelastic scattering rate, which was not taken explicitly into account in the previous calculations. An approximation can be carried out to get roughly the temperature dependence of the total scattering rate.

• The overall results agree with the d-wave pairing symmetry of the order parameter, suggesting that the mechanisms that influence the behavior of the quasiparticles below Tc and above 20 K are well described by the Fermi liquid theory at nearly optimal doping. The small differences found in the angle patterns between the twinned and untwinned samples can be explained in terms of the different impurity concentration as well as oxygen deficiency. The anisotropy of the d-wave gap proposed for BSCCO does not seem to occur in YBCO since the nodes are observed at both field orientations. The temperature dependence of the inelastic scattering rate is similar to that obtained for the longitudinal

<summary>
• Anomaly-mediated supersymmetry breaking (AMSB) models have attractive properties, including calculable soft supersymmetry breaking terms and real, flavor-invariant soft terms. However, they suffer from the problem of negative slepton mass-squared parameters, leading to tachyonic states. The original solution to this problem is to add a universal mass to the scalars, rendering them positive. This leads to the parameter space of the minimal AMSB model (MAMSB) being given by m_0, m_3/2, tan β, and sign(μ).

• An alternative setup for AMSB is hypercharged anomaly-mediation (HCAMSb), which uses a similar setup as AMSB but with SUSY breaking localized at the bottom of a strongly warped hidden region. This suppresses contributions from tree-level gravity mediation, and anomaly mediation becomes the dominant source of SUSY breaking in the visible sector. The mass of the bino can be the only soft SUSY breaking parameter not determined by anomaly mediation. The HCAMSb model combines the attractive features of AMSB and hypercharge mediation, curing phenomenological shortcomings of each other.

• The HCAMSb model predicts a negative mass-squared for stops and sbottoms, while the pure hypercharge mediation suffers from negative squared masses for sleptons. The combination of hypercharge and anomaly mediation leads to phenomenologically viable spectra for a sizable range of relative contributions. The parameter space of HCAMSb models is given by m_3/2, tan β, sign(μ), and a dimensionless quantity α that governs the size of the hypercharge contribution to soft terms relative to the AMSB contribution.

• The HCAMSb model has distinct features compared to MAMSB, including a severe left-right splitting of scalar masses and a different mass ordering in the neutralino mass matrix. The lightest stau state is expected to be mainly a left-state in HCAMSb, while it is mixed but mainly a right-state in MAMSB. The HCAMSb model also predicts a high multiplicity of b-jets in cascade decays, while MAMSB predicts a lower multiplicity.

• The LHC reach for HCAMSb models is expected to be somewhat lower than for MAMSB models, due to the highly split squark states in HCAMSb. The LHC event characteristics for HCAMSb models suffer similarities and differences with generic MAMSB models, including the presence of multi-jet plus multi-lepton plus missing energy event

<summary>
* The Submillimetre Common-User Bolometer Array (SCUBA) and the Max-Planck Millimetre Bolometer (MAMBO) arrays are used to survey the sky at millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths, detecting dusty objects at extreme redshifts. These surveys have revolutionized our understanding of galaxy formation and evolution, moving away from the optocentric view of the last century. The discovery of "SCUBA galaxies" was a significant finding, implying a large source density at high redshifts. However, early efforts to study these galaxies at optical and infrared wavelengths were met with pessimism due to the lack of plausible optical counterparts.

* Recent progress has been made through radio imaging of submillimeter survey fields, allowing for the detection of roughly half of the submillimeter sources observed. The use of radio data has also enabled the refinement of submillimeter samples, increasing the detection fraction to two-thirds of SMGs at 0.85-mm flux density levels. The bright SMGs have been found to be a diverse population, with some quasar-like, morphologically complex, extremely red, or with signatures of obscured active nuclei and/or superwinds. Spectroscopic redshifts have been difficult to determine, but the median redshift of the sample has been found to be around 2.2.

* The authors have developed a dual-survey extraction technique to combine independent submillimeter and millimeter maps of the Lockman Hole, resulting in a robust sample of 19 SMGs. Of these, 15 are detected securely by deep radio imaging, and 15 spectroscopic redshifts have been determined, with 10 considered secure. The resulting redshift distribution is consistent with that determined for a larger sample by Chapman et al. (2005). The authors conclude that the bright SMG population is readily amenable to study via radio-selected samples, down to a 850-μm flux density limit of 5 mJy.</summary>

<summary>
• The convection-diffusion model is a semi-linear parabolic partial differential equation with various applications in science and engineering. It has been solved numerically using different techniques, including finite element method, lattice Boltzmann method, and finite difference schemes. The paper aims to find a numerical solution of the initial value system of the 2D convection-diffusion equation with both Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions. The solution is approximated using the differential quadrature method (DQM) with new sets of modified cubic B-splines as base functions.

• The DQM is an approximation to derivatives of a function, which is the weighted sum of the functional values at certain nodes. The weighting coefficients of the derivatives depend only on the grids. The paper uses three methods: modified trigonometric cubic B-splines DQM (MTB-DQM), modified exponential cubic B-splines DQM (MEXP-DQM), and modified extended cubic B-splines DQM (MECDQ). These methods transform the convection-diffusion problem into a system of first-order ODEs in time.

• The system of ODEs is solved using the SSP-RK54 scheme, which has a reduced storage space, resulting in less accumulation error. The accuracy and adaptability of the method are illustrated by three test problems of 2D convection-diffusion equations. The numerical solutions are compared with the exact solutions, and the results show that the proposed methods produce more accurate solutions. The order of accuracy of the proposed methods for the convection-diffusion problem with Dirichlet's boundary conditions is cubic, while it is quadratic for the Neumann boundary condition.

• The stability of the method is analyzed using the matrix stability analysis method, and the results show that the proposed methods produce stable solutions for 2D convection-diffusion equations. The eigenvalues of the coefficient matrix are real and negative, confirming the stability of the methods. The paper also presents numerical results for three test problems, which demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of the proposed methods. The results are compared with those obtained by other existing schemes, and the proposed methods are found to be more accurate.

• The paper concludes that the proposed methods, MTB-DQM, MEXP-DQM, and MECDQ, are efficient and accurate for solving the initial value system of 2D convection-diffusion equations with both Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions. The methods are stable and produce more accurate solutions compared

<summary>
* The two-gluon exchange model, which is widely used to describe rapidity gaps in hadronic collisions, has been found to be insufficient due to its violation of partial wave unitarity.
* A unitarized gluon exchange model has been developed, which preserves the successful description of hard dijet events by perturbative QCD and introduces a universal phase that absorbs non-perturbative effects.
* The unitarized model has been compared to Tevatron data, and while it can fit the present data, the variation of the predictions with model parameters highlights the limitations of a perturbative approach to the color singlet exchange probability.
* The model suggests a unified phenomenological description of rapidity gap data via the gap survival probability and the universal phase, which could be further analyzed by experimental collaborations.</summary>

<summary>
* The paper discusses the importance of load forecasting for effective management of power systems and proposes an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) approach to forecast electric energy consumption in the Gaza Strip.
* The ANN model is trained using historical data from 1994 to 2011 and tested using data from 2012 and 2013, with the results showing good accuracy and indicating the relevance of the proposed approach.
* The performance of the forecast model is evaluated using different error criteria, including Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE).
* The study concludes that the proposed ANN model can be used to predict future trends of electric energy consumption in the Gaza Strip, and future works will consider other forecasting techniques.</summary>

<summary>
* The axial anomaly is a fundamental issue in quantum field theory, and its origin can be understood through the dispersive approach, which shows that it is related to the chiral limit and can be interpreted as an infrared effect. The dolgov and zakharov approach to the axial anomaly is based on the dispersion relation method, and it allows for a more direct treatment of the anomaly without using the renormalization procedure. This approach suggests that the axial anomaly is not solely due to ultraviolet divergences, but also has an infrared origin.

* The axial anomaly can be related to polarized radiative decays, such as the radiative pion decay, where the outgoing lepton undergoes an helicity flip. The differential decay rate for this process shows a term independent of the lepton mass, which can be interpreted as a manifestation of the axial anomaly. This term is a consequence of the cancellation of the chiral suppression factor due to the terms coming from the vertices with helicity flip.

* The mass singularities cancellation mechanism for helicity changing processes is controlled by the anomalous breaking of the chiral symmetry, and the axial anomaly implies that the collinear limit gives a finite result, independent of the fermion mass. The extension of these remarks to other gauge theories like QCD is possible, and it could allow for a more systematic and complete treatment of the infrared and collinear singularities. The dolgov and zakharov treatment of the axial anomaly can be extended to processes characterized by a lepton which changes helicity by emitting a photon.</summary>

<summary>
* The paper aims to extend the results of Yetter and generalize classical results of Gerstenhaber and Gerstenhaber and Schack on the infinitesimal deformation theory of associative algebras and poset-indexed diagrams of associative algebras to a deformation theory for arbitrary pasting diagrams of linear categories, linear functors, and natural transformations.
* The authors develop a method to prove that obstructions are all cocycles in a family of pasting diagrams sufficient to imply the result in general, and they also make explicit a point overlooked in previous works about the cochain maps constructed in those theorems.
* The paper also introduces a new technique, called the "polygonal method", which is used to prove that obstructions to the deformation of any given pasting diagram are cocycles, and it is shown that this method can be applied to a wide range of pasting diagrams, including those with multiple compositions and trivially deformed cells.</summary>

<summary>
* The problem of salient object detection has gained significant attention in the computer vision community, with various models proposed to simulate human attention in prioritizing objects for high-level processing. However, existing models have limitations, particularly in handling complex scenes with multiple objects. A new benchmark dataset is needed to address these challenges and provide a more comprehensive evaluation of salient object detection models.

* The authors propose a new dataset, Judd-A, which contains eye movements of 15 observers freely viewing 1003 scenes from various topics. The dataset is designed to be more challenging than existing datasets, with a higher number of objects and more complex scenes. The authors also analyze the relationship between fixations and annotations, finding that observers tend to annotate objects that attract more fixations.

* The authors propose a simple baseline model for salient object detection, which involves computing a saliency map and an over-segmented region map. The model is evaluated on various datasets, including MSRA-5K, Bruce-A, and Judd-A, and is found to perform well compared to state-of-the-art models. The authors also analyze the limitations of existing models and highlight the need for more robust and scalable models that can handle complex scenes.</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to novel calcium phosphate-coated implantable medical devices and processes of making same, which minimize immune response to the implant and have the capability to store and release one or more medicinally active agents into the body in a controlled manner.
• The calcium phosphate coating can be hydroxyapatite, dicalcium phosphate, tricalcium phosphate, or tetracalcium phosphate, and can be deposited on the device as particles having a diameter between about 1 μm and 100 μm and a thickness of between about 1 μm to 10 μm.
• The implantable medical device can be constructed of stainless steel, cobalt alloy, titanium cobalt-chromium or metallic alloy, and the calcium phosphate coating can be porous and retain a drug, with the rate of release of the drug from the pores controlled in an engineered manner.
• A sol-gel process for preparing calcium phosphate coatings comprises hydrolysing a phosphor precursor, adding a calcium salt precursor, depositing the gel on the surface of an implantable medical device, and calcining the calcium phosphate at a suitable elevated temperature and for pre-determined time.
• The invention also relates to a process of coating a soft tissue implantable device with a calcium phosphate coating using biomimetic deposition, calcium phosphate cement deposition, electro-phoretic deposition, or electrochemical deposition processes.
• The calcium phosphate coating can contain and elute a drug, and can be coated with a hydrogel film, with the ratio of calcium to phosphate in the sol-gel precursor engineered to enable various phosphate phases to be obtained.</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to seat base support assemblies, particularly those using sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, or flexible steel bands, and provides a new and improved rail connector for these assemblies.
* The rail connector embodies the features of conventional helical spring connectors while retaining essentially none of the undesirable features, and produces spring torsioning and dynamic uplift at the back rail through kinetic energy stored within itself.
* The invention provides two related forms of rail connector: a first form using a pre-stressed, close-wound coil spring with attachment arms, and a second form using a pre-stressed, cantilever spring configuration.
* The first form of rail connector can be modified to produce alternative spring action modes, including dynamic uplift, resilient expansion-contraction, torsion, and leverage amplification.
* The second form of rail connector uses a cantilever principle to provide dynamic uplift to the spring band at the back rail, and can be used with sinuous spring bands having leverage-amplified torsioning incorporated therein.
* The invention provides seat spring-enhancing connectors that combine the four essential seat-force-generators, producing the four most desired seat-performance characteristics: initial-drop, deep-drop, softness, and resilient uplift proportionate to load.</summary>

<summary>
• The present disclosure is directed to an anvil assembly for use with a surgical stapling device, specifically a circular surgical stapling device, including a stabilizing collet positioned to prevent damage to the anvil assembly.
• The anvil assembly includes an anvil shaft defining a first longitudinal bore and an anvil head assembly, with the anvil shaft having a proximal portion including a plurality of flexible legs that define the first longitudinal bore.
• A stabilizing collet defines a second longitudinal bore and is supported within the first longitudinal bore, positioned to prevent damage to the plurality of flexible legs and minimize the likelihood of damage to the anvil shaft.
• The collet is substantially rigid and is secured within the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft by a plurality of cantilevered fingers, each having a protrusion configured to secure the collet within the first longitudinal bore.
• The anvil assembly is designed to facilitate reliable attachment of the anvil assembly to a stapling device, reducing the risk of damage to the anvil shaft during attachment and ensuring proper coupling of the anvil assembly to the stapling device.
</summary>

<summary>
• The paper discusses the Heegaard Floer theory, a decorated topological quantum field theory (TQFT) in 3 dimensions, and its application to detecting exotic smooth structures on 4-manifolds with boundary. The authors provide a combinatorial procedure for calculating the ranks of the maps induced by 2-handle additions in a cobordism, which is a key step in understanding the TQFT. They also discuss the construction of a nice triple Heegaard diagram for a cobordism, which is a crucial ingredient in the combinatorial description of the TQFT. The authors' approach involves finessing the diagram for the link inside the 3-manifold and then modifying the diagram to make it nice.

• The paper also discusses the extension of the authors' arguments to a cobordism consisting of the addition of several 2-handles, and the application of the Heegaard Floer maps induced by 1- and 3-handle additions. The authors review the definition of the Heegaard Floer maps induced by 1- and 3-handle additions and discuss the properties of these maps. They also discuss the action of the group H^1(Y;Z) on the Heegaard Floer invariants and the extension of the cobordism maps to maps between the Heegaard Floer invariants with twisted coefficients. The authors' work provides a new perspective on the Heegaard Floer theory and its application to the study of 4-manifolds.</summary>

<summary>
• Low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs) are compact binaries consisting of a compact object and a low-mass star, with the secondary transferring mass via Roche-lobe overflow, forming an accretion disk around the compact object. LMXBs can be divided into two groups: Z-sources and atoll sources, with Z-sources being the brightest and having mass accretion rates that reach the Eddington limit. LMCX-2 is a persistent LMXB that shows the properties of a Z-source and is thought to be a neutron star system with an accretion rate around the Eddington limit.

• LMCX-2 is one of the most X-ray luminous LMXBs known, but due to its extra-galactic nature, its X-ray flux is rather low. Its optical counterpart was identified as a blue star, but little is known about the system parameters of LMCX-2. The estimates for the orbital period range from 6.4 hours to 12 days, and no periodic variability was detected in 6 years of MACHO data.

• A new technique was developed to detect a signature of the donor star in persistent LMXBs using phase-resolved spectroscopy. This technique was applied to LMCX-2, and a periodic signal was detected in the spectroscopic dataset, which was identified as the orbital period. The Bowen region shows the presence of narrow emission lines that are identified as coming from the irradiated side of the companion.

• The spectroscopic data were obtained using the FORS2 spectrograph attached to the VLT Unit 4 (Yepun telescope) at Paranal Observatory. The data were reduced and analyzed using optimal extraction techniques to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio. The radial velocity curve of the HeII emission line shows a periodic variability that is interpreted as the orbital period.

• Doppler tomography was used to probe the structure of the accretion disk, and the results show a ring-like structure with some minor differences between the two nights. The Bowen doppler map is dominated by a bright emission feature that is interpreted as arising on the surface of the donor star. The velocity of the bright spot is much higher than the disk velocities in the HeII doppler map.

• The detection of narrow emission lines in the Bowen region suggests that they arise on the irradiated surface of the donor star. The width of these emission lines suggests that they come from a very compact region in the system, and apart

<summary>
• The aim of physics is not only to calculate observable phenomena but also to understand the underlying physical picture, which often requires selecting essential degrees of freedom. In the case of crystals, the fundamental degrees of freedom are ions, electrons, and the electromagnetic field, but to understand electric conductivity and heat capacity, it is more effective to work with "heavy electrons" and phonons.

• A similar situation occurs in QCD, where the fundamental degrees of freedom are current quarks and gluon fields, but to understand the nucleon mass and low-energy properties, it is more effective to consider the spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry. This breaking gives rise to constituent quarks and Goldstone bosons, which interact through a chiral boson exchange interaction.

• The chiral boson exchange interaction is responsible for the hyperfine splittings in baryon spectroscopy and produces a short-range repulsion in the NN system. This repulsion is related to the spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry and is a crucial ingredient in understanding the NN interaction.

• The semirelativistic chiral constituent quark model is a successful approach to describing baryon spectroscopy, which includes the chiral boson exchange interaction and a linear pairwise confining interaction. The model has only four free parameters, which are determined from the fit to all 35 confirmed low-lying states.

• The model predicts a unified description of both nonstrange and strange baryon spectra in good agreement with phenomenology. The spin-spin interaction is crucial in producing the correct ordering of positive and negative parity states in the baryon spectrum.

• The nucleon in the low-energy regime consists mostly of three constituent quarks, which are big objects due to their meson clouds. The short-range part of the chiral interaction is crucially important inside baryons, while the long-range Yukawa tails of meson-exchange interactions become important when constituent quarks are well separated.

• The same short-range part of the chiral interaction that produces hyperfine splittings in baryon spectroscopy also induces a short-range repulsion in the NN system. This repulsion is related to the spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry and is a crucial ingredient in understanding the NN interaction.

• The chiral constituent quark model provides a microscopic understanding of the NN interaction, which includes a short-range repulsion, a long- and intermediate-range attraction, and a tensor and spin-orbit force. The model predicts that the same short-range repulsion should persist in other octet

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a cardiac assist system that combines a cardiomyostimulator and a cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator to provide both cardiac assistance and arrhythmia therapy.
• The system features a device and algorithm that temporarily stops or inhibits skeletal muscle stimulation once the onset of an arrhythmia is sensed, allowing for accurate detection and diagnosis of arrhythmias.
• The system includes a pulse generator that delivers stimulation to a skeletal muscle graft, senses depolarizations of the patient's heart, and measures the intervals separating successive depolarizations to detect arrhythmias.
• The system provides skeletal muscle stimulation while charging for defibrillation, which helps maintain cardiac perfusion and limits the increase in defibrillation threshold, allowing for smaller capacitors or lower voltages.
• The system includes various features such as asynchronous muscle stimulation bursts, muscle catch stimulation, and programmable parameters to optimize cardiac assistance and arrhythmia therapy.</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to the field of nerve regeneration, particularly to nerve conduits for the regeneration of peripheral nerves, and provides a fabricated implantable nerve guidance conduit (NGC) with a spiral structured porous sheet.
• The NGC has an integrated spiral structured porous sheet decorated with surface channels and electrospun fibers, providing superior mechanical strength, multiple channels, stable aligned fibrous layers, good inter-cell communication, and high surface/volume ratios.
• The NGC has chambers at the distal and proximal ends to provide additional space for fitting nerve stumps and reduce tension at the suture line, and a dense outer fibrous tube to prevent scar tissue infiltration.
• The NGC is tunable, with controllable sizes, and its length and outer diameter depend on the size of the spiral-wound sheet, allowing for fabrication of conduits with various lengths.
• The NGC has a three-dimensional spiral structured porous sheet with proximal and distal reserved chambers, providing an optimal initial environment for nerve ingrowth and preventing stress when the nerve tissue is sutured.
• The NGC's surface channels and electrospun fibers provide guidance for cell migration and directional axonal regeneration, and the aligned fibers ensure that the regenerating axon comes into contact with aligned fibers.
• The NGC's mechanical properties, including Young's Modulus, percent elongation to failure, and tensile strength, are suitable for in vivo use and provide a mechanically strong conduit that can be sutured well during coaptation of the nerve stump and NGC.
• The NGC's porosity values range from 71.98% to 78.41%, and its cell proliferation results show significantly greater cell proliferation than single lumen NGCs.
• The NGC's implantation results in a 10 mm Sprague Dawley rat sciatic nerve defect show improved functional recovery, nerve regeneration, and muscle reinnervation compared to single lumen NGCs.</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention is a board game that simulates the life at a lake, where players acquire, sell, mortgage, and improve properties such as lake areas, dams, and boat dealerships.
• The game includes a game board with a continuous path of spaces, tokens representing players, title deed cards, game pieces, scrip money, and cards with lake-related indicia.
• Players roll dice to determine movement, and can purchase properties, erect lake cabins and marinas, and collect rental fees from other players who land on their properties.
• The game also features Makin A Wake and Sunken Chest cards that provide benefits, penalties, or instructions to move to specific spaces on the board.
• Players can mortgage properties to the Bank, but must pay interest to lift the mortgage, and can go bankrupt if they are unable to meet their financial obligations.
• The game continues until all but one player is bankrupt, and the remaining player is declared the winner.</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a wave-based imaging method and apparatus employing Radial Reflection Diffraction Tomography (RRDT) for imaging objects in a surrounding medium. The method involves directing predetermined energy waves radially outward from within an interspace and receiving scattered energy waves, which are then processed to produce images of the objects using a wave-based algorithm.
* The invention has various applications, including characterizing vulnerable atherosclerotic plaque, non-destructive evaluation of materials in boreholes, and imaging of objects in other confined spaces. The RRDT technique uses a Hilbert space inverse wave (HSIW) algorithm to reconstruct images of the surrounding medium, allowing for improved lateral resolution and characterization of objects.</summary>

<summary>
* The present application claims priority to and is a continuation of U.S. patent application Ser. No. 13/080,754, titled GARNISH PICK, filed Apr. 6, 2011. The application is a Non-Provisional of and claims priority to U.S. Provisional Patent Application Ser. No. 61/321,291, titled GARNISH PICK, filed Apr. 6, 2010. The entire contents of these applications are incorporated herein by reference in their entirety for all purposes.

* A garnish pick is disclosed that includes one or more appendages, which may comprise skewering shafts that are tapered and/or sharpened at an outer tip of the appendage for skewering and holding a garnish. The appendages may project from a main shaft of the garnish pick at a variety of angles and/or orientations. The garnish pick may have two or more appendages, wherein at least one of the appendages may serve as a hook, while at least one of the other appendages may serve as a skewering shaft.

* The garnish pick may be made of wood or of any other sufficiently rigid, flexible, and/or strong material such as plastic, rubber, metal, glass, ceramic, and the like depending on implementation. The various components of the garnish pick can be made of different materials, and the garnish pick may comprise two or more materials. The construction details of the garnish picks disclosed herein may include a main shaft and/or appendages that may curve, have abrupt bends, or be curved along at least a portion of its axis.

* The advantages of the disclosed embodiments may include that the garnish pick can be hooked to the side of a glass, preventing the pick from becoming completely or further submerged in a beverage, and can provide additional shafts on which to hold garnishes. Such embodiments may also eliminate the need to retrieve the pick out of the beverage or beverage container and may make it easier to eat garnishes off of the pick. The garnish pick may be used to hold garnishes with one or more appendages emerging from a main shaft, angled toward a sharp end of the main shaft.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a container of a blender, particularly to a set of high-speed blades mounted inside the lower portion of the container. The usage of blenders has become popular, and the configuration structure of a blender is mainly a set of rotatable blades disposed inside the container to mix ice cubes, vegetables, and fruits until they become liquid. In early phases, the container of the blender was made of glass, but it had some drawbacks such as being prone to breakage and requiring a glass break detector. The inventors of the present invention encountered these problems and provided a metal lining to shield the inner wall of the receptacle.

• The inventors of the present invention encountered the problems of the prior art and provided a metal lining to shield the inner wall of the receptacle, which is known by their patent document 1. Patent Document 1 is TW580,899 entitled “container for blender” assigned to the inventors Kou-I Ling and Rong-Yuan Tseng of the present invention on 21 Mar. 2004. The same is also patented in the USA assigned patent number as U.S. Pat. No. 6,786,440 on 7 Sep. 2004. The inventors aimed to provide a container of the blender that complies with all hygienic rules.

• A conventional blender having a cup and a set of blades installed within the base of the cup is shown in FIG. 1. When blades are rotated in high speed, the vegetable and fruit will be grated until they become liquid as well as a whirlpool is formed in the receptacle. The whirlpool in usual brings the rough and long fibers to the outer circle in contact with the inner wall by centrifugal force. Some rough and long fibers are neither brought to the lower portion of the cup by whirlpool nor further being grated by the blades.

• The present invention is aimed to provide a container of the blender comprises a cup and a lining disposed inside the cup characterized in that the lining is formed as a shield inside the cup. A number of teeth projected from the inner wall of the lining for grinding the fibers of vegetable and fruit. The lining is selected from one of the following: metal lining, glass lining, lining has approximately the same hardness. Several vertical ribs projected from the inner wall of the cup, several vertical stopper members formed on the inner wall of the lining.

• The lining is selected from one of the following: half-mask, whole mask. The half-mask lining is combined to

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a biological oil composition derived from a marine copepod, preferably of the genus Calanus, which has been found to have a statistically significant ability to inhibit the formation of atherosclerotic plaques and lower total blood cholesterol levels.
• The oil composition is rich in wax esters, stearidonic acid (SDA), eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), and has a unique fatty acid composition that differs from other marine oils.
• The biological effects of the copepod oil were studied in mice deficient in apolipoprotein E (ApoE), and the results showed that the copepod oil had a striking and statistically significant effect on reducing plaque formation and lowering blood cholesterol levels.
• The copepod oil composition is provided as a medicament for the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease, atherosclerosis, hypercholesterolaemia, and elevated blood cholesterol levels, and can be administered orally in a daily dosage level of 4-100 mg/kg body weight.
• The invention also provides a method for the prophylaxis or treatment of cardiovascular disease, which involves administering a pharmaceutical composition comprising the biological oil composition, and optionally, other components such as SDA, EPA, and DHA.</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a gravity-driven, steerable vehicle with a prone, face-down, face-forward riding position, suitable for varied terrain such as dirt, grass, or snow.
* The vehicle has at least two wheels or skis, or a combination of both, and at least one brake, providing precise control in turns, especially on snow-covered surfaces.
* The suspension system is configured to provide a smooth, stable ride over irregular surfaces, with independent mechanical, air-actuated, or hydraulic-actuated brakes and shock absorbers.
* The vehicle may have a combination of skis and wheels, or a slide pan, providing enhanced performance on snow-covered terrain, and may be retrofitted with components to create different versions.
* A primary object of the invention is to provide a gravity-driven, steerable vehicle with a chassis, riding surface, means for steering, braking, and harnessing the rider.
* The vehicle may have a safety harness, automatic brake, and means for towing and assisting the rider in staying on the vehicle.
* The ski assembly has a front end, rear end, running surface, and upward-facing surface, with a brake assembly that causes a brake blade to extend below the running surface when actuated.
* The vehicle may have a combination rear roll bar and transport bail, providing a tow or lift bar that can be attached to a ski lift.
* The prone, low-center-of-gravity design provides control and good visibility, with a relatively stable and safe ride, and the vehicle may be made from lightweight, foam-core, fiberglass-reinforced construction.
* The invention provides a means for suspension of the wheels and/or skis, with a single A-arm pivotably attached to an axle, and a shock absorber connecting end pivotably connected to one end of the shock absorber.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to an accommodating intraocular lens (IOL) device for implantation in a lens chamber of a subject's eye. The IOL device comprises two lens portions, a first lens portion providing most of the accommodative power and a second base lens providing most of the corrective refractive power. The first lens portion must respond to the contraction and relaxation of the ciliary muscles by changing shape or displacement along an optical axis. The first lens portion may be an elastically deformable lens chamber filled with a fluid or gel.

• The IOL device is resiliently biased to an unaccommodated state, characterized by a first diameter, and actuates to an accommodated state, characterized by a second diameter, in response to radial compressive forces exerted on the outer peripheral edge. The first lens is a biconvex lens, and the cavity is fully enclosed. The IOL further comprises a gel in the cavity, which has a refractive index of 1.46 or greater and a Young's modulus of 10 psi or less. The gel is preferably a highly-branched polymer, such as cross-linked silicone.

• The second lens is a plano-convex lens, a bi-convex lens, or a positive meniscus lens, and is substantially more rigid than the first lens. The IOL further comprises a hinge disposed between the circumferential haptic and the second lens, which directs a substantial portion of the compressive forces onto the first lens. Each of the opposing and deformable surfaces of the first lens has a thickness that is 50% or less of the second lens. The IOL further comprises one or both of a plurality of apertures disposed on the circumferential haptic and a circumferential channel defined within the circumferential haptic.

• The IOL device further comprises a plurality of raised bumps, wherein at least one of the plurality of raised bumps is positioned adjacent to each one of the plurality of apertures. The IOL device further comprises a plurality of troughs, at least one of the plurality of troughs extending radially inward from each one of the plurality of apertures to facilitate fluid flow into the apertures. The circumferential haptic comprises a plurality of radial arms coupling the second lens, the plurality of radial arms defining apertures therebetween to permit fluid communication with the main cavity. The circumferential haptic comprises a third circumferential cavity disposed peripherally of the main I

<summary>
• The present invention is a continuation-in-part of a prior application, Ser. No. 07/589,995, filed Sep. 28, 1990, entitled ESOPHAGEAL DISPLACEMENT ELECTRODE. This application is incorporated by reference herein. The invention relates to esophageal electrodes, specifically an electrode that can be inserted down a patient's esophagus and into the stomach. The electrode is designed to be in contact with the stomach wall in a position most favorable for electrically stimulating the ventricle of the heart.

• The invention is directed to an esophageal-stomach electrode to achieve greater efficiency in the performance of medical procedures such as pacing and defibrillation. The closer an electrode is positioned to the heart, the less electrical power is needed to control the heart and more consistent control of the heart is achieved. A thin semi-rigid plastic tube with the electrode on the distal end is used, similar to the tube in the 07/589,995 application, but of sufficient length to be passed down the esophagus into the stomach. The tube is approximately 20 inches long and 3/16 inch in diameter.

• The electrode includes a semi-rigid plastic tube made of nylon or other suitable material, with the distal end carrying an electrode, preferably spherical in shape. The electrode is 1/4 inch in diameter, which just exceeds the diameter of the tube, allowing it to make positive contact with the stomach wall. The distal end of the tube may be further displaced or the complete electrode pulled back out of the esophagus to cause a bulge in the stomach wall. This action places the electrode in its operative position closest to the ventricle of the heart.

• The tube is crimped to form a hinge, enabling it to bend readily at that point. Ports are formed on opposite sides of the hinge, each spaced approximately an inch therefrom. A rigid pin is disposed in the tube, extending generally parallel to the tube axis, and a pair of cords are connected to the proximal and distal ends of the pin. The cords extend proximally in the tube out its proximal end and into the control mechanism.

• The control mechanism is connected to the distal ends of the cords to operate the displacement mechanism by taking up one cord and playing out the other. The control mechanism includes a sleeve, rectangular in cross-section, containing a slide. A bracket is secured to the bottom wall of the sleeve, retaining

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a new device and method for treating tissues and open wounds, and accomplishing directed tissue growth. The device and method aim to address the limitations of existing open pore dressings used for combined fluid supply and wound suctioning. The invention provides a reliable apparatus and method for eliminating hydrostatic pressure and achieving a standardized combination of continuous therapeutic fluid supply with warning of impending dressing pore blockage.

* The device comprises a fluid bag placed on a support with a sloping or horizontal surface, and the hydrostatic pressure is eliminated or minimized by moving the support vertically along a pole. The positioning of the fluid bag can be facilitated using a horizontal level measuring device. The device also includes a fluid administration set with a drip chamber and an injection port.

* The fluid administration set allows for visual or automatic drop count, and the injection port enables intermittent doses of saline or drug solution to be administered against a resistance. The device also includes a suction port with an open grid means to counteract occlusion of the underlying open pores of the pad when exposed to continuous suction.

* The method for treating and regenerating tissues involves applying continuous suction to the drainage port, injecting a restricted amount of saline or drug solution into the dressing pad, and stopping the injection once the injected fluid becomes visible through the suction tube wall. The method also involves eliminating hydrostatic pressure in the fluid supply port and maintaining the tissue hydrostatic pressure at 0 mmHg.

* The device and method can be used for non-regenerative tissue treatment, regenerative treatment, and artificial circulation to a tissue scaffold. The device and method provide a reliable and efficient way to treat tissues and open wounds, and to accomplish directed tissue growth.

* The device and method also include a means for detecting bleeding from a wound during continuous suctioning treatment. The means comprises a receptacle, a scale, a canister, movement buffer organs, a computer, visual display, audible alarm, and telemetry.

* The method for detecting bleeding involves determining the baseline rate and variability of therapeutic fluid formation over time, determining the minimal rate of fluid formed in addition to the baseline rate which is to be considered as a sign of bleeding, and making the computer subtract incoming rates of fluid formation from baseline serially.

* The device and method provide a reliable and efficient way to treat tissues and open wounds, and to accomplish directed tissue growth. The device and method can be used in a variety of applications, including non-regenerative tissue treatment, regenerative treatment, and artificial circulation to a tissue scaffold.

<summary>
* The invention relates to pharmacological compositions containing polyelectrolyte complexes in microparticulate form and at least one active substance. The active substance can be embedded in the matrix of the polyelectrolyte complex, be a partner in the polyelectrolyte complex, or be bound to a partner of the polyelectrolyte complex. The active substances can be pharmacological active substances such as active peptides, proteins, enzymes, enzyme inhibitors, antigens, cytostatics, antibiotics, antiinflammatory agents, or vaccines.

* The polyelectrolyte complexes can be composed of a macromolecular, multiply charged component of one polarity and many low molecular weight ions of the other polarity, or of two macromolecular partners, each of which is multiply charged with different polarity. The partners employed for the complex formation are preferably biocompatible, biodegradable polyacids and polybases which are naturally occurring or composed of natural subunits. The particular counterions can be composed either of low molecular weight ions or likewise of a polyionic species.

* Microparticles composed of polyelectrolyte complexes can be prepared in average particle sizes from a few nm up to a few hundred μm. The breadth of the size distribution can be adjusted by the stirring speed on mixing the polyelectrolytes, the drop rate, the nozzle diameter, the pH, and by suitable choice of the polyelectrolyte partners. Particles below 5 μm in diameter are suitable for intravenous injection.

* The incorporation of an active substance in the polyelectrolyte complex particles/colloids can be carried out in at least 4 ways: incorporation by "entrapment" of the active substance, incorporation by absorption of the active substance from a solution, precipitation of the polyelectrolyte complex with the active substance chemically bound to at least one complex partner, and incorporation by employing the active substance as a partner in the formation of the polyelectrolyte complex. The invention also relates to a process for preparing pharmaceutical compositions containing polyelectrolyte complexes and active substances.

* Polyelectrolyte complex/active substance formulations show property profiles as required for diverse pharmaceutical applications. The cytostatic daunorubicin and the polyacid xylan polysulfate produce macroparticles which contain daunorubicin and release the latter in buffer solution or in biological systems uniformly over a lengthy

<summary>
* The invention relates to dental apparatus, specifically to dental cleaning and massaging apparatus, aiming to provide a more effective means of cleaning teeth and massaging gums. Research has shown that traditional brushing and flossing methods do not adequately prevent caries and peridental disease.

* The apparatus consists of a mouthpiece with upper and lower channel members that fit over the teeth and snugly against the gums, joined by a membrane structure. Pneumatic means are provided to move the channel members relative to the gums, massaging them, while hydraulic means clean the teeth and gingival crevices.

* The mouthpiece has bite blocks to hold the teeth in place, allowing the channel members to ride up and down on the gums during the massaging action. The elasticity of the membranes and air-sacks pulls the channel members toward each other when the air-sacks are deflated.

* The apparatus can be operated in three modes: providing both air and water, air only, or water only, controlled by three ON-OFF switches on the control box or a remote control device. The control box also provides suction to remove fluid seepage from the mouth.

* The invention can be modified with additional features, such as bristles to assist the massaging action, and a single coupling arrangement to couple the control panel to the mouthpiece. These changes can be made without departing from the spirit and scope of the invention.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a golf ball teeing device that allows a golfer to easily insert a golf tee into the ground with a golf ball on top without bending over. The device is designed to eliminate the need for a manually controlled unclamping mechanism, allowing a golf club to be used as the handle. This reduces the weight and size of the device, making it more portable and convenient to use. The device is also designed to be simple to use, with no cumbersome controls to release the tee and ball.

* The device consists of a housing with an upper and lower portion, a delayed urging means, and a ball interface member. The delayed urging means is designed to exhibit a delayed rebound after being compressed, allowing the device to automatically unclamp the ball and tee once the tee is pushed into the ground. The ball interface member provides a uniform surface to contact the golf ball, and the housing is designed to securely hold the ball and tee in place. The device also includes a clip for attaching to a golf bag or the golfer's apparel.

* The device is designed to be easy to use, with the golfer simply attaching it to the end of a golf club, placing a golf ball in the housing, and sliding a golf tee into the slot underneath the ball. The golfer then holds the golf club vertically and moves it straight down to sink the tee into the ground, causing the delayed urging means to compress and the device to lower with respect to the ball and tee. Once the tee is sunk to the desired depth, the golfer releases the ball and tee from the device by moving the golf club straight up. The device can then be removed from the teed ball by moving the golf club in a motion parallel to the ground.

* The device also allows for easy retrieval of the golf tee, whether it remains in the ground or comes out while hitting the ball. The golfer can use the golf club as a long handle to maneuver the device under the head of the tee and pull it out of the ground. For tees that come out of the ground and are lying horizontally, the golfer can use the device to scoop up the tee without bending. The device is designed to be convenient and easy to use, with the goal of making golf more accessible and enjoyable for golfers of all ages and abilities. </summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a novel electro-surgical dissection and cauterization instrument for use primarily in laparoscopic/endoscopic procedures, aiming to improve visualization and reduce unintentional cauterization of healthy tissue.
• The instrument features a rigid arm extending between the distal working tip electrode and the insulating sleeve, with at least a portion of the arm laterally offset from the longitudinal axis of the sleeve.
• The arm includes an electrical insulating layer along its entire length, up to the exposed working tip electrode, to prevent inadvertent cauterization of tissue with portions of the tool other than the working tip electrode.
• The instrument is designed for easy handling and use by the surgeon, with a plug at the proximal end for connecting to a conventional electro-surgical unit, and a conductive rod surrounded by a linear, rigid sleeve formed of an insulating material.
• The working tip electrode comes in various shapes, such as a hook or a flattened spatula, depending on the needs of the surgeon in a particular surgical application.
• The invention provides an enhanced viewing area of the surgical work site and working tip electrode for the surgeon, allowing for more precise and effective surgical procedures.</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a magnetic resonance imaging apparatus that allows exposures with the subject in at least two predetermined exposure positions, with at least one exposure taking place using predetermined adjustment parameters.
• In known magnetic resonance imaging apparatuses, exposure parameters must be modified for different exposure positions, requiring a readjustment of the apparatus, which can take 10 to 90 seconds per exposure position.
• The invention aims to provide high-contrast exposures in a short time, even for examinations of larger body segments, by determining the required adjustment parameters in a preceding adjustment process.
• The adjustment parameters are stored until the conclusion of the examination and can be used again when identical or similar exposure parameters are reached.
• The inventive solution is suitable for various forms of magnetic resonance imaging apparatuses, including cylindrical magnets and horseshoe magnets.
• The apparatus includes a support plate, transmit coils, receive coils, and an adjustment unit that processes inputs and supplies control signals to various components.
• In the inventive apparatus, larger bodily segments can be examined, and high-contrast exposures are obtained without omitting an adjustment, resulting in reduced examination times.
• The stored adjustment parameters enable quick switching of transmit and receive coils during the examination, allowing for the tracking of contrast agent over a larger body region without chronological gaps.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present disclosure relates to a person support apparatus, such as a bed, with a mechanism for adjusting the height and orientation of a patient support frame. The apparatus is suitable for hospital or long-term care beds. The patient support deck may be controllably articulated to take up different support configurations. The deck support frame is supported on leg assemblies with linear actuators for pivoting the leg assemblies relative to the deck support frame.

* The leg assemblies can be pivoted together to raise or lower the deck support frame while keeping it substantially parallel to the floor. Alternatively, one of the foot or head end assemblies can be pivoted to lower just one of the foot or head ends and move the deck support frame into the Trendelenburg or reverse Trendelenburg positions. The deck support frame is supported on leg assemblies which are pivotally connected at their upper end to the deck support frame. The leg assemblies have linear actuators for pivoting the leg assemblies relative to the deck support frame.

* Known arrangements for pivoting leg assemblies relative to a deck support frame have several problems, including a risk of trapping fingers in the guide element and a need to overcome frictional forces between the inner surface of the slideable guide element and the outer surface of the longitudinal element. These arrangements also have a propensity for dust and dirt to collect on the surface of the longitudinal element and interfere with the sliding operation. The present disclosure aims to address these issues. The present disclosure provides a person support apparatus with a deck support frame and a support assembly for supporting the deck support frame.

* The support assembly includes at least one leg assembly pivotally coupled at a first upper end portion to the deck support frame and coupled at its second lower end portion to floor engaging means. An actuator element is operable to move the leg assembly and thereby move the deck support frame relative to the floor. The deck support frame has two sides extending between a head end and a foot end. At least one of the sides of the deck support frame comprises an inverted substantially U-shaped channel element.

* The channel element has a substantially continuous upper surface, two substantially continuous side surfaces connected at their top edges to the upper surface, and a downward facing opening between the bottom edges of the two side surfaces. The first upper end portion of the leg assembly includes a guide or follower element arranged to contact and run along an inner surface of the channel element. This arrangement results in a deck support frame that is robust and stable. The deck support frame can accommodate changes in geometry necessary for movement or adjustment between

<summary>

* The present invention relates to a skin reflectance measuring apparatus, which is specifically adapted for measuring the reflectance of the skin. The measurement of skin reflectance finds a particular application in pathology and in cosmetology. It may also present an advantage for studying other skin diseases such as lichen, SSM, and for grading different types of skins. The invention finds an application in measuring the effect of products known as "anti-reflectance" products for greasy skins.

* Various methods and devices already exist for measuring surface reflectance, but they are not applicable to the measurement of skin reflectance. A first problem to be solved with this particular application is the problem of influence of color. The known devices using relative measurement remain inappropriate for measuring skin reflectance. The apparatuses used in industry generally comprise optical systems with focusing lenses which require an accurate positioning of the measuring apparatus.

* The apparatus according to the invention comprises a probe, a measuring device, and a flexible connection in fiber optics connecting the measuring device to the probe. The probe is designed to be placed in contact with the skin in order to light up the part of the skin surface requiring to be examined. The connection comprises three optical channels, which convey to the probe the light produced from a light-emitting device. The emitting and receiving devices are connected to a control and processing device via an interface circuit.

* The emitting device comprises means of regulating the intensity of the emitted light and is operated by control signals issued by the processing device. The receiving device comprises photo-electrical transducers working out electrical signals representing the normal reflection and the diffuse reflection. The processing device comprises memory circuits, an arithmetical and logical unit, and interface circuits permitting the connection with a display device.

* The resulting reflectance is a relative value worked out from measurements of the specular reflection and of the diffuse reflection. The difference is preferred to the quotient insofar as it introduces less scale distortion with respect to the judgement of the skin reflectance made by eye. A scale of reflectance may be defined from a measurement of a matt surface of reference and of a calibrated mirror. The reflectance value finally retained may be a mean value worked out from the results of a predetermined number of measurement cycles.

* The measuring operation consists in the following phases: initialization of the graph, and tracing of the outline of the screen with a view to displaying the measurement results as a curve representing the variation of the reflectance. The operator can thus correct any incorrect positioning of the probe by observing the position variations in y

<summary>
* The present invention relates to fasteners for albums such as photographic albums and scrapbooks where it is required to add or replace album pages.
* The invention provides a releasable fastener for an album comprising front and back covers and removable pages between the covers, with a pair of strap anchors and a strap that passes through aligned apertures in the covers and album pages.
* Each strap anchor is in the form of a channel in which the strap is snap-locked to be releasably locked therein against displacement.
* The strap is snap-locked into the channel by snapping engagement beneath locking lips at an open side of the channel facing the base of the channel.
* The base of the channel and opposing surface of the strap have formations which are engaged to prevent longitudinal displacement of the strap within the channel when it is in its engaged position beneath the lips.
* The strap anchors can be adhesively attached to the respective covers, for example by double-sided adhesive tape, and the strap is of a semi-rigid plastics material formed on one surface with parallel ribs.
* The invention also provides an album having at least two fasteners as defined above mounted along the spine part of the album, the strap anchors of each fastener being attached to the respective covers of the album.
* The fasteners can be produced inexpensively and are designed to be cost-sensitive, with a low profile to prevent interference with closure of the cover when in its closed position.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to the field of pelvic floor reconstruction using implants, specifically addressing the issue of pelvic organ prolapse (POP) in women. The invention aims to provide a reliable anchoring of the mesh implant, which is not achieved by prior art surgical procedures. The invention includes a needle for surgical threading of a strap of an implant through a tissue.

* The needle comprises a trap for trapping the strap, a tip for threading the trapped strap, and a mechanism for releasing the trap, allowing the tip to return to the accessible side of the tissue while abandoning the strap at the threaded point. The trap may include a niche and a rod for grasping the end of the strap. The mechanism for releasing the trap may be manually driven or comprise a cable driven from the accessible side of the tissue.

* The invention also includes an anterior implant with at least two first straps for threading into the arcus tendineous fascia pelvic (ATFP) ligaments and at least two second straps for threading into the sacrospinous (SS) ligaments. The anterior implant may be used for reconstructing the organs selected from the group including prolapse of the urinary bladder, the colon, and the small intestine. The anterior implant may further comprise spaces for reducing the weight of the implant.

* A posterior implant is also described, comprising at least two straps for threading into the sacrospinous (SS) ligaments, a first loop between the straps for anchoring to the cervix, and a second loop at the side opposing the straps for anchoring to the perineal body. The posterior implant may be used for reconstructing the organs selected from the group including the colon, the small intestine, and the uterus. The posterior implant may further comprise spaces for reducing the weight of the implant.

* The invention also includes a method for using a needle to thread a strap through a surface, comprising the steps of trapping an end of the strap, threading the needle through the surface, releasing the trap, and returning the needle to the accessible side while abandoning the strap at the threaded point. The method may be used for installing an anterior or posterior implant. The method allows the surgeon to thread the strap from the side having surgical access, without requiring any additional perforations of the body from the opposing direction.

* The needle and method of the invention provide a reliable and efficient way to anchor the mesh implant, improving the outcome of pelvic floor reconstruction surgery. The invention is designed to be minimally invasive, reducing the risk of complications and promoting

<summary>
* The present invention relates to methods and apparatus for removing a gas from a liquid, particularly for separating oxygen from water on an offshore hydrocarbon recovery platform. The apparatus includes a vessel with multiple gasification chambers, each with a vapor space, and a mechanism for ingesting and mixing a second gas into the liquid to displace the first gas.
* The invention provides a mechanical, cylindrical gas scavenger machine with a reduced height compared to a stripping tower, and is particularly suited for use on floating offshore hydrocarbon recovery platforms. The apparatus can remove oxygen from water to trace levels, making it an efficient solution for minimizing corrosion in equipment used in offshore drilling operations.</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to methods and apparatus for providing ventilatory assistance matched to a subject's respiratory need, particularly for spontaneously breathing human subjects requiring long-term ventilatory assistance during sleep. The ventilatory assistance can be for a subject who is either spontaneously or non-spontaneously breathing, or moves between these breathing states. The invention is especially suitable for subjects with severe lung disease, chest wall disease, neuromuscular disease, or diseases of respiratory control.

• The invention aims to match the phase and degree of assistance to the subject's spontaneous efforts when ventilation is well above a target ventilation, automatically adjust the degree of assistance to maintain at least a specified minimum average ventilation without relying on the integrity of the subject's chemoreflexes, and provide some immunity to the effects of sudden leaks. The invention also seeks to damp out instabilities in the spontaneous ventilatory efforts, such as Cheyne Stokes breathing. The invention uses fuzzy logic to determine the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle as a continuous variable.

• The invention discloses a method for calculating the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle, including determining the instantaneous airflow and rate of change of airflow, and using fuzzy inference rules to determine the phase. The method also includes calculating the average respiratory rate by low pass filtering the instantaneous rate of change of phase. The invention further discloses a method for providing ventilatory assistance in a spontaneously breathing subject, comprising the steps of ascribing a desired waveform template function, calculating the instantaneous phase, selecting a desired pressure modulation amplitude, and setting the delivered pressure to the subject.

• The invention also discloses a method for calculating the instantaneous inspired volume of a subject, operable substantially without run-away under conditions of suddenly changing leak. The method includes determining respiratory airflow approximately corrected for leak, calculating an index varying from 0 to 1 equal to the fuzzy extent to which the corrected respiratory airflow is large positive for longer than expected, or large negative for longer than expected, and calculating the instantaneous inspired volume as the integral of the corrected respiratory airflow multiplied by the fuzzy negation of the index.

• The invention further discloses a method for providing assisted ventilation to match the subject's need, comprising the steps of describing a desired waveform template function, determining respiratory airflow approximately corrected for leak, calculating an index varying from 0 to 1 equal to the fuzzy extent to which the respiratory airflow is large positive for longer than expected, or large negative for longer than expected, and calculating the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle.

• The invention also discloses a method for providing assisted

<summary>
* The invention relates to a power and free conveyor system that allows for the transfer of carriers from one predetermined path to another by pushing across a transfer zone in a minimum period of time with minimum cost and maintenance.
* The system uses a third dog that is normally urged to an operative carrier pushing position but is held by the track out of operative position, allowing for selective transfer of the carrier over short and long distances as desired.
* The system can be operated in various configurations, including moving the dogs upwardly simultaneously or sequentially, to minimize the number of pushers on the conveyor chain and reduce costs while retaining a minimum lapse of time in transfer.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention is based on a generic hydraulic unit for a vehicle brake system, where pressure fluid entrained into a cam element chamber is delivered to a spring chamber, far from electrical components, and collected in that chamber. This eliminates the need for permeable elements at a central venting point or a check valve, resulting in cost savings and a hermetic seal of the unit from the environment.
* The hydraulic unit includes a housing block, a motor, a housing, and a covering hood, with a conduit oriented downward from the cam element chamber and discharging into the spring chambers. The conduit portions are utilized in two ways, providing a cost savings compared with two separately embodied conduits.
* The invention also brings about a pressure equilibrium between the motor and a covering hood, which contains electrically operative components, by making use of a cable sheath joined in sealed fashion to the covering hood, and this sheath is terminated at the highest possible point in the vehicle to avert the risk that water can enter a partially immersed vehicle.</summary>

<summary>
• The present disclosure relates to a packaging machine with a plurality of work stations that are operable in synchronism with one another and define a production direction of the packaging machine.
• The packaging machine is provided with a rotationally driven shaft arranged in the production direction, which drives the tool members of a plurality of work stations, synchronizing their movements mechanically.
• The shaft is connected to a drive, such as an electric motor or servomotor, and can be driven alternately in different directions of rotation or in a continuous 360° rotation.
• A transfer mechanism, comprising an arrangement of toggle levers and/or a cam mechanism, is provided between the shaft and each of the movable tool members to convert the rotational movement of the shaft into the movement required to operate the respective tool member.
• The packaging machine may comprise a plurality of work stations, including a forming station, a sealing station, and/or a separating or cutting station, which are arranged on a common machine frame.
• At least two work stations of the packaging machine may be arranged on different vertical levels, allowing for a more compact structural design.
• The packaging machine may also be provided with a frame for supporting the shaft, which should be adequate to stabilize the shaft and prevent the generation of vibrations in the packaging machine.
• The tool members of the work stations can be implemented as replaceable components, and various media connections can be attached to the tools, which are configured to be easily releasable.</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a ventilation system for rotating water feeds, particularly useful in connection with water-cooled generators. The invention aims to eliminate air enclosed in the cooling system to avoid local overheating and the formation of steam bubbles. This is achieved by providing a bypass with at least one inlet and outlet arranged between the feed duct and discharge duct.

* Prior art techniques have been found to require considerable engineering effort, and the present invention seeks to provide a simpler and more effective solution. The invention utilizes the pressure gradient between the inflow and outflow for automatic operation of the device. This results in rapid and complete removal of air bubbles from the cooling system.

* The bypass is arranged in or on an end face of the feed ducts, which is particularly advantageous if the branch point is at the end of the feed duct. The bypass can also be designed as a radially arranged pipe member with at least one inlet in the space around the axis of rotation. This solution is suitable for cases where cooling water inlets are distributed over the entire length of a central bore.

* The invention provides several embodiments of the bypass, including a coiled pipe having at least one inlet opening into the space around the axis of rotation. This form of construction affords advantages in minimizing the amount of leakage and bypass. The bypass can also be structured to include means for increasing the hydrodynamic resistance of flow through the bypass.

* The various embodiments of the invention are depicted in the accompanying drawings, which show the arrangement of the feed duct, discharge duct, and bypass. The drawings illustrate the different designs of the bypass, including a T-pipe, a radially arranged pipe, and a coiled pipe. Each embodiment is designed to provide effective ventilation of the cooling system.

* The invention provides a ventilation system that is relatively simple in design and construction, yet effective in eliminating air bubbles from the cooling system. The system is particularly useful in connection with water-cooled generators, where the elimination of air bubbles is crucial for efficient operation. The invention achieves its objectives by providing a bypass with at least one inlet and outlet arranged between the feed duct and discharge duct.</summary>

<summary>
• This invention relates to finishing articles, specifically those with a mounting hub permanently affixed, designed for quick attachment and release to a portable power tool.
• The invention aims to address the problem of preventing undesired disassociation of the article from the shaft or spindle, particularly in detachable connections.
• Prior art devices used adhesives, keyways, and corresponding key structures to secure the grinding wheel to the mounting hub, but these methods had inherent disadvantages.
• The invention provides a disposable finishing article drive member assembly that securely holds the article during operation without the use of adhesives.
• The assembly includes a backing flange with gripping means, a retaining nut, and a pressure cap that work together to place the grinding wheel in compression during use.
• The compression force increases as the grinding wheel is tightened onto the spindle, precluding movement relative to the hub and disengagement from the spindle.
• The invention is relatively light in weight, vibration-free, and less expensive than prior art throw-away articles while meeting all safety standards.
• The assembly can accommodate various sizes of standard diameter depressed center grinding wheels and can be easily assembled and disassembled.
• The invention provides a secure attachment of the abrasive finishing article to the power tool, precluding relative rotation of the grinding wheel with respect to the driving member.</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a steering column for a motor vehicle, which comprises a jacket unit supporting a steering shaft rotatably about its longitudinal axis and a retaining part. The jacket unit is connected with the retaining part across an energy absorption connection and a break-away connection. The energy absorption connection comprises at least one bending wire or strip that is deformed upon a displacement of the jacket unit with respect to the retaining part. The break-away connection is released if a limit value of the force acting onto the jacket unit parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft in the direction toward the front of the motor vehicle is exceeded.

* The steering column is preferably implemented such that it is adjustable in length, and an openable and closable securement device is provided. The retaining part is formed by a part of the securement device, and the retaining part in the closed state of the securement device is in engagement with a securement part that is secured in position with respect to the bracket unit. The securement part and the retaining part come into mutual contact in different positions depending on the length positioning of the steering column. The retaining part is guided displaceably with respect to the jacket unit parallel to the longitudinal axis and is connected with the jacket unit across a break-away connection and an energy absorption connection.

* The break-away connection can be realized via a shear bolt, and the energy absorption connection can be developed using a bending wire or strip that is connected with the retaining part and the jacket unit. The bending wire or strip is elastically deformed during assembly, and the jacket unit is prestressed with respect to the retaining part relative to a displacement parallel to the longitudinal axis in the direction toward the motor vehicle front.
