• The present invention relates to a system for controlling daylight and artificial illumination in a space, as well as reducing sun glare. The system uses a combination of electric lighting and motorized window treatments to achieve a desired illumination profile. The system can be divided into multiple zones, each with its own lighting and window treatment controls.

• The system uses a central processor to control the lighting and window treatments based on input from photosensors. The photosensors measure the light level in the space and transmit this information to the central processor. The central processor then adjusts the lighting and window treatments to achieve the desired illumination profile.

• The system can be configured to have multiple presets, each with its own lighting and window treatment settings. The presets can be adjusted based on the time of day, the amount of daylight available, and the desired illumination profile. The system can also be configured to have a manual override, allowing users to adjust the lighting and window treatments manually.

• The system uses a closed-loop control algorithm to adjust the lighting and window treatments based on the input from the photosensors. The algorithm takes into account the amount of daylight available, the time of day, and the desired illumination profile. The algorithm can also be adjusted to account for the spectral sensitivity of the photosensors.

• The system can also be configured to reduce sun glare by adjusting the window treatments based on the sun angle. The system uses an astronomic time clock to determine the sun angle and adjust the window treatments accordingly. The system can also be configured to adjust the dead-band thresholds based on the sun angle.

• The system can be configured to have multiple dead-band thresholds, each with its own set of lighting and window treatment settings. The dead-band thresholds can be adjusted based on the amount of daylight available, the time of day, and the desired illumination profile. The system can also be configured to have a manual override, allowing users to adjust the lighting and window treatments manually.

• The system can be configured to use a variable control setpoint or threshold to adjust the lighting and window treatments based on the sun angle. The system uses an astronomic time clock to determine the sun angle and adjust the control setpoint accordingly. The system can also be configured to adjust the dead-band thresholds based on the sun angle.

• The system can be configured to use a low sampling rate numerical integration of the light level error to adjust the lighting and window treatments. The system uses a numerical integration algorithm to accumulate the light level error over time and adjust the lighting and window treatments accordingly. The system can also

<summary>
• The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) created the Superfund program to clean up the nation's most contaminated hazardous waste sites. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) investigates contaminated areas and places the most highly contaminated sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for study and cleanup. As of December 1996, there were 1,210 sites on the NPL, and EPA had selected incineration as a Superfund cleanup remedy 43 times. EPA establishes specific cleanup standards for each incinerator used at a Superfund site, based on studies of the site's characteristics.

• EPA relies on four principal methods to ensure the safe operation of incinerators used to clean up Superfund sites: setting site-specific standards for emissions and operations, incorporating safety features into an incinerator's emergency systems, monitoring emissions at the incinerator's stack and along the site's perimeter, and providing 24-hour on-site oversight. However, EPA has not followed through on other opportunities to improve its oversight of incinerators, including having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors inspect Superfund incinerators and systematically sharing the lessons learned from site to site. EPA officials agreed that they should be sharing the lessons learned from each site, but they have no formal mechanism to ensure that other incineration projects can benefit from the experiences of previous sites. The General Accounting Office recommends that EPA implement its guidance for having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators and document the lessons learned about safe operation from the experiences of each Superfund site.</summary>

<summary>
* The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sections 4911 and 162(e) have different definitions of lobbying, which can affect registration and reporting requirements. The LDA definition covers only contacts with federal government officials, while the IRC definitions cover contacts with state and local government officials as well. The LDA definition also includes a broader range of nonlegislative matters, such as regulations and policies.

* The LDA definition of lobbying includes legislative matters and an extensive list of nonlegislative matters, while IRC section 4911 only covers lobbying contacts that address specific legislative proposals. IRC section 162(e) covers lobbying contacts on legislative and nonlegislative subjects, but its coverage of legislative subjects is somewhat more limited than LDA's coverage. The LDA definition also includes grassroots lobbying, which is not covered under the IRC definitions.

* The LDA definition covers contacts with any covered government officials about any legislative or nonlegislative matters, while the IRC definitions require that the contact be on a specific legislative proposal or a specific legislative matter. The LDA definition also includes a broader range of executive branch officials, including all officials in the Executive Office of the President and officials at levels O-7 and above in the uniformed services. The IRC definitions only cover executive branch officials who may participate in the formulation of legislation.

* The LDA definition contains 19 exceptions to the definition of lobbying, while the IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) contain 5 and 7 exceptions, respectively. The exceptions in the LDA definition make technical clarifications in the law and do not provide special exceptions for particular groups. The exceptions in the IRC definitions provide technical clarifications to the statutory provisions and do not appear to exclude a significant amount of expenses that would be counted as lobbying expenses under the other lobbying definitions.

* The choice of definition can significantly affect whether an organization must register under LDA and what information it must disclose on its semiannual lobbying report. Using an IRC definition instead of the LDA definition could result in an organization not filing lobbying registrations, because the use of the IRC definition could keep their federal lobbying below the LDA registration thresholds. The choice of definition can also affect the individuals who must be listed as lobbyists on an organization's lobbying registration.

* The LDA requires organizations to report their total estimated expenses for all activities covered by the definition, but the reported expenses do not reveal how much of the reported expenses were for individual activities and for what level of government

<summary>
* The current surface transportation programs in the US are not effectively addressing the nation's transportation challenges, with a lack of clear vision and federal role, and a focus on formulas rather than performance and needs. Many programs are not linked to performance or outcomes, and the fiscal sustainability of the Highway Trust Fund is in doubt due to increased spending without commensurate increases in revenues. The federal role in surface transportation has expanded over the years, but the programs have become complex and inefficient.

* The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has identified a framework of principles to guide the restructuring of surface transportation programs, including creating well-defined goals, establishing a clear federal role, incorporating performance and accountability, employing the best tools and approaches, and ensuring fiscal sustainability. These principles can help ensure that restructured programs address current challenges and provide a framework for considering levels of investment and funding and financing options. The GAO has also developed illustrative questions to help determine the extent to which proposals align with these principles.

* The GAO has reported that the effectiveness of federal surface transportation programs can be increased by promoting and facilitating the use of the best tools and approaches to improve results and emphasize return on investment. This includes using economic analysis, such as benefit-cost analysis, in project selection, and requiring grantees to conduct post-project evaluations. The GAO has also identified various financing mechanisms, such as bonding, loans, and credit assistance, that can provide flexibility for state and local governments when funding additional infrastructure projects.

* The GAO has also examined the potential of public-private partnerships to help meet the nation's transportation financing challenges, and has identified both benefits and risks associated with these partnerships. The GAO has recommended that the Secretary of Transportation develop and submit objective criteria for identifying national public interests in highway public-private partnerships, and that Congress direct the Secretary to do so. The GAO has also noted that the federal role in transportation provides an opportunity to identify emerging national public interests in highway public-private partnerships.

* The GAO has concluded that the nation's surface transportation programs are no longer producing the desired results, and that a fundamental reexamination of the program is warranted. The GAO has recommended that Congress review the results of surface transportation programs and test their continued relevance and relative priority, and that appropriate funding sources and financing mechanisms be tailored for programs that continue to be relevant in today's environment. The GAO will continue to assist Congress in evaluating options and developing a national transportation policy for the 21st century.</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) defines a Military Working Dog (MWD) as any canine bred, procured, or acquired to meet DOD's requirements to support operations in the protection of installations, resources, and personnel. MWDs are removed from service when they can no longer perform their duties due to medical or behavior problems, and are then made available for adoption under "Robby's Law".
• Adopted MWDs often require preventative care and may have prevalent medical conditions such as skin, dental, and musculoskeletal issues, with estimated costs for treatment varying based on factors such as course of treatment and geographic location. Assistance with privately provided veterinary care is available through nonprofit organizations, such as the U.S. War Dogs Association, and owners with access to DOD medical care may also purchase care for their adopted MWDs at military installations.</summary>

<summary>
* The Institute of Medicine published a report in 1993 discussing secret U.S. chemical weapons programs during World War II, which found that an estimated 60,000 military personnel participated in tests of exposure to mustard agents and lewisite. The report also identified unknown numbers of additional servicemembers who may have been exposed to these substances through production, transportation, and storage. In response, the Deputy Secretary of Defense issued a memo releasing individuals from nondisclosure restrictions and tasked the secretaries of the military departments to declassify and provide information to the VA. The Chemical Weapons Exposure Study Task Force was developed to identify DOD personnel exposed to chemical substances.

* The task force identified approximately 6,400 servicemembers and civilians who were potentially exposed to mustard, lewisite, and other chemical substances. A database was created with information about these individuals, and certificates of commendation were sent to over 700 individuals. The contractor developed a database and issued reports identifying locations of human exposures to chemical substances. The reports included information on tests, transportation, production, storage, and disposal.

* In 2000, the acting Secretary of Veterans Affairs requested assistance from the Secretary of Defense in obtaining information about classified chemical and biological tests under DOD's Project 112 program. DOD officials initiated actions to identify potentially exposed individuals, and the Defense Authorization Act for FY 2003 required DOD to submit a comprehensive plan for reviewing and declassifying Project 112 records. The plan was implemented, and DOD identified 5,842 servicemembers and estimated 350 civilians who were potentially exposed during Project 112 tests.

* DOD's current effort to identify individuals potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances lacks clear and consistent objectives, scope of work, and information needs. The objectives of DOD's current effort are inconsistent, and the scope of work has expanded to include other exposures. The amount and type of information that the contractor needs to collect have also been expanded. DOD's current effort has not included an active search of civilian personnel.

* DOD's current effort lacks adequate oversight of contractor activities and results. OUSD (AT&L)'s chemical and biological defense office did not fully leverage the work of other entities that had previously identified exposed individuals. Multiple DOD and non-DOD organizations have conducted independent efforts to identify thousands of individuals who were potentially exposed during chemical or biological tests. DOD's current effort lacks transparency, and it has not worked with veterans or kept Congress and veterans service organizations fully informed.

<summary>
* The National Criminal History Improvement Program (NCHIP) is a federal grant program that aims to improve the accuracy, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records used by various national systems. NCHIP is managed by the Department of Justice's Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) and has provided over $438 million in grants to states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories since its inception in 1995. The program's goal is to build a national infrastructure to facilitate the interstate exchange of criminal history and other relevant records.

* NCHIP funds are used by states to support various activities, including improving criminal history records, automating fingerprint identification systems, and enhancing sex offender registries. States are required to provide a 10% match to the federal funds awarded, but many states have invested much more than the required amount. For example, one state that received over $5 million in NCHIP funds estimated that over $20 million of its own funds have been invested in system improvements since 1995.

* The use of NCHIP funds by states is closely coordinated with the federal Edward Byrne Memorial Grant Program, which requires states to use at least 5% of their awards for improving criminal history records. NCHIP funds are also used to support the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS), which is used to conduct presale background checks of persons purchasing firearms. In fiscal years 2000-2003, a majority of NCHIP funds were used for NICS-related purposes.

* Despite progress made in automating criminal history records, some areas still reflect a need for improvements. For example, automated information on the disposition of felony and other potentially disqualifying arrests is not always widely available. Additionally, automated information is not always available to identify other prohibited purchasers, such as persons convicted of misdemeanor crimes of domestic violence.

* The demand for background checks is growing, driven by screening requirements for employment and other noncriminal justice purposes. The number of civil fingerprint submissions to the FBI has increased substantially in recent years, with 9.1 million submissions in 2002. The growth in civil fingerprint submissions is partly attributable to federal legislation that encouraged states to have procedures requiring fingerprint-based national searches of criminal history records.

* The future of NCHIP is uncertain, but policymakers should consider the extent of cumulative progress and shortfalls in creating national, automated systems that cover all needed types of information. The program's goal of improving public safety by enhancing the quality, completeness, and accessibility of the nation's criminal history and sex offender record

<summary>
• The SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were fairly stated in all material respects, but the agency did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of September 30, 2007. This was due to a material weakness and significant deficiencies in internal control, which may adversely affect decisions based on inaccurate information.

• The material weakness was caused by a combination of control deficiencies in the period-end financial reporting process, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures. These deficiencies collectively resulted in more than a remote likelihood that a material misstatement of the financial statements would not be prevented or detected.

• In addition to the material weakness, three significant deficiencies in internal control were identified, concerning property and equipment, information security, and accounting for budgetary resources. These deficiencies, although not material weaknesses, represent significant deficiencies in the design or operation of internal control.

• The SEC made progress in resolving information security weaknesses, but previously identified weaknesses still need to be addressed, along with new weaknesses found during the audit. The agency's information security program has not been fully implemented, leaving financial information and assets vulnerable to misuse or destruction.

• The SEC's property and equipment controls were found to be deficient, with inaccuracies in recorded acquisition costs and dates, unrecorded purchases, and errors in amounts capitalized and amortized for internal-use software projects. These errors did not materially affect the financial statements, but evidence a significant deficiency in control over property and equipment.

• The agency's accounting for budgetary resources was also found to be deficient, with errors in recording obligations and undelivered orders, and a lack of effective review over these transactions. These errors were corrected, but the ineffective processes that caused them constitute a significant deficiency in internal control.

• The SEC's management is responsible for preparing financial statements, establishing and maintaining internal control, and complying with applicable laws and regulations. The agency's management provided comments on the draft report, discussing plans to remediate the material weakness and address the findings and recommendations identified during the audit.
</summary>

<summary>
* The US Postal Service had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with 80,238 in Executive and Administrative Schedule (EAS) positions, making up about 10% of total Service career-level employees. The EAS workforce consists primarily of employees in EAS 11 through 26 positions, with management-level positions beginning at EAS 16.
* The Postal Service's Diversity Development Department was established in 1992 to foster an all-inclusive business environment and support the recruitment, retention, and upward mobility of women and minorities. The department reports directly to the Deputy Postmaster General and is responsible for actively supporting diversity-related issues.
* A study by Aguirre International found that women and minorities were underrepresented in higher EAS positions, with a perceived "glass ceiling" at EAS 17 and above positions. However, the study's findings were based on limited data and did not provide convincing evidence of a glass ceiling.
* The Postal Service developed 23 initiatives in response to the Aguirre report, aimed at strengthening its diversity program and addressing concerns raised by the study. The initiatives include improving data collection and use, increasing diversity in hiring and promotions, and enhancing supplier diversity.
* The Postal Service has made progress in implementing the initiatives, with nine completed and seven 90-99% complete as of December 1998. However, the Service still lacks reliable data on the flow of applicants through its promotion processes, which hinders its ability to identify and remove barriers to the promotion of women and minorities.
* The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Postmaster General ensure that appropriate Service officials capture EEO group data and use it to improve the Service's diversity program, including identifying barriers to promotions to high-level EAS positions. The GAO also suggests that the Service establish targets and measures to track its progress in meeting its diversity goals and objectives.</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) is planning to replace the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center (LRMC) and the 86th Medical Group (MDG) clinic with a new medical center in Germany, which will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for the European Command, Central Command, and Africa Command theaters of operation.
• DOD officials used patient workload data and staffing requirements to determine the size and configuration of the replacement medical center, but the documentation of these processes contained inconsistencies, gaps, and calculation errors.
• The replacement medical center's design incorporates patient quality of care and environmentally friendly standards, including evidence-based design and Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) green building standards.
• DOD's cost estimating methodology for the replacement medical center substantially met best practice criteria, but the documentation of the cost estimate was minimal, lacking detailed information on data sources, calculations, and estimating methodologies.
• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that DOD provide clear documentation on how medical planners applied DOD criteria to determine the facility's requirements and revise the cost estimate to reflect potential posture changes and correct calculation errors.</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) is the principal federal agency responsible for programs in four areas: housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues.
* HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs that were not funded during fiscal year 1999, with a total budget of about $28 billion in new discretionary budget authority.
* The proposed budget raises questions about HUD's capacity to manage such an increase, given its ongoing organizational reform and the need for dedicated resources to plan, implement, and manage new programs.
* One of the largest program increases in HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget proposal is in its Section 8 housing assistance program, with a proposed budget of over $3 billion for project-based contract renewals.
* The General Accounting Office (GAO) has concerns about the accuracy of HUD's budget proposals for the Section 8 program, including the use of unexpended balances and the basis for contract renewal costs.
* HUD's Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) Program provides communities with grants for activities that benefit low- and moderate-income people, but the program's management system, IDIS, has been found to be incomplete, inaccurate, and untimely.
* The GAO is concerned that HUD may not be prepared to administer a new contracting initiative, Contract Administration, due to documented weaknesses in its contracting practices.
* HUD is also proposing an increase in its Urban Empowerment Zones (EZ) Program, but it is unclear why HUD needs to fund the same communities with two different programs.
* The GAO has provided a draft of its statement to HUD for review and comment, and HUD officials have responded with comments on several issues, including the number of new programs and initiatives.</summary>

<summary>
* The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency exercises discretion throughout the alien apprehension and removal process, with officers having more latitude to exercise discretion when encountering aliens who are not fugitives or criminals and are not targets of ICE investigations. The alien apprehension and removal process encompasses six phases, and officers exercise the most discretion during the initial phases. ICE has recently expanded its worksite enforcement and fugitive operations, increasing the probability that officers will encounter aliens with humanitarian issues.

* ICE guidance to instruct officer decision making in cases involving humanitarian issues and aliens who are not primary targets of ICE investigations is not comprehensive and has not been updated to reflect ICE's expanded worksite and fugitive operations. The lack of comprehensive guidance puts ICE officers at risk of taking actions that are not appropriate exercises of discretion and do not support the agency's operational objectives. ICE has recently begun undertaking reviews and revisions of training to provide critical information to officers and supervisors.

* ICE relies on supervisory reviews and an inspection program to monitor its removal operations, but neither provides a mechanism for management to collect and analyze information specific to officers' exercise of discretion. The ability to collect and analyze data about the exercise of discretion across field offices could provide ICE with additional assurance that it can identify and respond to areas that may require corrective action. ICE plans to update its data systems, but it is unclear whether these plans will provide information on officers' exercise of discretion.</summary>

<summary>
• The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits that can be redeemed for food in stores nationwide. FNS funds food stamp benefits and about half of the states’ administrative costs and establishes regulations for implementing the Food Stamp Program. FNS regulations require that states certify household eligibility at least annually and establish requirements for households to report changes that occur after they are certified.

• To monitor program accountability, FNS’s quality control system measures states’ performance in accurately determining food stamp eligibility and calculating benefits. States implement the Food Stamp Program by determining whether households meet established limits on gross income and assets, calculating monthly benefits for eligible households, and issuing benefits to households. The actual amount of the food stamp benefit is based on household income after certain deductions—including shelter, dependent care, and child support.

• FNS offers alternatives to monthly and change reporting: quarterly and semiannual reporting, which decrease the frequency with which households with earnings are required to report. Many states told us that they used reporting options and waivers to reduce their payment errors, to ease program administration, and to simplify paperwork requirements for households. Because some reporting options applied to specific households only, many states considered them somewhat restrictive.

• The Transitional Benefit Alternative gives states the option to continue to provide families with their same food stamp benefit amount for 3 months after they leave welfare. Many states told us they plan on using this option to support working families, as it helps with the transition from welfare to work by stabilizing the families after they leave welfare. The primary reason that states would provide a transitional benefit is to support working families.

• No state is implementing or plans to implement all aspects of the Simplified Food Stamp Program option, mainly due to its complexity and difficulty in implementation. The simplified program option was to be a vehicle for creating conformity between TANF and the Food Stamp Program by merging the programs’ rules into a single set of requirements for individuals receiving both types of assistance. However, states are not planning to use the simplified program, but some state officials indicated that it might be worthwhile to develop such a program if it could apply to all food stamp households.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter. The program aimed to achieve ambitious maintainability goals to realize lower operating and support costs and wartime operational availability. However, the program has experienced significant increases in program acquisition unit cost and funding reductions, leading to restructuring. The Army proposed a program restructure to acquire six aircraft in addition to the two prototypes by deferring developmental efforts to fiscal year 2002 and beyond.

* The Comanche program's restructuring continues to pose risks associated with making production decisions before knowing whether the aircraft will be able to perform as required. The Army's plan to defer additional developmental efforts to fiscal year 2002 and beyond may increase the risk that needed funds may not be available to perform the deferred developmental effort. The program's uncertainties in software development and aircraft maintainability increase the risk that the aircraft will not perform successfully. The Army's maintenance concept for the Comanche program is predicated on two levels of maintenance—unit- and depot-level maintenance.

* The Comanche program is experiencing technical problems, including software development issues and maintainability requirements that may not be achievable. The program is at risk of not meeting its maintainability goals, including direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour, mean time to repair, and fault isolation. The Army established a requirement of a 1-percent false removal rate for the Comanche, which is considered stringent and challenging to achieve. The program's weight growth is also a concern, with the Comanche's empty weight increasing from its original specification of 7,500 pounds to 7,883 pounds.

* The Comanche program's software development is a significant program objective, with the development and integration of on-board, embedded computer systems being critical to the aircraft's performance and capability. However, software development problems still exist, including delays in software development and testing, and improvements are needed in configuration management. The lack of a uniform, qualified compilation system among software developers could put first flight at risk. The program is also experiencing high turnover of software engineers at one of the contractor team's facilities.

* The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Defense require the Army to complete operational testing to validate the Comanche's operational effectiveness and suitability before committing any funds to acquire long-lead production items or enter low-rate initial production. The GAO also recommends that the Army not commit production funds to the program until performance and mission requirements are met. The GAO believes that the

<summary>
* Ground ambulance services are provided by various organizations with different structures, staffing, and revenue sources. Medicare payments for ambulance services consist of a service-level payment and a mileage payment. Providers may be affiliated with institutions, independent, for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based, and may rely on volunteers or paid staff. The mix of revenues available to providers varies, including community tax support, charitable donations, and payments from Medicare or Medicaid.

* The cost of providing ground ambulance transports varies greatly among providers, ranging from $224 to $2,204 per transport in 2010, with a median cost of $429. Providers' costs are affected by factors such as volume of transports, intensity of Medicare transports, and level of government subsidies. Personnel costs account for the largest percentage of providers' total costs, and providers with lower transport volumes tend to have higher costs per transport. The variability in costs per transport reflects differences in provider characteristics.

* Medicare payments to ambulance providers are made through a national fee schedule, which includes a service-level payment and a mileage payment. The payment formula takes into account the type of transport, the number of miles traveled, and the geographic location of the transport. Providers' Medicare margins, which represent the difference between their Medicare payments and costs, vary greatly, with a median margin of 2% in 2010. The introduction of the national fee schedule in 2002 may have contributed to increased billing for Medicare ambulance services.

* The number of Medicare ambulance transports increased by 33% from 2004 to 2010, with the largest increase in super-rural areas. The increase in transports was primarily due to an increase in basic life support nonemergency transports. The Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Inspector General has cited improper payments as a potential cause of the increase in ambulance utilization. The American Ambulance Association has noted that ground ambulance providers' current Medicare payments are lower than those calculated for 2010 due to various factors, including the expiration of a temporary increase in Medicare payments.</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) has a department-wide office, Supply Chain Integration, responsible for leading the development of DOD supply chain policies, including those for SRC I ammunition. The Army plays a prominent role in managing SRC I ammunition, as it procures a majority of the department's ammunition and provides wholesale storage for other military services. The Army depots ship SRC I ammunition owned by other military services to their respective locations at their request.

• DOD policy requires continuous program and policy oversight to ensure protection of sensitive conventional arms, ammunition, and explosives (AA&E), including SRC I ammunition. The military services have automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, which maintain various item-specific data such as serial number and production lot number. However, the Air Force does not track SRC I ammunition by serial number, but has plans to revise its guidance.

• The military services generally recorded shipment and receipt of SRC I ammunition in their accountability systems, but the Army and Marine Corps do not have guidance that requires the receipting of SRC I ammunition in a timely manner. The Air Force and Navy have policies regarding maintaining in-transit accountability for shipped SRC I ammunition, but the Army's policy and processes do not fully adhere. The Marine Corps has planned system updates to adhere to requirements.

• The military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition in the continental United States. The Army did not have timely, complete, or accurate information of its SRC I ammunition, but has taken action to improve visibility. The military services have not always entered timely information in the Defense Transportation Tracking System (DTTS) on SRC I ammunition shipments.

• The DOD concurred with all six recommendations made by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to enhance the department's policy and procedures and improve the accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition. The recommendations include revising guidance to clarify that accountability for all SRC I ammunition items in the Air Force's custody should be maintained in the Air Force's system of record. The DOD also stated that the military services and the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command will collaboratively determine the specific information required for the military services to ensure timely data entry into DTTS.</summary>

<summary>
• The Social Security Administration (SSA) is the largest single producer, collector, and user of information in the United States, with virtually billions of records. SSA collects and maintains personal information such as name, date of birth, address, and Social Security numbers (SSNs) to distinguish among individuals and ensure that people receive the services or benefits they are entitled to under the law. SSA is responsible for issuing SSNs and maintaining information on individuals' wages and earnings.

• SSA's disclosure policy is designed to protect the privacy rights of individuals to the fullest extent possible while permitting the exchange of records required to fulfill its administrative and program responsibilities. The policy has been revised to comply with about 25 statutes, including the Privacy Act of 1974, which regulates the collection, maintenance, use, and disclosure of personal information that federal agencies maintain in a system of records. The Privacy Act requires that agencies inform individuals of the authority for the collection, the principal purpose, routine uses, and consequences of not providing the information.

• SSA's disclosure policy allows the disclosure of information to law enforcement under certain conditions, such as when the criminal activity involves fraud or other crimes in Social Security programs, nonviolent crimes and criminal activity in other government programs, or violent and serious crimes. SSA may also disclose information when a person violates parole and the violent crime provisions of the original conviction have been met. SSA defines violent and serious crimes as those characterized by the use of physical force or by the threat of physical force causing actual injury.

• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than the disclosure policies of most major federal agencies, with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Census Bureau being exceptions. The IRS and Census Bureau have disclosure requirements prescribed in their statutes, which are more restrictive than the Privacy Act and the disclosure policies of most federal agencies. SSA's policy is designed to protect individuals' personal information, particularly tax information, and maintain the pledge of confidentiality that the agency made long before the Privacy Act was enacted.

• SSA's disclosure policy is contained in 20 C.F.R. Part 401 and is promulgated through regulations outlined in its "Program Operations Manual System" (POMS) and Emergency Messages. The Privacy Officer within SSA's Office of Disclosure Policy has overall responsibility for overseeing the agency's implementation of the disclosure policy. SSA field offices handle requests for disclosing information because they are at the local level where information is frequently needed.

• SSA officials have several concerns about expanding SSA's disclosure policy, including the potential for compromising individuals' privacy and

<summary>
• The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) of 1976 and its 1984 amendments aim to minimize threats to human health and the environment from hazardous waste generation, treatment, storage, and disposal. RCRA governs hazardous waste management from generation to final disposal, including waste from past industrial operations.

• RCRA's regulations apply to all hazardous waste, regardless of its source or generation method, and include provisions for identifying and listing hazardous waste. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has established criteria for identifying hazardous waste and listed specific types of waste in its regulations.

• RCRA's requirements can create disincentives for industry to clean up previously contaminated sites, increasing costs and time for cleanups and leading parties to select less aggressive remedies. The three most significant requirements under RCRA that add cost and time to cleanups are land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements.

• Land disposal restrictions and minimum technological requirements can be costly and complex, driving parties to use more stringent and expensive cleanup technologies than necessary. The requirements for permits can add time and costs to cleanups, with the process of obtaining a permit involving substantial documentation and review.

• To address these issues, EPA has proposed alternative policies and regulatory changes, including the "contained-in" policy, permit waivers, site-specific variances, and the corrective action management unit (CAMU) rule. However, these alternatives have been met with mixed reactions from stakeholders, with some finding them burdensome and others questioning their legal defensibility.

• In 1996, EPA proposed a comprehensive rule to reform RCRA's requirements for remediation waste, but the proposal was met with significant disagreements from stakeholders, leading EPA to announce plans to withdraw the rule and focus on more narrow regulatory changes. EPA has concluded that comprehensive reform can best be achieved through legislative changes to RCRA.

• Stakeholders disagree on the extent to which waste should be exempt from RCRA's requirements, as well as on EPA's legal authority to exempt waste from the requirements. Some stakeholders prefer an approach that includes all remediation waste, while others prefer a more limited approach that only exempts certain types of waste.

• EPA has acknowledged that its treatment standards under RCRA are not generally appropriate for much of the contaminated soil typically found at cleanups, and that the agency lacks research to demonstrate that alternative technologies can attain the stringent treatment levels required by RCRA. EPA has estimated that exempting relatively low-risk contaminated media from the treatment standards could reduce cleanup costs nationwide by 50%.

• The

<summary>
• The Internet has grown in importance to American businesses and consumers, serving as the host for hundreds of billions of dollars of commerce each year, and relies on the domain name system to ensure the uniqueness of each e-mail and Web site address.
• The U.S. government supported the implementation of the domain name system for nearly a decade, but began a process for transitioning the technical responsibility to the private sector in 1997, leading to the creation of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN).
• ICANN has made significant progress in increasing competition, but progress has been slower on activities designed to address stability and security, representation of the Internet community, and private, bottom-up coordination.
• The Department of Commerce has limited its public assessment of the status of the transition process, and its oversight of ICANN has been informal, with no formal record of discussions and no status reports issued.
• ICANN's president has proposed reforms, including a "well-balanced public-private partnership" with an increased role for national governments, and the Department of Commerce is gathering views from U.S. business and public interest groups, as well as other executive branch agencies.
• The Department of Commerce will need to decide whether to extend the current MOU with ICANN, amend it, or establish a new arrangement, and is recommended to issue a status report detailing its assessment of the progress made on transition tasks and the work that remains to be done.</summary>

<summary>
* Before 1996, Medicare program integrity activities were performed by insurance companies under contract with CMS, but funding constraints limited their ability to conduct audits and review medical claims. In 1996, HIPAA established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) and provided CMS with dedicated funding to conduct program integrity activities. The maximum amount of MIP funds increased from $440 million in fiscal year 1997 to $720 million in fiscal year 2003.

* MIP funds are used to support five program integrity activities: audits, medical review, secondary payer, benefit integrity, and provider education. CMS allocates MIP funds primarily to support its contractors' program integrity efforts for the traditional Medicare program. Contractors receive MIP funds to perform one or more of the five program integrity activities.

* From fiscal years 1997 through 2005, CMS generally increased the amount of funding for each of its five program integrity activities, but the amount of the funding provided and the percentage increase varied among the activities. Provider education received the largest percentage increase in funds, while audit and medical review received the largest amount of funds overall. CMS increased its allocation for provider education by about 590 percent from fiscal year 1997 through fiscal year 2005.

* CMS officials told us that they generally had allocated MIP funds to the five activities based predominantly on historical funding, but sometimes considered high-level priorities. However, this approach does not take into account data or information on the effectiveness of one activity over the other in ensuring the integrity of Medicare. CMS has not routinely collected information to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of its five program integrity activities.

* CMS has developed qualitative assessments of the impact of benefit integrity and provider education, but these activities provide value to the program in helping to ensure proper Medicare payments. Benefit integrity contributes to the work of federal law enforcement agencies, which investigate and prosecute Medicare fraud and abuse. Provider education helps reduce billing errors, according to CMS.

* CMS collects information on the relative savings from specific secondary payer functions and has used this information to decide on funding allocations within the secondary payer activity. CMS allocates funds to, and calculates savings for, about 16 secondary payer functions. Within secondary payer, for fiscal year 2005, savings for the 16 functions ranged from less than 1 percent to 49 percent of savings of over $5 billion for all of the functions.

* The Medicare program is undergoing significant changes, including the addition of the new Part D prescription drug benefit and the reform of Medicare contracting. These changes will require CMS

<summary>
• The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and the Department of Defense (DOD) have been working together to develop a comprehensive, life-long medical record for each service member since 1998. Their first initiative, the Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR) project, aimed to create an electronic interface to share patient health information between the two departments. The project was later renamed the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program and achieved one-way transfer of data from DOD to VA by 2002.

• The departments are now working towards a two-way exchange of health information through the HealthePeople (Federal) initiative, which includes the development of a common health information architecture and the creation of a virtual medical record. The Bidirectional Health Information Exchange (BHIE) and Laboratory Data Sharing Interface (LDSI) demonstration projects have shown promise in exchanging electronic medical information between the departments. However, the departments still face challenges in achieving their long-term goals, including the need for a more detailed project management plan and the resolution of data quality issues.</summary>

<summary>
• The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has been working to improve the performance of passenger and checked baggage screeners at US airports, with a focus on enhancing training and assessing screener performance. TSA has developed a basic screener training program and required remedial training, but has faced challenges in providing access to recurrent training.

• TSA has taken steps to enhance training for screeners and supervisors, including the development of an Online Learning Center with self-guided training courses and the implementation of a dual-function screener training program. However, some Federal Security Directors (FSDs) have reported difficulties in providing access to recurrent training due to insufficient staffing and lack of high-speed internet connectivity.

• TSA has established a requirement for 3 hours of recurrent training per week averaged over a quarter year, but some FSDs have reported that screeners are not receiving sufficient training due to staffing shortages and lack of connectivity. TSA has acknowledged these challenges and is taking steps to address them.

• TSA has developed leadership and technical training courses for Screening Supervisors, but some FSDs have reported that additional training is needed in areas such as leadership, communication, and supervision. TSA has also established a plan to provide Lead Screener, Screening Supervisor, and Screening Manager training based on funding availability.

• TSA has implemented a number of improvements to enhance screener performance, including the deployment of the Threat Image Projection (TIP) system and the implementation of a screener recertification program. However, these efforts have primarily focused on passenger screening, and TSA has not yet undertaken a comparable performance study for checked baggage screeners.

• TSA has established performance measures and indexes for the passenger and checked baggage screening systems, but has not yet established performance targets for the individual components of these measures. TSA plans to finalize performance targets for the indicators by the end of fiscal year 2005.

• TSA has conducted covert testing to assess screener performance, but the results of these tests cannot be generalized to all airports or screeners. TSA has also enabled FSDs to conduct local covert testing and has implemented a plan to test all airports at least once every three years.

• TSA has developed a plan to prioritize and schedule the deployment of high-speed internet connectivity to all airport training facilities, but the plan has not been provided to the Government Accountability Office (GAO). TSA has also acknowledged the need to develop internal controls to ensure that screeners receive required training.

• The GAO has recommended that TSA develop a plan to prioritize and schedule the deployment of high-speed internet connectivity

<summary>
* The IRS operates a network of 25 call sites with 10,000 customer service representatives, providing round-the-clock service to taxpayers. The network is managed as a single call center, allowing calls to be routed to sites with the shortest hold times. This approach has improved the efficiency of the call center operations.

* The IRS' Operations Center is responsible for forecasting call demand, planning call routing, developing staffing requirements, and monitoring network call traffic. The center works with call sites to ensure they meet staffing requirements and provides support to optimize service. The Operations Center also monitors site adherence to staffing requirements.

* The IRS has not established a long-term, desired level-of-service goal based on taxpayer needs and the costs and benefits of meeting them. Instead, the agency determines its funding level and then calculates the expected level of service that funding will provide. This approach is inconsistent with federal guidance on strategic planning.

* The IRS' approach to setting service-level goals is also inconsistent with industry practices, which base goals and staffing on customer needs. The agency's lack of a long-term goal makes it difficult to strategically plan and manage call center performance and measure improvement. The Government Performance and Results Act requires agencies to develop multiyear strategic plans and measure progress toward meeting long-term goals.

* The IRS has estimated the service it could provide based on different staffing levels, but these estimates are not based on a long-term goal. For example, in fiscal year 2000, the agency estimated that it could achieve a 58- to 80-percent level of service with different staffing levels. The IRS decided to request funding at the lower level, establishing a 58-percent level-of-service goal.

* The IRS recognizes the need to establish long-term goals and is considering adopting measures used by other organizations. For fiscal year 2001, the agency plans to measure the percentage of callers who reach IRS within 30 seconds. However, the IRS has not established a long-term goal for this measure.

* The six call sites visited faced challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives. Site officials cited difficulties recruiting representatives due to job characteristics, training representatives and keeping them proficient, retaining skilled representatives, and scheduling representatives to meet forecasted staffing requirements.

* The IRS is developing a national recruiting strategy to improve its recruiting efforts. The agency is identifying sites where its salary and benefits make it a competitive employer in the local job market and sites that have trouble recruiting and retaining suitable applicants. This will help the IRS determine which sites should be growth sites for hiring telephone

<summary>
• Ginnie Mae is a government-owned corporation that operates as a unit of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Its mission is to expand affordable housing in America by linking capital markets to the nation's housing markets. Ginnie Mae does not buy or sell loans or issue mortgage-backed securities, but rather provides guarantees backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. government.

• Ginnie Mae's guarantee allows investors to purchase mortgage-backed securities (MBS) that are backed by pools of government-backed loans, reducing the risk of default. The agency's guarantee also helps to increase the amount of credit available to borrowers and lower interest rates. Ginnie Mae's securities finance the great majority of FHA and VA loans.

• Ginnie Mae's market share of the total MBS market has declined significantly over the last 20 years, from 54% in 1985 to 10% in 2004. The decline is largely due to the growth of the conventional MBS market, which has increased from $64 billion in 1985 to $1.8 trillion in 2004. Ginnie Mae's new issuance of MBS has remained fairly constant, ranging from $150 billion to $200 billion annually.

• Ginnie Mae faces challenges in a number of areas, including responding to changes in the marketplace and meeting the needs of its stakeholders. The agency has expanded its product offerings and taken other initiatives to maintain its viability. Ginnie Mae must also adequately disclose loan information that MBS investors need to assess prepayment risk.

• Ginnie Mae's outstanding volume of MBS has declined in recent years due to the decline in the outstanding volume of FHA and VA loans. The decline is largely due to the growth of the conventional mortgage market, which has allowed more FHA and VA borrowers to refinance into conventional loans. Ginnie Mae's share of the government-backed mortgage market has been fairly constant.

• Ginnie Mae's securities are considered to be highly liquid, with a bid-ask spread comparable to that of Fannie Mae securities. However, some market participants have expressed concerns about the liquidity of Ginnie Mae securities, particularly for smaller trades. Ginnie Mae officials believe that the agency's securities have at least adequate liquidity.

• Ginnie Mae's revenues exceed its expenses, and the agency does not receive appropriations or borrow money to finance its credit operations. The agency's fee income is based on the principal balance of its securities portfolio, and its revenues largely depend on the volume of its outstanding securities. Ginnie Mae

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) has made progress in addressing the issues of illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments, with a significant reduction in such adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002. DOD has implemented controls to identify and prevent these types of adjustments, including upgrading its contract reconciliation system (CRS) and changing the default reallocation of adjusting payments from oldest funds first to proration. However, despite these efforts, DOD still faces long-term, major problems in accurately accounting for and reporting on disbursements. The complexity of contract accounting and frequent changes in payment allocation terms contribute to the need for adjustments.

• DOD's use of numerous appropriation control records (ACRNs) and changes in contract payment allocation terms can lead to payment errors and adjustments. A review of 101 contracts found that 38 contracts had 51 or more ACRNs, with an average of 74 ACRNs per contract. This complexity can result in costly and extensive contract reconciliations, and DOD estimates that it will take over 9,000 hours to complete the audit of one contract with 548 ACRNs. The use of numerous ACRNs and changes in payment allocation terms can also lead to errors in accounting records.

• The General Accounting Office (GAO) has identified two options for the Congress to consider in addressing the issue of closed account adjustments. The first option is to take no legislative action and allow DOD to adjust closed account records when necessary to correct accounting errors. The second option is to amend the account closing law to prohibit any adjustments to an appropriation account after it is closed. This option would eliminate adjustments to closed accounts but could also result in permanent inaccuracies in accounting records.

• DOD has agreed to reverse and correct $172 million of illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments made during fiscal year 2001. The remaining $119 million of adjustments were adequately documented corrections of errors and were not in violation of appropriations law. DOD plans to review an additional $1.1 billion of fiscal year 2001 closed account adjustments and estimates that it will take several hundred contracts and about 1,000 closed account adjustments to complete the review. DOD also plans to have the reaudits and corrections for fiscal year 2001 closed account adjustments completed by September 2004.

• The GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) to ensure that the Defense Finance and Accounting Service (DFAS) completes its

<summary>
* The federal government has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820, and the General Allotment Act of 1887 provided for the division of Indian tribal lands into allotments for individual tribal members and families. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands and extended the period that the federal government would hold allotted lands in trust.

* The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) was established in 1994 to oversee the management of Indian trust funds, and it has made significant progress in implementing trust fund management reforms. OST has implemented several key trust fund management reforms, including the Trust Funds Accounting System (TFAS) and the Trust Beneficiary Call Center.

* The Trust Funds Accounting System (TFAS) is an accounting and investment system that enables the automated production of account statements for individual Indians and tribal account holders. TFAS was deployed in August 1998 and was fully operational in May 2000.

* The Trust Beneficiary Call Center is a centralized call center that provides timely responses to beneficiaries' questions and allows them to access account information. The call center was fully operational by December 2005 and has received over 135,000 calls from beneficiaries.

* The Office of Trust Records was created in 1999 to ensure that Indian records are maintained and safeguarded. In September 2003, Interior signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the National Archives and Records Administration to create a national repository for American Indian records.

* The Trust Asset and Accounting Management System (TAAMS) is a centralized system for managing Indian trust assets, and it includes two components: the TAAMS land title system and the leasing module. TAAMS was completed in January 2006, and it is currently being integrated with TFAS.

* The Probate Case Management and Tracking System (ProTrac) is a system for managing and tracking probate cases from initiation to closing. ProTrac was developed by BIA, and it is currently being used by BIA, OST, and Interior's Office of Hearings and Appeals.

* OST has relied extensively on contractors to perform many of its trust reform activities, and it has obligated nearly 21% of its appropriated funds to contracting in fiscal years 2004 and 2005. The majority of contracting dollars went to two firms: Chickasaw Nation Industries (CNI) and SEI Investments.

* The Special Trustee has not provided the Congress with a timetable for completing the remaining trust reform activities, and it

<summary>
* The electricity industry is composed of four distinct functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations, with the operation of an electric power system requiring a system operator to constantly balance the generation and consumption of power. The industry is highly dependent on control systems, which are IT- and network-based systems that monitor and control sensitive processes and physical functions.

* The industry has begun to update the electricity grid by integrating new technologies and additional IT systems and networks, with a broader vision for transforming the electricity grid into a "smart grid" that is more reliable and efficient. This vision would increase the use of IT systems and networks and two-way communication to automate actions that system operators formerly had to make manually.

* The use of smart grid systems may have a number of benefits, including improved reliability with fewer and shorter outages, downward pressure on electricity rates, and an improved ability to detect and respond to potential attacks on the grid. However, the increased reliance on IT systems and networks also exposes the electric grid to potential and known cybersecurity vulnerabilities.

* Threats to the electricity industry and its transmission and distribution systems are evolving and growing, and can come from a wide array of sources, including unintentional and intentional threats. Risks to cyber-based assets can originate from natural disasters, defective computer or network equipment, software coding errors, and careless or poorly trained employees.

* Multiple entities have taken steps to help secure the electricity grid, including NERC, NIST, FERC, and the Departments of Homeland Security and Energy. These entities have developed and enforced cybersecurity standards, provided guidance and support, and established programs to promote the adoption of cybersecurity frameworks.

* Despite these efforts, there are still challenges to securing the electricity grid, including monitoring the implementation of cybersecurity standards, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, taking a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity, ensuring that smart grid systems have built-in security features, effectively sharing cybersecurity information, and establishing metrics for evaluating cybersecurity. Addressing these challenges will be crucial to mitigating the risk of cyber threats to the electricity grid.
</summary>

<summary>
• The federal workforce faces significant challenges, including skills gaps, retirements, and outdated personnel systems, which can impede the government's ability to serve the public and achieve results. According to OPM data, over 34% of federal employees will be eligible to retire by 2020, which could lead to gaps in leadership and institutional knowledge. Agencies must strategically monitor and manage turnover to mitigate these risks.

• The federal pay system is outdated and does not align with modern compensation principles, which prioritize skills, knowledge, and performance. The GS system has not kept pace with the government's evolving requirements, and pay decisions are often based on length of service rather than individual performance. Congress has provided exemptions to some agencies to give them more flexibility in setting pay.

• The composition of the federal workforce has changed over the past 30 years, with a greater need for professional, administrative, and technical roles. Federal jobs require more advanced skills and degrees than private sector jobs, and the federal workforce is more highly educated than the private sector workforce. This shift has implications for the design of the federal compensation system.

• Agencies face challenges in addressing poor performance, including the need for effective performance management systems and meaningful distinctions in employee performance levels. Supervisors play a critical role in performance management, and agencies should promote people into supervisory positions based on their supervisory skills. A cultural shift may be needed to acknowledge that a rating of "fully successful" is already a high bar.

• OPM has taken steps to address these challenges, including revising its strategic human capital management regulation and providing guidance to agencies on performance management. However, more work is needed to modernize the classification system, improve hiring processes, and strengthen human resource capacity. Agencies must make effective use of the tools and flexibilities available to them to improve executive branch personnel management.</summary>

<summary>
• The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) describes the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit. The auditor has a responsibility to both the audited taxpayer and all other taxpayers to conduct a quality audit. IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, which address issues such as scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management.

• Each standard has one or more key elements, and workpapers provide documentation on the scope of the audit and the diligence with which it was completed. Workpapers assist in planning the audit, record procedures applied, tests performed, and evidence gathered, and provide support for technical conclusions. They also provide the basis for review by management.

• The primary tool used by IRS to control quality under the nine standards is the review of ongoing audit work, which is the responsibility of IRS' first-line supervisors, called group managers. Group managers review audit workpapers during the audit to identify problems with audit quality and ensure that the problems are corrected. After an audit closes, IRS uses its Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) to collect information about the audit process.

• Our observations about the adequacy of the audit workpapers and supervisory review during audits are based on our work during 1996 and 1997 on IRS' use of financial status audit techniques. We relied on a random sample of individual tax returns that IRS had audited, excluding audits that were unlikely to use financial status audit techniques. The sample included 354 audits from a population of about 421,000 audits.

• We found that IRS auditors did not always meet the requirements laid out under the workpaper standard, which requires workpapers to support the auditor's conclusions and document procedures applied, tests performed, information obtained, and conclusions reached. The five key elements for this workpaper standard involve fully disclosing the audit trail and techniques used, being clear and organized, ensuring that tax adjustments agree with IRS forms, and adequately documenting the audit activity records. We found examples of problems with workpapers, such as tax adjustments not agreeing and required documents or summaries missing.

• Although we are unable to develop estimates of the overall quality of audit workpapers, IRS has historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers. Evaluations conducted as part of IRS' EQMS indicated that IRS auditors met all of the key elements of the workpaper standard in no more than 72 percent of the audits. The success rate indicates whether all of the key elements within the standard were

<summary>
* The Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program was authorized by Congress in 1983 through the Foreign Assistance Act to provide training and equipment to friendly countries to deter and counter terrorism. The program's purpose is to enhance the antiterrorism skills of partner nations, strengthen bilateral ties, and increase respect for human rights.

* ATA offers a wide range of counterterrorism assistance, including training courses and grants of equipment such as small arms and bomb detection equipment. The program's curricula and training focus on enhancing critical counterterrorism capabilities, including crisis management and response, cyberterrorism, and dignitary protection.

* The Coordinator for Counterterrorism is responsible for the overall supervision and coordination of the U.S. government's counterterrorism activities, while the Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security implements security programs to protect diplomatic personnel. The roles and responsibilities of S/CT and DS/T/ATA are described in a 1991 internal policy guidance memorandum and the Foreign Affairs Manual.

* S/CT and DS/T/ATA do not systematically use country-specific needs assessments and program reviews to plan what types of assistance to provide partner nations. The assessments have weaknesses and inconsistencies, and S/CT provides minimal policy guidance to DS/T/ATA to help determine assistance priorities.

* S/CT places countries on a tiered list in one of four priority categories based on criteria such as country-specific threats and the level of diplomatic and political engagement. However, S/CT provides little guidance to DS/T/ATA beyond the tiered list, and DS/T/ATA officials stated that they received little or no guidance from S/CT.

* The assessments and reviews conducted by DS/T/ATA do not consistently provide a basis for targeting program assistance to the areas of a partner nation's greatest counterterrorism assistance need. The assessments do not prioritize assistance to be provided or include specific timeframes for implementation.

* S/CT and DS/T/ATA have mechanisms to coordinate the ATA program with other U.S. government international counterterrorism training assistance, but the program lacks clear measures and processes for assessing sustainability. The program's principal intended outcome is to enable partner nations to achieve advanced and sustainable counterterrorism capabilities.

* State has not complied with a congressional mandate to report to Congress on U.S. international counterterrorism assistance, and recent ATA annual reports have contained inaccurate data relating to basic program information. The reports do not provide systematic assessments of program results or consistent information on program activity.

* The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has recommended that the Secretary of State revisit and revise internal guidance

<summary>
* The US government has established two programs, 18F and USDS, to improve the management of IT acquisitions and operations, with a focus on providing digital services to citizens.
* Both programs have provided a variety of development and consulting services to agencies, with a majority of surveyed agency project managers expressing satisfaction with the services provided.
* However, 18F and USDS have not fully established outcome-oriented goals, performance measures, and targets, which are essential for effective program management and accountability.
* The programs have also not fully implemented procedures for prioritizing IT projects, which could lead to inefficient use of resources and failure to address the most critical projects.
* To address these issues, recommendations have been made to GSA and OMB to ensure that goals and performance measures are outcome-oriented, and that procedures for prioritizing projects are established and implemented.</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. Bankruptcy Code provides two approaches for reorganizing or terminating a large financial company: a judicial bankruptcy process or a special resolution regime for insolvent financial entities. The goal of bankruptcy is to help individuals and businesses eliminate or restructure debts and ensure equitable treatment of creditors.

* The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the Judicial Conference of the United States, the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts (AOUSC), and the Federal Judicial Center. The Department of Justice's U.S. Trustee Program and the judiciary's Bankruptcy Administrator Program oversee bankruptcy trustees and promote integrity and efficiency in the bankruptcy system.

* Large, complex financial companies that are eligible to file for bankruptcy generally file under Chapter 11 of the Code, which allows debtors to continue some or all of their operations subject to court supervision. The debtor typically remains in control of its assets and is called a debtor-in-possession (DIP).

* The resolution of globally active large financial firms is often associated with complex international, legal, and operational challenges, including conflicting regulatory regimes and the treatment of cross-border derivatives. Insolvency laws vary widely across countries, and some resolution authorities may lack the legal tools or authority to share information with relevant foreign authorities.

* Chapter 15 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, based on the Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL), promotes coordination between courts in different countries during insolvencies. The chapter authorizes several types of coordination, including U.S. case trustees operating in foreign countries and foreign representatives having direct access to U.S. courts.

* The Financial Stability Board (FSB) and the European Union have taken steps to strengthen their regulatory structures and facilitate cross-border resolutions, including the development of principles to guide the development of resolution regimes for financial firms active in multiple countries. The FSB has also issued a set of principles to guide the development of resolution regimes for financial firms active in multiple countries.

* The U.S. government has taken steps to improve cross-border coordination, including the development of resolution plans or "living wills" for large financial companies. The Federal Reserve and FDIC have also taken regulatory actions to facilitate orderly resolution, including efforts to address potential obstacles to global cooperation.

* The bankruptcy proceedings of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., MF Global Holdings Ltd., and Washington Mutual Inc. have made progress, with distributions to creditors and ongoing litigation. However, the cases highlight the complexity and

<summary>
* The largest interagency contracting vehicle is the MAS program, also known as the Federal Supply Schedule or the schedules program, which is directed and managed by the GSA.
* Government buyers usually pay a fee for using other agencies' GWACs, MACs, and schedule contracts, which are typically a percentage of the procurement value.
* Enterprisewide contracts are similar to interagency contracts but generally do not allow purchases from the contract outside of the original acquiring activity.
* In fiscal year 2008, federal agencies spent at least $60 billion through GWACs, MACs, the MAS program, and enterprisewide contracts to buy goods and services.
* The MAS program is still the primary governmentwide buying program aimed at helping the federal government leverage its significant buying power when buying commercial goods and services.
* OMB and agencies lack reliable and comprehensive data to effectively leverage, manage, and oversee interagency and enterprisewide contracts.
* The federal government's official procurement database is not sufficient or reliable for identifying MACs and enterprisewide contracts, making it difficult to track their use.
* Vendors and agency officials expressed concerns about duplication of effort among MACs, GWACs, and enterprisewide contracts, which can result in increased costs and missed opportunities to leverage the government's buying power.
* GSA faces challenges in effectively managing the MAS program, including a lack of transactional data, limited use of pricing tools, and a decentralized management structure.
* The federal government does not have a clear and comprehensive view of who is using interagency and enterprisewide contracts and if they are being used in an efficient and effective manner.
</summary>

<summary>
* The USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) and the FDA are responsible for ensuring the safety of meat, poultry, and certain egg products, as well as all other foods, including fruits and vegetables, dairy products, seafood, and certain canned, frozen, and packaged foods.
* The food-processing sector is the middle segment of the farm-to-table continuum, extending from the time livestock and crops leave the farm for slaughter and processing into food until it reaches retail establishments.
* FDA and FSIS work to ensure the safety of food products processed in the United States through a regulatory system of preventive controls that identifies hazards early in the production process to minimize the risk of contamination.
* The Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) system makes food-processing facilities responsible for developing a plan that identifies harmful microbiological, chemical, and physical hazards that are reasonably likely to occur and establishes critical control points to prevent or reduce contamination.
