<summary>
* The study investigated the presence of motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb of patients with stroke, and the correlation between the two variables using a tracking and reposition sense test.
* Fifty hemiparetic stroke patients and 40 sex- and age-matched normal control subjects participated in the study, with the results showing significant differences in motor function and sensory function between the two groups.
* The stroke group showed a lower accuracy index in the metacarpophalangeal joint and higher error scores in the joint reposition test, indicating motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb.
* A significant correlation was found between ipsilateral sensory deficits and motor deficits, suggesting that stroke patients may have difficulty performing complicated motor tasks requiring delicate sensorimotor functions.
* The study's findings support the idea that bilateral hemisphere activation is necessary for normal motor control of the upper limb, and that disturbance of transcallosal transfer after unilateral brain damage may lead to ipsilateral sensory deficits.
* The results imply that both motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb contribute to the difficulty stroke patients experience in task performance, and that future studies should investigate the recovery of ipsilateral sensory deficits after stroke onset.</summary>

<summary>
• The goals of chronic stable angina management are to control symptoms and reduce the risk of adverse clinical outcomes, with optimal medical therapy including anti-anginal and disease-modifying therapy. Anti-ischemic agents such as nitrates, beta-blockers, and calcium channel blockers are used to reduce angina symptoms and prolong exercise duration.

• A study was conducted to evaluate the effect of sublingual nitroglycerin spray on time to onset of angina during exercise in patients with chronic stable angina. The study found a dose-dependent increase in time to onset of moderate angina following administration of nitroglycerin spray.

• The study included 51 patients who performed a baseline exercise test and qualified for continuation, with all patients showing an improvement in exercise duration of 60 seconds or greater after receiving 0.4 mg of open-label sublingual nitroglycerin spray. Two patients did not complete the study due to loss to follow-up and ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation.

• The results of the study demonstrated a significant improvement in exercise tolerance with sublingual nitroglycerin spray in patients with stable angina, with the increase in time to onset of angina and to onset of moderate angina most pronounced in the 1.6-mg group. The occurrence of a minimum 1.0-mm st-segment depression was later in all treatment groups compared with the placebo group.

• Adverse events considered related to treatment were reported for 2-26% of patients receiving placebo and 0.2-1.6 mg nitroglycerin spray, with the most frequently reported adverse events being headache and dizziness. No serious adverse events related to treatment were reported.

• The study's findings support the use of sublingual nitroglycerin spray as nitrate therapy in patients with stable angina who are being managed with optimal medical therapy, and further studies are needed to evaluate the long-term beneficial effects of using routine prophylactic nitroglycerin spray in patients with stable angina. This approach may also be beneficial for patients who have persistent angina post-revascularization.</summary>

<summary>
• A 71-year-old male patient with oral submucous fibrosis and heavy vertical fibrous bands presented with a reduced mouth opening of 2.5 cm, making prosthetic treatment challenging. The treatment plan included sectional maxillary and mandibular final impression procedures, followed by fabricating maxillary hinged and mandibular sectional and hinged complete dentures. The dentures were designed to collapse at the midline, allowing for easier insertion and removal. The patient was educated on the insertion and removal of the dentures and was recalled for follow-up visits to check for maintenance and adaptability.

• The technique used in this case involved sectional impression procedures and prosthesis designs that aid in fabrication of prostheses for patients with limited mouth opening. The advantages of this technique include simplified sectional tray design and ease of fabrication, which can be accomplished in any dental laboratory without complicated machinery. However, the technique shares disadvantages common to all sectional tray/prosthesis designs, such as additional time, labor, and materials. Periodic recall, maintenance, and further improvements in design are needed to determine the long-term success of this technique.</summary>

<summary>
• The Millennium Cohort Study is a large prospective study that collected data on health, behavioral risk factors, and occupational characteristics related to military service. The study began in 2001 and included 77,047 participants, with follow-up surveys conducted in 2004 and 2007. The study aimed to evaluate the association between sleep characteristics and incident diabetes.

• The study found that trouble sleeping, sleep duration of 5 hours or less, and sleep apnea were significantly associated with higher odds of incident diabetes. These associations persisted after adjustment for multiple mental health conditions, including PTSD and depression. The study also found that sleep apnea was associated with higher diabetes risk, independent of BMI and other sleep characteristics.

• The study's findings suggest that the associations between type 2 diabetes risk and mental health conditions and sleep characteristics may involve different pathways. The independent role of mental health conditions associated with poor quality and quantity of sleep in predicting risk of diabetes has only been addressed in a limited manner in previous research. The study's results are consistent with previous research on stress and diabetes risk.

• The study's limitations include the use of self-reported data for diabetes and sleep apnea, which may be subject to misclassification. However, the study's strengths include its large sample size, long duration of follow-up, and adjustment for multiple mental health conditions. The study's findings have implications for the prevention and management of diabetes, particularly in younger populations.</summary>

<summary>
* The associations between diabetes and cancer have been debated for over a century, with recent studies suggesting a link between type 2 diabetes and increased risk of certain malignancies, such as breast, colon, and pancreatic tumors. The role of insulin therapy, particularly long-acting insulin analogues like glargine, has raised concerns about potential mitogenic and anti-apoptotic effects on cancer cells. However, the clinical implications remain controversial, with some studies suggesting no increased risk associated with glargine compared to human insulin.
* Several epidemiologic studies have investigated the potential link between glargine and cancer risk, with mixed results. While some studies have suggested an increased risk of breast cancer associated with glargine, others have found no significant association. Further research is needed to address the relationship between diabetes, insulin, and cancer, as well as the potential protective effects of metformin and the underlying reasons for the complex associations between diabetes and cancer.</summary>

<summary>
*Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects people of all ages, with a higher prevalence in women and increasing with age.
*The prevalence of RA in Italy is estimated to be around 0.5%, with a higher prevalence in women (0.51%) than in men (0.13%).
*The annual incidence of RA in Italy is estimated to be around 0.98 per 1,000 people, with a higher incidence in women (1.42) than in men (0.51).
*The economic burden of RA in Italy is significant, with estimated annual costs ranging from €3,718 to €22,946 per patient, depending on disease severity.
*The introduction of biological agents has increased direct medical costs, but is also associated with improved disease activity, joint damage, and loss of productivity.
*The estimated mean annual cost per patient with RA in Italy is around €11,546, with direct costs accounting for 43% of the total expenditure.
*The economic impact of RA in Italy is expected to increase over the next 30 years, with estimated annual costs rising from €3.3 billion to €4 billion.
*The development of biosimilar biologics may alter the landscape of biologics and their associated costs in the future, with tight regulation required to avoid additional safety risks.
*Further research is needed to develop estimates of the economic impact of different therapeutic approaches in patients with RA in Italy, to guide treatment decisions and ensure effective spending without compromising the quality of care delivered.
</summary>

<summary>
• Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the sixth most common malignancy worldwide and the third most common cause of global cancer-related mortality. Risk factors for the development of HCC include chronic liver inflammation, autoimmune hepatitis, and environmental carcinogens. The molecular pathogenesis of HCC is multifactorial and involves dysregulation of multiple pathways, including Wnt/β-catenin, MAPK, and PI3K/AKT/MTOR. The HGF-cMET pathway plays a critical role in HCC development and progression.

• The HGF-cMET pathway is a complex signaling network that promotes cell survival, proliferation, migration, and invasion. HGF is secreted primarily by mesenchymal cells and binds to the cMET receptor, triggering autophosphorylation and downstream signaling. The HGF-cMET pathway is implicated in various solid tumors and hematopoietic-derived malignancies, including HCC. Overexpression of HGF and cMET is observed in 33% and 20-48% of human HCC samples, respectively.

• Pharmacologic cMET inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for HCC. Several cMET inhibitors are in active clinical trials, including tivantinib, cabozantinib, and foretinib. Tivantinib and cabozantinib have shown promising results in phase 2 trials, with improved time to progression and overall survival in patients with HCC. However, the predictive utility of biomarkers, such as cMET expression and phosphorylation status, is unclear.

• Ongoing trials are addressing the challenge of identifying patients most likely to benefit from cMET targeted therapy. Strategies for patient selection include quantification of tumor cMET content via immunohistochemical analysis and assessment of MET sequence status. Pharmacodynamic serum markers are also being evaluated as a strategy to assess clinical response. Innovative clinical trial designs, including enriched patient cohorts and biomarker analyses, are essential in moving forward with cMET targeted therapy for HCC.</summary>

<summary>
• The study retrospectively reviewed the radiological and clinical findings of 13 patients with a pathologically confirmed mesenchymal hamartoma of the liver. The patients were aged from 6 months to 7 years 6 months, with a mean age of 3 years 2 months.

• The tumors were classified into three types based on the extent of the cystic component on CT scans: multiseptated cystic, mixed solid and cystic, and solid. The multiseptated cystic type was the most common, accounting for 46% of the patients.

• The patients presented with abdominal distension, a palpable mass, or an incidentally detected tumor during US for other clinical indications. The serum level of alpha-fetoprotein, total and direct bilirubin level, alkaline phosphatase level, and level of transaminases were normal in all except two patients.

• The tumor occurred in the right lobe of the liver in nine patients and in the left lobe in four patients. Splenomegaly, ascites, and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy were noted in one patient with biliary atresia.

• The longest diameter of the tumors ranged from 1.8 to 20 cm, with a mean of 13.0 cm, and was larger than 10 cm in 11 patients. There was no significant difference in the size of the tumors among the three CT types.

• The amount of hepatocytes was significantly different among the multiseptated cystic, mixed solid and cystic, and solid tumors. The solid tumor also contained various amounts of mesenchymal stroma and proliferation of the small bile duct.

• A mesenchymal hamartoma is the second most common benign hepatic tumor in children and accounts for 8% of all hepatic tumors in children. Histologically, a mesenchymal hamartoma appears as a disordered arrangement of mesenchyme, bile ducts, and hepatocytes.

• The tumor can rarely occur as a solid tumor, and in this study, the tumor was totally solid in 31% of the patients. The mixed hamartoma and mesenchymal hamartoma may be in one disease spectrum, since there is some overlapping in the histological features of both hamartomas.

<summary>
* A 73-year-old Korean man presented with a perianal infestation of Amblyomma testudinarium, a large, ornate tick species that is rare in Korea but common in tropical areas.
* The patient had visited a water reservoir in a rural county in South Korea a month prior to the presentation, where he likely acquired the tick infestation.
* Histopathologic examination of the tick bite site revealed an intense skin reaction with a characteristic feeding lesion, and the tick was identified as a female adult of A. testudinarium based on morphological characteristics.
* The tick's distribution in Korea is expanding northwards, with this case being the third reported human infestation and the first in the southwestern coastal area of the Korean peninsula.
* The histopathology of the skin response to the tick infestation showed a mix of acute and chronic inflammatory reactions, with a notable "paucicellular zone" around the cement with relatively few inflammatory cells.
* The tick's salivary glands secreted eosinophilic cement material that helped attachment to the host, with the cement found mostly in the perirostral portion and little on the skin surface.</summary>

<summary>
* Adamantinoma of the tibia is a rare, slow-growing primary tumor of the bone, with approximately 300 cases reported in the English language literature. The most common site of metastasis is to the lungs, and metastases to the regional lymph nodes are rare. There is limited information regarding the best practice plan for their management in the literature.

* The relationship between osteofibrous/fibrous dysplasia and adamantinoma is a major focus of controversy, with some authors suggesting that osteofibrous/fibrous dysplasia may be a precursor lesion for adamantinomas. Adamantinoma of the tibia can be divided into two main groups based on their histology and biological behavior: classical and differentiated. Classical adamantinoma refers to the prototype cases with a predominance of epithelial tumor cells.

* Differentiated adamantinoma of the tibia has a predominance of an osteofibrous/fibrous dysplasia-like pattern with scant epithelial tumor elements and is commonly seen in an intracortical location. Many authors suggest that osteofibrous/fibrous dysplasia, a benign lesion occurring commonly in the tibia of children under 10 years of age, is related to adamantinomas. The association of fibrous dysplasia with adamantinoma was first described by Cohen et al. in 1962.

* The variant of differentiated adamantinoma is considered by some authors as a secondary reparative process that is associated with a more benign behavior and better prognosis. Distant metastases have been reported in adamantinoma of the long bones in about 15-20% of cases, which may be falsely low due to the slow-growing nature of the tumor. Regional or other distant metastases as seen in the lung are found more frequently in patients who have a history of repeated local recurrences.

* Risk factors for metastases include male sex, persistent pain, symptoms of less than five years duration, and inadequate initial treatment by biopsy curettage/excision, or resection. The only histological feature associated with an increased recurrence rate was lack of squamous differentiation. In view of the relationship between adamantinoma and osteofibrous dysplasia, Czerniak et al. proposed two biological courses that a tibial adamantinoma may follow.

* One is by the differentiated adamantinomas, which are predominantly intracortical and behave as a reparative process with a low potential to metastasize. The second,

<summary>
* Hyperhidrosis is a condition characterized by excessive sweating, primarily affecting the axillae, palms, plantar surface of the feet, and face, with intense discomfort and social, affective, and professional impacts. The condition affects 0.6 to 1.0% of the population, mainly young adults. Various treatment options are available, but they have limitations.

* Video-assisted thoracoscopic sympathetic surgery has been globally accepted as a treatment for primary palmar hyperhidrosis, with different methods including resection, transection, and clipping. The aim of this study was to compare two simplified methods for treating palmar and axillary hyperhidrosis by transecting the sympathetic chain at the level of either the third or fourth rib. Emphasis was placed on comparing the impact of sympathicotomy at r3 and r4.

* Between January 1999 and April 2009, 133 patients with primary hyperhidrosis underwent video-assisted thoracic sympathicotomy, with 62 males and 71 females, and a mean age of 22.56.5 years. The most common clinical manifestation was palmar and axillary sweating, followed by palmar sweating alone and axillary sweating alone. Patients were randomized into two therapeutic groups.

* The incidence of "moderate" to "severe" compensatory sweating was higher in the r3 group than the r4 group, with no significant difference between the two groups in terms of age, sex, and positive family history. No patient requested reoperation in either group, and no patient expressed regret after surgery. The dominating indication for sympathetic surgery is hyperhidrosis of the upper limb.

* The study suggests that r4 sympathicotomy decreases the extent of side effects but does not compromise efficacy, making it the method of choice for treating palmar and axillary hyperhidrosis. R3 and r4 have similar success rates in treating palmar and axillary hyperhidrosis. Selective sympathicotomy is an effective surgical method to eliminate compensatory sweating in the treatment of hyperhidrosis.
</summary>

<summary>
* A phase 1 study was conducted to assess the safety and tolerability of intrathecal nusinersen in children with spinal muscular atrophy, where 73 lumbar punctures were performed with a 32% incidence of adverse events, mainly headache, back pain, and post-lumbar puncture syndrome.
* The study suggests that using a 24-gauge needle or smaller, along with minimal sedation and proper patient positioning, can reduce the risk of adverse events and make intrathecal delivery of medication a safe and well-tolerated procedure for children with spinal muscular atrophy.</summary>

<summary>
* Antireflection (AR) technology plays a crucial role in the fabrication of high-efficiency solar cells by increasing light coupling into the active region of devices. Generally, a relatively low-light reflectivity can be obtained for crystalline silicon solar cells by combining surface texturization with thin-film deposition.

* To further reduce the light reflectivity for the improvement of solar cell efficiency, various nanostructures with sizes comparable to the wavelength of the utilized solar spectrum have been proposed. These nanostructures include photonic crystals, porous structures, plasmonics, and biomimetic nanostructures.

* The subwavelength structures can be nanowires, nanocones, frustum nanorods, and dielectric nanoparticles, which should be based on wide bandgap materials that cannot absorb sunlight. Zinc oxide (ZnO) material has a wide bandgap and has been popularly used in the fields of photocatalysis and optoelectronic nanodevices.

* For photovoltaic application, ZnO nanostructures as antireflective layers can be fabricated by various approaches, including pulsed laser deposition, chemical vapor deposition, and electrochemical deposition technique. A seeding and growth two-step process in zinc salt and amide mixed solutions seems quite acceptable for photovoltaics due to its low cost and good potential for scale-up.

* Experiments have shown that ZnO nanorod arrays can exhibit better antireflective properties than other oxide compounds, achieving a weighted global reflectance of 6.6% in the broadband range from 400 to 1,200 nm. However, most work on ZnO nanorod arrays as antireflective layers is performed on the naked silicon wafer.

* In this work, ZnO nanowhiskers (NWS) with different lengths were grown by the seeding and growth two-step process, and the ZnO NW technique was integrated into the fabrication of Czochralski (CZ) silicon solar cells. The density and length of ZnO NWS were optimized for the improvement of solar cell performances by controlling the time of growth.

* The result shows that the efficiency of CZ silicon solar cells can be improved by a value of 3% relatively using the ZnO NWS as the AR layer in practice. The starting samples were p-type CZ silicon solar cells fabricated by a standard process, including surface texturization, phosphorus diffusion, thin-film deposition, screen printing, and metallization.

<summary>
• Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the degeneration of dopaminergic and nondopaminergic neurons with Lewy bodies. The clinical diagnosis of PD can be challenging, especially in mild or uncertain cases. Accurate and early diagnosis is crucial for correct management and prognostication.

• Molecular imaging techniques, such as PET or single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT), have improved the diagnostic accuracy of PD and non-PD. Dopamine transporter (DAT) ligands and sympathetic innervation of the heart have become popular in clinical practice. DAT SPECT abnormalities can help support a diagnosis of degenerative parkinsonian syndromes.

• However, DAT imaging alone cannot differentiate between various types of degenerative parkinsonian syndromes with sufficient accuracy. Meta-[I]-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) myocardial scintigraphy has shown utility in assessing sympathetic cardiac nerve terminals in PD patients. The combination of DAT SPECT and MIBG scintigraphy may improve diagnostic accuracy.

• This retrospective study compared the results of SPECT studies of striatal DAT receptors and myocardial MIBG scintigraphy with clinical diagnoses in 34 patients with suspected parkinsonian syndromes. The study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy and usefulness of combined SPECT imaging in the same patient population. The patients underwent both [I]-MIBG scintigraphy and DAT SPECT within a 4-month period.

• The results showed that the individual molecular approaches had a mild test accuracy (TA) in differentiating between PD and non-PD. However, the combined use of DAT SPECT and MIBG scintigraphy was more useful for differentiating between PD and non-PD. The sensitivity and specificity of the combined approach were 86.7% and 73.7%, respectively.

• The study's limitations include a small study population and the use of clinical diagnosis as the gold standard without histopathological confirmation. The results should be confirmed in a multicenter study with a large population of pathologically diagnosed patients. The combination of DAT SPECT and MIBG myocardial scintigraphy may improve the sensitivity of PD diagnosis.

• The approach is based on commercially available radiotracers and can be used in clinical practice without short-lived PET tracers. The study's findings suggest that the combined use of DAT SPECT and MIBG scintigraphy can improve diagnostic accuracy in differentiating between PD and non-PD. Further studies

<summary>
• Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease that affects airflow and daily activities, and pharmacological treatment is essential to achieve and maintain clinical control. The most widely used approach for treating asthma is inhalation, which allows drugs to reach the lungs selectively and reduces systemic adverse effects.

• The study aimed to validate two scores for measuring patients' ability to use metered-dose inhalers (MDIs) and dry powder inhalers (DPIs), identify common errors, and determine which patients need educational programs. The study found that the most common error was the inability to hold breath for more than 10 seconds after inhalation, and that incorrect inhaler use affects drug efficacy.

• The validated scores will allow healthcare professionals to identify and correct inhaler technique errors, improve inhaler use, and provide personalized educational programs. The study's findings are clinically relevant, and the validated scores can be used to classify patients as able or unable to use their inhalers, ensuring effective pharmacological treatment.</summary>

<summary>
* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is characterized by left and/or right ventricular hypertrophy, with predominant involvement of the interventricular septum in the absence of other causes of hypertrophy. Familial HCM is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomere proteins. At least 15 genes are implicated in 55-70% of HCM, with the major genes including cardiac-myosin heavy chain, -tropomyosin, cardiac troponin T, cardiac myosin-binding protein C, cardiac troponin I, cardiac myosin regulatory light chains, and cardiac myosin essential light chains.

* Cardiac troponin T is a thin-filament protein that takes part in muscle contraction, and mutations of TNNT2 were thought to account for approximately 15% of familial HCM. Most TNNT2 mutations alter the contractile properties of cardiac muscle, especially the Ca sensitivity of force development and ATPase activity in vitro and in vivo. Previous reports have suggested that there is a more consistent relationship between certain genetic mutations and clinical outcome, allowing for the classification of benign and malignant mutations.

* To investigate mutations of TNNT2, DNA analysis was performed in 173 unrelated Japanese patients with familial HCM. Three reported mutations and a new mutation of TNNT2 were identified in 11 individuals from four families. The clinical features of patients with TNNT2 mutations varied, with some showing mild cardiac hypertrophy and others showing severe cardiac hypertrophy and a high incidence of sudden death.

* In family A, all five members who carried or were suspected of having HCM also had arrhythmia, and two of them died suddenly. The proband and her elder brother had the double reported mutations, Arg130Cys and Phe110Ile, of TNNT2. Her father, who had arrhythmia and mild HCM, had the Phe110Ile mutation, and her mother had the Arg130Cys mutation.

* In family B, three of 10 members who carried or were suspected of having HCM were thought to have obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The proband showed apical hypertrophy and apical aneurysm at a comparatively young age, and her aunt died suddenly at the age of 19 years. Her grandmother, her son, and her cousin, who carried HCM, had an Arg92Trp mutation of TNNT2.

<summary>
• Schistosomatidae, a family of digenetic endoparasites, includes several species that infect humans and animals, causing schistosomiasis. The most studied genus is Schistosoma, which includes six species that infect humans: S. haematobium, S. intercalatum, S. japonicum, S. malayensis, S. mansoni, and S. mekongi.

• Schistosomiasis is a chronic and debilitating disease considered one of the most serious public health issues, with 237 million people requiring treatment worldwide. The disease is endemic in 77 countries, and its transmission is dependent on the existence and distribution of intermediate hosts.

• The control of schistosomiasis represents a great challenge and is based on drug treatment, snail control, improved sanitation, and health education. The development of powerful and scalable methods to analyze nucleic acids and proteins has changed the way biological data is surveyed.

• The Schistosoma genome sequence data has been made available, and comparative analyses across different species have become possible. The genome-wide analysis has corroborated previous genetic studies and supports the evolutionary hypothesis of S. haematobium and S. mansoni as the most related species.

• Mitochondrial genes have been used as molecular markers for species and strain identification, which is key to various studies such as phylogenetics, population genetics, biogeography, and molecular ecology. The analysis of the whole mitochondrial genome of diverse taxa has changed the perspective of such studies.

• Phylogenomics has allowed the identification and characterization of all eukaryotic protein kinases encoded in the S. mansoni genome and improved the functional annotation of over 40% of them. Phylogenomics has also unraveled the distinct evolutionary histories of three expanded endopeptidase families in S. mansoni.

• Transcriptomic analyses are valuable for studies of differential regulation in gene expression and the identification of splicing variants. Transcriptomics is also a key approach to study posttranscriptional regulatory mechanisms such as alternative and transsplicing.

• The increasing information on Schistosome genomes and transcriptomes is now raising the possibilities to better explore molecular techniques in the field of parasitology, genomics, and computational biology. User-friendly databases have been created and made publicly available to the scientific community to accelerate parasite research and development of effective tools for schistosomiasis diagnostics and treatment.
</summary>

<summary>
• The optimal surgical strategy for resectable synchronous colorectal liver metastases (SCLM) remains controversial, with simultaneous resection and staged resections being considered. Simultaneous resection can simplify and shorten the treatment schedule, but it may also increase the risk of postoperative complications. The study aimed to determine the predictive factors for postoperative morbidity and anastomotic leakage after simultaneous resection for SCLM.

• The study analyzed the medical records of 86 patients who underwent simultaneous resection of primary and hepatic tumors for SCLM between 1992 and 2004. The patients' median age was 59 years, and the primary tumor was staged as T3 in 63% and T4 in 37% according to the TNM classification. The mean diameter of the primary tumor was 55 mm, and liver metastases were solitary in 29 patients and multiple in 57 patients.

• Postoperative complications were significantly correlated with the presence of a diverting stoma, duration of operation greater than 8 hours, amount of intraoperative blood loss, and intraoperative blood transfusion. Only a greater amount of blood loss had a predictive value for increased occurrence of postoperative complications. Anastomotic leakage was significantly correlated with lateral lymph node dissection, primary site of rectum, duration of operation greater than 8 hours, and amount of intraoperative blood loss.

• Multivariate analyses revealed operation time greater than 8 hours as the only independent predictive factor for anastomotic leakage after simultaneous resection of SCLM. The extent of hepatectomy, timing of anastomosis and hepatectomy, and usage of the Pringle maneuver did not correlate with the occurrence of complication or anastomotic leakage. The overall survival rate after simultaneous resection for SCLM was 61% at 3 years and 45% at 5 years, with a median survival time of 47 months.

• The study suggests that staged resections should be considered when simultaneous resection would involve excessive surgical stress, such as predicted operation time greater than 8 hours. A prospective study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the operation time-based decision model is in progress. Comparison of the ratio of patients who could receive adjuvant chemotherapy will be essential when comparing the efficacy of simultaneous resection and staged resections in a future study of SCLM.

• The limitations of the study include its retrospective design and the relatively small number of patients studied. The morbidity

<summary>
* Osteoarthritis (OA) in the knee joint is a common cause of functional disability and lowered quality of life in older adults in India. The severity of OA can be influenced by factors such as age, height, weight, and BMI.
* Physiotherapists use self-reported questionnaires and performance-based tests to monitor prognosis in OA knee rehabilitation, with the goal of improving pain, symptoms, activities of daily living (ADL), and quality of life (QOL).
* Self-reported questionnaires, such as KOOS, provide subjective information about the disease process, while performance-based tests, such as the 6-minute walk test (6-MWT), objectively measure a patient's ability to perform ADL activities.
* The present study aimed to investigate the correlation between KOOS subscales and objective measures, including 6-MWT, age, height, weight, and BMI, in patients with primary OA knee.
* The results showed a strong correlation between KOOS subscales and 6-MWT, as well as with weight and BMI, but a weak correlation with age and height. The study's findings are consistent with previous studies and support the use of KOOS in Indian OA knee patients.
* The study's results also suggest that BMI is significantly correlated with pain, symptoms, and ADL, and that weight gain is associated with worsening pain, stiffness, and function in knee pain patients.</summary>

<summary>
• Bacteriocins are ribosomally synthesized antimicrobial peptides produced by bacteria, with potential use as natural and nontoxic food preservatives and in human and veterinary applications. They can have activity across genera, and their antimicrobial sensitivity can depend on ecological conditions. The classification of gram-positive bacteriocins is difficult due to their heterogeneity, and classification schemes have had to evolve. Bacteriocins can be classified into four classes, including lantibiotics, small heat-stable nonlanthionine-containing membrane-active peptides, large heat-labile proteins, and complex proteins.

• Enterococcus strains have been characterized as antagonists of a broad range of foodborne pathogens, and their bacteriocins have displayed heterogeneous structures and differences in their mode of action. Many enterococcal strains have been isolated from different types of food, broilers, and animal secretions. Some bacteriocins have exhibited high activities against a broad spectrum of bacteria, including gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. The ability to produce bacteriocins may play a role in providing an ecological advantage.

• Enterocin S37 was isolated from poultry feces and showed antagonism against strains belonging to Listeria and Campylobacter species. The antibacterial activity of Enterocin S37 was assessed against gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria, and it displayed activity against E. faecalis JH2-2, Lb. brevis F145, L. monocytogenes EGDe, and L. innocua F. The activity observed against strains of Enterococcus genus is interesting for generating novel knowledge on immunity proteins and cross-resistance within this genus. Enterocin S37 was purified by a three-step method, including ammonium sulfate precipitation and two RP-HPLC steps.

• The stability of Enterocin S37 remained intact after heating treatments and at pH values ranging from 4 to 9. Attempts to reduce putative disulfide bridges of Enterocin S37 were performed with dithiothreitol, but the experiment was not conclusive due to toxicity towards the target strains. The bacteriocin appeared to have a molecular weight comprised between 4 and 6 kDa, and its activity increased several folds during the purification process. The spectrum of partially purified Enterocin S37 was the same as that observed with CFS, but with stronger activities.

• The effect of K channel modulators on Enterocin activity was revealed in this research, using two K channel activators

<summary>
* This systematic review examined the methodological quality of studies determining the psychometric properties of outcome measures used in stroke self-management interventions (SMIs) according to the COSMIN checklist. The review found that 43 different outcome measures were adopted by studies, but none scored in every category of COSMIN. Only 21 measures (49%) demonstrated some properties in stroke populations, and the majority of measures scored poorly due to inadequate sample sizes or lack of involvement of users in the development of the measure.

* The review highlights the need for further conceptualization of stroke self-management to ensure that self-management strategies pertinent to people recovering from stroke are captured in existing or new outcome measures. Physical function was the most commonly used indicator of effective self-management, but its role in stroke self-management requires further clarification. The review also found that measures developed without user-involvement have questionable meaning and other types of validity. There is a need to focus on the development of measures of self-management developed with people recovering from stroke.

* The review recommends that clinicians and researchers seeking to evaluate stroke SMIs should clarify the theoretical premise of the intervention and select outcome measures that appropriately reflect and capture the expected outcome change. Further work is warranted to conceptualize stroke self-management and examine the theoretical premises supporting such interventions, and expected outcomes. The selection of outcome measures developed with involvement from the target population is also advocated to ensure that what is meaningful to the patient is more likely to be captured appropriately. Researchers must support clinicians by conducting further work to examine the concept and theoretical premises of self-management and developing appropriate measures if required.</summary>

<summary>
• The oral route is a preferred route of drug administration due to its safety, ease of administration, and acceptability by patients, with about 60% of conventional dosage forms available as oral solid dosage forms.
• Fast dissolving tablets have attracted attention due to the difficulty of swallowing tablets, especially for people with motion sickness, coughing, or other conditions that make it hard to drink water.
• Orally dissolving strips are a more advanced form of oral solid dosage form, offering more flexibility and comfort, and improving the efficacy of active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) by dissolving quickly in the oral cavity.
• Clobazam is a well-tolerated, safe, and effective antiepileptic drug with minimal side effects, making it an ideal candidate for an orally dissolving strip formulation.
• A 3 factorial design was used to optimize the formulation of clobazam orally dissolving strips, with the film prepared using 100 mg of polyvinyl acetate (PVA) and 6% of sodium starch glycolate (SSG) showing the highest dissolution rate and suitable in vitro disintegration time.
• The optimized formulation (F6) was comparable to the marketed formulation (Frisium 5) in terms of in vitro drug release and showed no significant difference in pharmacokinetic parameters in vivo.
• The orally dissolving strips of clobazam prepared using PVA as film-forming material and SSG as disintegrant by the solvent-casting method showed satisfactory drug dissolution and acceptable physicomechanical characteristics.
• The prepared formulation was stable up to 6 months at 40°C (75% RH), with an average clobazam content of 95.1 ± 0.17 mg, indicating its potential usefulness for the treatment of epileptic attacks.</summary>

<summary>
• The study aimed to investigate the contribution of celiac disease (CD) and Helicobacter pylori (HP) infection to lymphocytic gastritis (LG) and to characterize the different immunoprofiles of the gastric inflammatory cells involved in these diseases. The results showed that CD patients with associated HP infection had a lower rate of LG, and the number of CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) was significantly higher in CD patients compared to controls or HP-infected patients without CD.
• The study suggests that in young patients infected by HP with suspicion of having atypical CD, the number of CD8+ IELs in the antrum might hint towards the diagnosis of CD rather than HP infection, and the number of lymphoid follicles directs towards the diagnosis of HP infection. Immunohistochemical analysis of CD8 lymphocytes in the antrum may be useful in undefined cases of CD.</summary>

<summary>
* The main concern in healthcare is to ensure the highest possible standard for services provided, and clinical governance (CG) was introduced in the UK in 1997 as a strategy for improving healthcare quality. The Iranian Ministry of Health and Medical Education (MOHME) applied CG as a framework for improving quality and safety in all hospitals since 2009.

* The CG model developed in Iran consists of seven interlocking components, including clinical effectiveness, clinical audit, risk management, patient and public involvement, education and training, staff and staff management, and use of information. Systems awareness, leadership, ownership, teamwork, and communication are considered the foundation of this model.

* A qualitative research study was conducted to capture both facilitators and barriers in CG implementation from the viewpoint of curative deputies in Iranian medical universities. The study used face-to-face interviews and relevant document reviews as the main information sources.

* The study found that senior managers accepted that improving quality of healthcare should be integral to their role and essential to safeguard patient care. They believed that quality improvement is a strategic goal to achieve central government targets.

* The findings demonstrated the willingness to support and positive attitude towards clinical governance, and senior managers declared that having adequate knowledge about clinical governance and a positive attitude towards the necessity of the program are the main factors affecting CG implementation.

* The study identified five main themes, including knowledge and attitude, culture, organizational factors, managerial factors, and barriers, which influence CG implementation. The domains were classified based on senior managers' perceptions about the important factors in implementing clinical governance.

* The main identified obstacles were lack of adequate managerial support, resources, structural and cultural issues, and professional boundaries. The study's results are parallel with the findings of many other studies, including a model developed by O'Brien et al.

* The study's findings highlighted the importance of supporting culture, appropriate organizational structure, and managerial commitment as perceived facilitators in CG implementation. The necessity of physicians and medical staff participation in clinical governance programs was also emphasized.

* The authors concluded that developing educational courses and workshops, developing a supportive culture, having all levels of staff commitment and involvement, effective communication, developing clinical guidelines, using incentive tools, and overcoming legal challenges are possible solutions to facilitate CG implementation.
</summary>

<summary>
* Hydatid cyst disease is a significant zoonotic disease caused by the larval stage of the Echinococcus granulosus parasite. Canines, such as dogs, wolves, foxes, and jackals, are the final hosts, while herbivores and humans are intermediate hosts. The disease is common in many parts of the world, especially in countries with animal husbandry practices.

* The parasite is spread through contaminated soil, water, and vegetables, and humans can become infected through accidental ingestion of contaminated food or direct contact with infected dogs. The disease can affect various organs, including the lungs and liver, and its symptoms depend on factors such as age, gender, infection severity, and cyst size. Epidemiological, clinical, and pathological symptoms of the disease vary widely.

* The disease is prevalent in many tropical regions, including Argentina, Peru, East Africa, Central Asia, China, and South America. In endemic regions, the incidence rate can reach over 50 per 100,000 person-years, with a prevalence rate of 5-10% in humans. Hydatidosis is considered one of the most important human diseases with significant health and economic burdens.

* Iran is considered a hyper-endemic area due to its close relationship with animals, traditional animal husbandry, and contact with sources of infection. The prevalence rate of the disease in intermediate hosts has been reported to be 11.5-34.6%, while the prevalence rate in humans has been reported to be 1.1-13.7% in different parts of Iran. Assessment of the disease's epidemiological and clinical aspects can help health policymakers focus on public health problems.

* A cross-sectional study was conducted in Khorasan Razavi Province, Iran, to determine the epidemiological and clinical status of human hydatidosis. The study population consisted of all cases with hydatid cysts diagnosed in governmental and private laboratories, hospitals, and health centers in the province during 2011-2014. Data collection was performed using a checklist, and descriptive and analytical statistics were used for data analysis.

* The study found that 357 hydatid cyst cases were registered in health centers during the study period, with the most percentage of cases related to the cities of Mashhad, Ghoochan, Neishabour, and Fariman. The majority of patients (54.9%) were women, and the mean age of women was higher than that of men. The most common symptom was abdominal pain, followed by hepat

<summary>
* Friederich is credited with describing the first case of a ciliated hepatic foregut cyst (CHFC) in 1857 and positing their congenital origin. Wheeler and Edmonson were the first to use the term CHFC to describe the lesion and identified specific characteristics that differentiate it from other hepatic cysts.

* CHFCs are rare, with only 103 cases reported since 1857, and are thought to be the result of evagination of the foregut during embryonogenesis. The majority of cases have been reported in the last 25 years, with improved imaging techniques.

* CHFCs are most frequently located superficially in the median segments of the liver, are rarely multi-loculated or septated, and are mostly asymptomatic. They are typically solitary and unilocular, with four layers: an outer fibrous rim, a layer of smooth muscle, subepithelial connective tissue, and a lining of ciliated, pseudo-stratified, mucin-secreting columnar epithelium.

* The imaging appearances of CHFCs are variable, appearing as anechoic or hypoechoic cysts with spotty hyperechoic areas on ultrasound, and non-enhancing, rounded lesions of varying density on CT. Typical magnetic resonance imaging features are a hyperintense cyst on T2-weighted images and a variable appearance on T1-weighted images.

* Histologically, the differential diagnosis of a hepatic cyst includes simple cyst, hydatid cyst, biliary cystadenoma, cystadenocarcinoma, and bronchogenic cyst. The main differential diagnosis can be bronchogenic cyst because both cystic lesions share a common embryonic origin.

* The recommended treatment of CHFC has varied from observation to aspiration to surgical excision, but most authors agree that CHFCs should be surgically excised for cysts larger than 4-5 cm, symptomatic or enlarging lesions, and asymptomatic lesions with wall abnormalities on imaging. Laparoscopic approach is a minimally invasive approach that can be utilized effectively to stop cyst growth.

* Laparoscopic excision is a suitable treatment option for CHFCs, especially for lesions in segments II to VI, where visualization and access are easiest. The subcapsular location and the presence of a thick outer fibrous layer in the cyst wall make it amenable to laparoscopic excision with minimal morbidity.
</summary>

<summary>
• The REVIVE survey highlights the prevalence of vulvar and vaginal atrophy (VVA) among postmenopausal women, with 38% of respondents reporting symptoms such as vaginal dryness, dyspareunia, and local irritation. Despite its commonality, many women have low awareness and poor understanding of VVA, with almost half never discussing their symptoms with a healthcare provider (HCP).
• The survey emphasizes the need for improved communication between women and HCPs, as well as proactive patient education on the physical changes underlying VVA and its treatment options. By engaging in open discussions and providing individualized care, HCPs can help bridge the communication gap and improve patient adherence and satisfaction with VVA treatment.</summary>

<summary>
• Angiogenesis, the process of forming new blood vessels, is crucial for the growth of solid tumors, and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a primary stimulant of angiogenesis. Inhibiting VEGF has been shown to be an effective therapeutic target in cancer treatment, with several VEGF inhibitors approved by the US Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of tumors or age-related macular degeneration.

• Anti-VEGF therapy has been shown to reduce tumor size, microvessel density, and macrophage infiltration in orthotopic models of breast cancer, and also modulates immune cell infiltration, including myeloid-derived suppressor cells, dendritic cells, and neutrophils. The combination of anti-VEGF therapy with conventional chemotherapy has been tested in clinical trials, and preventive angioinhibitory therapy may also be possible in the future due to its lower toxicity and susceptibility to acquired drug resistance.</summary>

• Obesity is a chronic inflammatory disease with a multifactorial etiology, including eating habits, sedentary lifestyle, and genetic predisposition. Adipose tissue secretes proinflammatory factors like interleukin 6 (IL-6), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), and leptin, as well as anti-inflammatory factors like interleukin 10 (IL-10) and adiponectin. A high-fat diet promotes metabolic changes, inducing the production of proinflammatory interleukins and a chronic inflammatory process. The presence of large concentrations of endotoxins and saturated fatty acids in the diet activates toll-like receptor 4 (TLR-4), triggering the production of proinflammatory cytokines.

• Menopause is defined as the permanent cessation of menstruation due to loss of ovarian function, leading to adverse changes in lipoprotein profiles, glucose and insulin metabolism, body fat distribution, clotting, and vascular endothelium. The loss of estrogen production promotes these changes, placing women at a high risk of developing cardiovascular diseases. Estrogen exerts an anti-inflammatory effect on the vasculature through antioxidant effects, generation of nitric oxide, prevention of apoptosis in vascular cells, suppression of proinflammatory cytokines, and modulation of the renin-angiotensin system. However, controversy persists as to whether the effects of estrogens are anti- or proinflammatory.

• This study evaluated the effects of a high-fat diet with or without ovariectomy on the inflammatory process in rats. The results showed that administration of a hyperlipidic diet for 8 weeks combined with short-term ovariectomy promoted an increase in body weight gain and a decrease in metabolic efficiency, accompanied by hyperleptinemia. The cytokine content of the liver and gastrocnemius muscle was unchanged, but levels of all cytokines analyzed were decreased in mesenteric adipose tissue. Ovariectomy in rats fed a hyperlipidic diet caused hyperleptinemia and increased body weight gain, food efficiency, and carcass lipid content.

• The combination of a high-fat diet and ovariectomy may cause a decrease in energy expenditure and an increase in adipose tissue deposits, probably via enhanced uptake of triglycerides from chylomicrons. Estrogen replacement has been shown to decrease food intake and restore weight in ovariectomized rats, suggesting that estrogen is involved in the modulation of energy homeostasis. <summary>
• Hemoptysis is a common symptom in patients with respiratory diseases, with a mortality rate of over 50% when massive. Bronchial artery embolization (BAE) is a safe and effective treatment for massive, chronic, or recurrent hemoptysis. The procedure involves a complete angiography of the pulmonary vascular tree, followed by embolization therapy when bleeding bronchial arteries are seen. BAE has been widely used since 1974, and its success rate is similar to that of surgery.

• A retrospective study of 344 patients who underwent BAE at Tianjin Haihe Hospital between 2006 and 2013 was conducted to determine the demographic characteristics, clinical features, and outcomes of the procedure. The patients were hospitalized due to hemoptysis, with a mean age of 57 years old and a range of 17-83 years old. There were 186 men and 158 women, with 234 patients having acute and massive hemoptysis and 110 patients having chronic and recurrent hemoptysis. The data for outcome analysis were obtained from clinical records and radiological images.

• The etiologies of hemoptysis in the 344 cases were tuberculosis (55.2%), bronchiectasis (28.8%), malignancy (5.8%), undefined (5.2%), pneumonia (1.8%), deformity of bronchial artery (1.8%), bronchial artery aneurysm (0.2%), and other pulmonary disease (1.2%). BAE was successful in controlling hemoptysis immediately in 330 of 344 patients (96%). Recurrent hemoptysis occurred in 61 patients (17.7%) within 1 month after undergoing BAE, and a second embolization procedure was performed in three patients. The main responsible vessels for bleeding were right bronchial arteries, left bronchial arteries, combined right and left bronchial trunk, and right intercostal arteries.

• The complications of BAE included subintimal dissection, arterial perforation by a guidewire, and reflux of embolic material into the artery without adverse sequelae during the procedure. Fever, chest pain, dyspnea, transient dysphagia, groin hematoma, and headache or blindness were also reported. However, the symptoms were transient and disappeared within 48 hours. A spinal artery was identified in three patients, and the procedure was modified to avoid embolizing the spinal artery.

<summary>
• Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is a condition where the arteries in the lower extremities narrow due to atherosclerosis, increasing the risk of coronary and cerebral vascular events. The most common symptom of PAD is intermittent claudication, which affects around 5% of individuals over 60 years old. Oxidative stress and high blood cholesterol levels are also associated with PAD. Statins, lipid-lowering drugs, have been shown to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in patients with PAD.

• A study was conducted to evaluate lipid peroxidation parameters and total antioxidant capacity in patients with PAD before and after surgery, as well as in patients receiving simvastatin therapy. The results showed that patients with PAD had enhanced oxidative stress and higher levels of malondialdehyde (MDA) before surgery. Simvastatin therapy was found to reduce MDA levels and improve antioxidant capacity. However, surgical treatment did not significantly decrease lipid peroxidation parameters.

• The study suggests that statin therapy may be beneficial in reducing oxidative stress and improving antioxidant capacity in patients with PAD. The results also highlight the importance of antioxidant enzymes and non-enzymatic antioxidants in protecting against oxidative damage. Further studies are needed to clarify the mechanisms involved in PAD and the relative importance of lipid-related and nonlipid-related effects of statins. The study's findings support the use of statin therapy in patients with PAD to reduce cardiovascular risk.</summary>

<summary>
* In Denmark, women planning to conceive are advised to take a daily supplement of 400g folic acid (FA) until the 12th week of gestation to reduce the risk of neural tube defects (NTDs). Despite campaigns promoting the FA recommendation, women in the preconceptional period appear to have neither adequate dietary intake of folate nor adequate supplementation from FA tablets or multivitamin (MV) supplements.

* A study was conducted to estimate the prevalence of FA and MV supplement use and identify sociodemographic, lifestyle, reproductive, and medical predictors of such use among Danish pregnancy planners. The study was a cross-sectional analysis of baseline data from an internet-based prospective cohort study of Danish pregnancy planners, "Snart-Gravid" (Soon Pregnant).

* The study found that 62.1% of the 5383 pregnancy planners used FA or MV supplements, with 7.7% using FA supplements exclusively, 20.4% using MV supplements exclusively, and 34.0% using both. The prevalence of FA or MV use was higher among women who finished high school, had higher vocational training, and had higher total monthly household income.

* The study also found that women who had pap smears once or more during the last 3 years were more likely to use FA or MV supplements compared with women who did not have pap smears. Women who engaged in physical activity were more likely to use FA or MV supplements than sedentary women.

* The study found that women with a previous spontaneous abortion were more likely to use FA or MV supplements, and that women who had intercourse frequency of 1 time or more per week were more likely to use FA or MV supplements. Women who had a higher alcohol intake were less likely to use FA or MV supplements.

* The study found that women with a higher body mass index (BMI) were less likely to use FA or MV supplements, and that women who smoked were less likely to use FA or MV supplements. Women who had a higher education level were more likely to use FA or MV supplements.

* The study's findings are consistent with previous studies that found that maternal age, education, income, smoking, and BMI were associated with preconception FA use. However, the study found little association between parity and FA use.

* The study highlights the need to target women at high risk of not following the FA recommendation, as well as those not following other preconceptional guidelines. Being diagnosed with a chronic disease was not associated with increased

<summary>
* The endoscopic injection of dextranomer/hyaluronic acid copolymer (DX/HA) is a minimally invasive treatment option for vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), with success rates ranging from 75-80%, although it is lower than the 98% success rate of open reimplants.
* Intraoperative positional instillation of contrast (PIC) cystography can detect occult VUR and prevent postoperative contralateral new onset of VUR, but it cannot replace postoperative studies due to its 80% correlation with postoperative voiding cystography (VCUG) results.</summary>

<summary>
• Glaucoma is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by the loss of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and optic nerve atrophy. Müller cells, a type of glial cell, play a crucial role in retinal function and are involved in the pathogenesis of glaucoma. Activation of Müller cells can lead to the production of tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), contributing to neurodegeneration in glaucoma.

• The study found that -aminoadipic acid (AAA) treatment attenuated Müller cell gliosis and reduced retinal TNF-α levels in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension (AOH), leading to the protection of RGCs. AAA treatment also rescued RGCs from apoptosis and reduced the number of TUNEL-positive cells. These findings suggest that AAA may be a potential therapeutic target in the treatment of neurodegeneration in glaucoma.</summary>

<summary>
* Laparoscopy-assisted endoscopic full-thickness resection with ligation device (LAEFTR-L) is a new technique for treating nonampullary superficial duodenal neoplasms (SDNs). This method combines the benefits of laparoscopic and endoscopic approaches to achieve complete resection without exposing the abdominal cavity to malignant cells.
* The LAEFTR-L procedure involves mobilizing the duodenum, identifying the target lesion, ligating the tumor, and resecting it under the ligation band using a snare technique. The specimen is then retrieved intraluminally using the endoscope, and the defect in the duodenal wall is closed with sutures.
* The study reports on the successful treatment of 5 consecutive patients with nonampullary SDNs using LAEFTR-L, with a mean operative time of 173 minutes and no complications. The mean diameter of the resected specimen was 24 mm, and complete resection was achieved in all cases.
* LAEFTR-L has two advantages over conventional full-thickness resection (FTR) procedures: it avoids contact with the peritoneum, reducing the risk of intraperitoneal tumor dissemination, and it does not require proficient experience in endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD). However, additional studies are needed to further evaluate the efficacy and safety of LAEFTR-L procedures.</summary>

<summary>
* Lung cancer is the third most common cancer diagnosed and the leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States, with 226,160 patients diagnosed and 160,340 deaths estimated in 2012.
* Bone metastasis is a common complication of lung cancer, occurring in 19.8% of patients 65 years or older with newly diagnosed lung cancer, and is associated with increased mortality.
* Skeletal-related events (SREs) such as fractures, radiotherapy to bone, surgery to bone, and spinal cord compression occur in 51% of patients with bone metastasis.
* Radiotherapy to bone is the most common SRE, followed by fracture, spinal cord compression, and surgery to bone.
* Pathological fractures occur in 13% of patients with SREs, with the spine being the most common site of occurrence.
* Having a bone metastasis is associated with mortality among lung cancer patients, with a hazard ratio of 2.4 compared to patients without bone metastasis.
* The association between bone metastasis and mortality is similar for bone metastasis complicated by SRE and for bone metastasis without SRE.
* The study's findings highlight the importance of considering bone metastasis and SREs in the management of lung cancer, particularly in elderly patients.</summary>

<summary>
* The demand for herbal remedies in Nigeria has been increasing, but there is a lack of scientific data to support their medicinal claims. Many herbal formulations are being promoted and marketed without scientific evidence of their safety and efficacy. This has raised concerns about the potential health risks associated with their use.

* A study was conducted to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a popular herbal remedy called FJK, which is prepared from a mixture of 13 medicinal plants. The study aimed to determine the effect of oral and repeated exposure to FJK on rat plasma biochemical indices and liver morphology. The results showed that FJK caused significant changes in rat plasma biochemical indices, including a decrease in total protein and an increase in triglyceride levels.

* The study also found that FJK caused a significant increase in the atherogenic index, which is a predictor of cardiovascular disease risk. The levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) increased, while the levels of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) decreased. This suggests that FJK may increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.

* The study also evaluated the effect of FJK on liver function and found that it caused significant changes in liver enzymes, including an increase in alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels. The levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) decreased, which may indicate liver damage. The histopathological examination of liver sections showed evidence of liver damage, including hemorrhage, ruptured vascular channels, and hyperemia.

* The study concluded that FJK may pose a risk to human health, particularly with regards to cardiovascular disease and liver damage. The results highlight the need for further research on the safety and efficacy of herbal remedies, particularly in developing countries where they are widely used. The study also emphasizes the importance of regulating the use of herbal remedies to ensure their safe use.</summary>

<summary>
• The study aimed to compare the effect of photodynamic diode laser and other smear layer removal methods on the bond strength of self-adhesive cement. The results showed that different smear layer removal methods from root canal dentin affect the bond strength of a fiber post cemented with adhesive resin to dentin.

• The study used 55 maxillary central incisors, which were extracted due to periodontal problems, and were divided into 5 experimental groups of 11 teeth each. The post spaces were treated with different methods, including physiological saline, sodium hypochlorite, EDTA, orthophosphoric acid, and photodynamic diode laser.

• The results showed that the higher bond strength values were obtained for the helbo theralite laser and 37% orthophosphoric acid groups. The null hypothesis was rejected, indicating that different smear layer removal methods affect the bond strength of self-adhesive cement.

• The study found that the photodynamic diode laser group showed post-cement failure, while the other groups showed mixed failures. The results suggest that using the photodynamic diode laser in post space increased the bond strength of resin cement to dentin interface.

• The study concluded that removal of the smear layer and formation of the resin-dentin interdiffusion zone are important for post restoration success. The results also suggest that modifying the smear layer may be more effective when a self-adhesive system is used.</summary>

<summary>
* The study examined the relationship between dietary and physical activity behaviors and self-rated health (SRH) in a population of adults from Miami-Dade County, Florida, primarily minorities, half of whom were from a diverse Hispanic population. The results showed that modifiable lifestyle behaviors known to reduce cardiovascular disease risk, low fruits and vegetables intake and high fat intake, were associated with poor/fair SRH in males and females. Females who consumed 2 servings of fruits and vegetables per day were 2.1 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH as compared to those who consumed 5 servings per day. Females who consumed mostly high fat foods were 1.5 times more likely to report poor/fair SRH as compared to those who had primarily low fat foods.

* The study also found that physical activity was significantly associated with SRH in females only, and low physical activity was also more common in women than men in this study sample. Females who engaged in less physical activity were more likely to report poor/fair SRH as compared to those who were more physically active. The association of physical activity and SRH was no longer significant for males once adjustment variables were added. The results indicate that gender differences may have implications in designing and monitoring lifestyle interventions to prevent cardiovascular diseases.

* The study's findings are consistent with previous studies that have found a strong association between physical activity and SRH, regardless of gender. However, the study's results also suggest that the impact of physical activity on health status may vary according to gender, with women being more likely to rate their health worse due to lack of physical activity. The study's limitations include the inability to establish causality of lifestyle behaviors with SRH due to the single time point and the lack of data on other factors that may have influenced SRH. Despite these limitations, the study's results highlight the importance of promoting healthy lifestyle behaviors to improve SRH and reduce cardiovascular disease risk.</summary>

<summary>
* Identifying carriers of autosomal recessive or X-linked disorders before pregnancy can benefit prospective parents by allowing them to become aware of possible genetic risks and reproductive options. Carrier screening and carrier testing are two approaches to identifying carriers, with screening being offered to individuals without an increased risk and testing being offered to those with a higher risk based on personal or family history. Carrier screening can be offered individually or as part of an organized screening program, either during or before pregnancy. The goal of preconceptional carrier screening is to strengthen reproductive autonomy and informed decision-making.

* Commercial companies have started offering preconceptional carrier tests directly to consumers, which has raised concerns about the desirability of these activities. These tests provide information about monogenic diseases and the risk of having affected offspring, but concerns have been raised about the validity and utility of the tests, as well as the lack of individualized medical supervision and adequate consent procedures. The companies offering these tests do not make a distinction between screening individuals with a low population risk or testing individuals with a high risk of having an affected child. This has led to concerns about the potential consequences of these tests for individual citizens and society as a whole.

* The offer of preconceptional carrier tests by commercial companies raises several ethical concerns, including the need for medical supervision and follow-up, the provision of information and informed consent, and the appropriate use of existing resources. The companies offering these tests often provide limited information and support, and may not be equipped to handle the complex issues that arise from genetic testing. Furthermore, the tests may not be suitable for all individuals, and may lead to unnecessary anxiety and stress. The lack of regulation and oversight of these companies is also a concern.

* The implementation of preconceptional carrier tests should result in the optimization of advantages while reducing risks or adverse effects. The tests should be suitable for important health problems and have a known predictive value, and quality pre- and post-test information and counseling should be provided to lead to informed decision-making. However, the commercial offer of direct-to-consumer genetic carrier testing through the internet makes it difficult to meet these criteria. The purpose of carrier screening is to enlarge people's reproductive autonomy, but commercial companies may prioritize profits over this goal.

* Regulatory oversight of commercial companies offering preconceptional carrier tests is necessary to ensure that specific standards are being held and to promote the responsible provision and use of these services. The government has a duty to protect citizens against the risks of unsound testing, and should ensure that the tests

<summary>
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of autosomal recessive conditions caused by defects in various enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis, with 90-95% of cases resulting from 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This deficiency leads to signs and symptoms of androgen excess, including ambiguous genitalia in females and rapid somatic growth in both sexes.

• The typical medical treatment for CAH consists of oral glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid administration to compensate for adrenal steroid deficiencies and suppress adrenal androgens. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are commonly used medications for managing CAH.

• Adrenal masses were found in all four reported cases of CAH patients, and recent reports reveal a high appearance of small tumors in patients with untreated CAH. Most adrenal masses in children with CAH are benign, but the incidence of adrenal masses appears to be higher in CAH patients and heterozygotes than in the general population.

• The pathogenesis of adrenal tumor in patients with 21-hydroxylase deficiency CAH is thought to be related to a consequence of ACTH hypersecretion, which results from the lack of glucocorticoid synthesis. Chronic poor compliance to therapy appears to be associated with the development of the tumor.

• The aim of medical treatment in 21-hydroxylase deficiency is to suppress adrenal androgens sufficiently without impairing growth, while allowing for normal pubertal development and fertility. Glucocorticoids are given in doses sufficient to suppress excessive secretion of CRH and ACTH without total suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis.

• Infants with the salt-losing form of 21-hydroxylase deficiency require mineralocorticoid and sodium chloride supplements in addition to glucocorticoid treatment. Treatment is indicated only for those with symptoms and aims to reduce hyperandrogenism.

• CAH constitutes a continuum of disorders that affect patients throughout their lives, and a variety of clinics involving close interaction between pediatric, reproductive, adult endocrinologists, and clinical psychologists will be necessary for patients with CAH. Follow-up imaging may help to discover the appearance of adrenal tumor in patients with long-term management of 21-hydroxylase deficiency CAH.

* The study aimed to investigate the commonest indications of implant removal and detect which implants were most likely to require removal. The study was conducted prospectively on patients admitted for removal of implants in the orthopedics department of a teaching hospital. A total of 87 patients fulfilled the inclusion criteria, but four did not return for follow-up, leaving 83 patients for the study.

* The reasons for removal of implants were found to lie in five categories: pain/discomfort/prominent hardware, infected hardware, implant failure, elective (patient's insistence), and other reasons. The most common reason for removal was pain or discomfort, accounting for 39.75% of cases. The implants most commonly responsible for pain or discomfort were patella tension band wiring, olecranon tension band wiring/plates, and distal humeral plates.

* Twenty-four patients required hardware removal due to infection, with the most common implants being distal tibial/ankle plates, proximal tibial plates, and olecranon plates. Infection subsided in 21 patients after removal, but one patient had a refracture of the tibial shaft after sequestrectomy. The incidence of infections is likely to rise as more operations are performed and longevity increases.

* Eight patients required implant removal and revision osteosynthesis for implant failure, with the most common implants being femoral intramedullary nails, distal tibial locked plates, and humeral shaft dynamic compression plates. The reasons for failure of the implant include faulty implant, faulty operative technique, inadequate implant, delayed healing, and patient noncompliance. Poor quality of the implant was cited as the most common cause of failure.

* Seventeen patients had their implants removed on demand, despite being asymptomatic, with three developing persistent pain at the operated site and two developing superficial wound infections. The most consistently encountered obstacle during surgery was difficulty in removing the hardware from the bone, especially in locked plates of the distal humerus and forearm. Screw heads had to be cut off to remove the plate in two patients due to loss of contour of the screw head slot.

* The study found that the majority of patients requiring removal of implant were men, with a male preponderance of 85.5%. The mean age of patients requiring removal for infection was higher than those with pain or implant failure. Implant-associated pain or discomfort was the most common reason necessitating removal.

* The accuracy of detecting fetal pathology depends on the expertise of the sonographer and limitations inherent to the imaging technique. Descent of the fetal head and progressive ossification of the skull bones towards the end of pregnancy, maternal obesity, and oligohydramnios are well-known limitations affecting the sensitivity to detect central nervous system pathology. Advances in MRI technology have led to an increasing role for MRI in the diagnostic work-up of prenatal anomalies.

* Fetal MRI is mainly performed on 1.5 Tesla scanners, and no adverse health effects have been demonstrated after short-term exposure to electromagnetic fields. The HASTE sequence is the most used, combining short acquisition times with a good signal-to-noise ratio and acceptable spatial resolution. T1-weighted imaging is often used to detect hemorrhages or calcifications.

* The major limitations of fetal MRI are the impact of fetal motion on image acquisition and its relatively low spatial resolution compared to ultrasound. Contra-indications for MRI are the same as for non-pregnant patients, including claustrophobia, metallic brain clips, and pacemaker implant. MRI has an excellent contrast resolution, enabling differentiation between gray and white matter.

* Knowledge of the normal appearance and maturation of the developing cerebral gyri and sulci is helpful in the diagnosis and counseling of anomalous fetuses. At 14 weeks, the sylvian fissure and callosal sulcus are visible, and the central sulcus is reliably seen until 24-25 weeks of gestation. Numerous new sulci and gyri develop by the age of 32-35 weeks.

* Ventriculomegaly has a wide range of causes, including an imbalance between the production and absorption of cerebrospinal fluid, abnormal cerebral development, and destructive disease processes. Unilateral ventriculomegaly is more often seen in destructive processes, while developmental anomalies are characterized by bilateral broadening of the ventricles. The reported incidence of additional anomalies goes up to 70-85%.

* Isolated ventriculomegaly is used when no other structural anomalies are seen at the time of diagnosis. Isolated and/or unilateral ventriculomegaly, particularly the mild form, has a lower incidence of peri- and postnatal morbidity and mortality. Fetal MRI is useful in detecting and characterizing additional cerebral anomalies.
