<summary>
• The human microbiome is composed of trillions of microorganisms that play a crucial role in our overall health and well-being. Research has shown that the gut microbiome is involved in various physiological processes, including digestion, metabolism, and immune system function. An imbalance of the gut microbiome, also known as dysbiosis, has been linked to various diseases, including obesity, inflammatory bowel disease, and colorectal cancer.

• The gut microbiome is influenced by various factors, including diet, lifestyle, and environmental exposures. A diet high in processed foods and low in fiber can disrupt the balance of the gut microbiome, leading to changes in the way the body processes glucose and increasing the risk of metabolic disorders. Additionally, the use of antibiotics and other medications can also alter the gut microbiome.

• Research has identified three distinct enterotypes, or clusters, of gut microbiota, each with its own unique characteristics and functions. These enterotypes are influenced by diet and lifestyle factors and can have a significant impact on our overall health. For example, one enterotype is associated with a higher risk of obesity and metabolic disorders.

• The gut microbiome plays a crucial role in the development and progression of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Research has shown that an imbalance of the gut microbiome can lead to inflammation and damage to the gut lining, increasing the risk of IBD. Additionally, the gut microbiome has been linked to the development of colorectal cancer.

• The gut microbiome has also been shown to have a significant impact on our mental health and behavior, with research suggesting that it plays a role in the development of anxiety and depression. The gut-brain axis, which refers to the bidirectional communication network between the gut microbiome and the central nervous system, is thought to play a key role in this process. Further research is needed to fully understand the relationship between the gut microbiome and mental health.</summary>

<summary>
* Onychomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the nail, characterized by nail discoloration, thickening, and defect, with dermatophytes, yeasts, and nondermatophytes being the involved pathogens. The infection is more prevalent in toenails than in fingernails, and if left untreated, it can extend to other nails and cause further complications.

* A study was conducted to investigate the effect of topical tazarotene on distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis in 15 immunocompetent patients, with the drug being applied once a day for 12 weeks. The results showed complete healing in all patients at the end of the study, with a rapid and progressive amelioration of all evaluated clinical parameters.

* Tazarotene has proven to be effective in reducing hyperkeratinization in fungus-infected nails, and its therapeutic effects are mediated by the intracellular upregulation of cellular retinoic acid-binding protein-II expression. The reduction in excessive cell growth and the protective action on the microvascular bed against fungal infection may also contribute to its efficacy.

* The study's preliminary results documented the safety and rapid efficacy of topical treatment with tazarotene on distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis, representing an alternative new promising therapeutic approach. Further studies are needed to confirm the efficacy in terms of relapse and reinfection, and to investigate the specific effects of tazarotene in a larger cohort of patients with a longer follow-up.
</summary>

<summary>
* Male mice fed with nordihydroguaiaretic acid (NDGA) at 3.5g/kg diet (373mg/kg body weight/day) showed a 12% increase in median lifespan.
* The dose of NDGA that extended median lifespan is within 12% of that initially reported to extend the lifespan of NIH-ITP mice.
* NDGA consumption was associated with an increase in multiple tumor types and hemorrhagic diathesis in mice.
* The drug also increased the lifespan of Drosophila, suggesting its target(s) and mechanism(s) of action may be phylogenetically conserved.
* NDGA did not alter food consumption, body weight, or locomotor activity in Drosophila, unlike its effects in mice.
* The mechanisms for the longevity effects of NDGA are unclear, but may involve inhibition of mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) or other pathways.
* The study's findings suggest that NDGA may have potential as a therapeutic agent, but its toxicity and side effects need to be carefully evaluated.</summary>

<summary>
• Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) is an important treatment for patients with heart failure and left ventricular dyssynchrony, but clinical non-response to CRT is reported in 25-35% of patients.
• A study was conducted to investigate the acute hemodynamic response (AHR) of the implanted system and alternative left ventricular endocardial pacing sites in patients clinically not responding to CRT.
• Twenty-four non-consecutive patients underwent an acute hemodynamic study to search for improving existing CRT, and the results showed that 11 patients had a positive response to endocardial pacing.
• The study found that basal or mid-posterolateral segments had the highest AHR of the tested endocardial sites in all 14 patients who showed an AHR ≥ 15% rise in LVDP/DTmax compared with baseline.
• Ten patients were considered possible candidates for LV endocardial pacing, and 5 of them finally agreed to LV endocardial implant at the optimal LV site as indicated from the acute study.
• All five patients improved clinically with a reduction of at least 1 class in the NYHA score after 6 months of follow-up.
• The study also showed that endocardial pacing opposite the epicardial coronary sinus lead did not improve the AHR, and epicardial pacing at the optimal site may be a good alternative for endocardial LV lead placement.
• The longest Q-LV interval is a reliable indicator for the optimal electrode position in the individual patient, and a temporary acute hemodynamic study could be useful in non-responders to establish the chance of improvement with alternative pacing sites.
• Larger randomized series are necessary to justify the technique of LV endocardial pacing before definitive conclusions can be drawn.
</summary>

<summary>
• Oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is a common opportunistic fungal infection in HIV-positive patients, with Candida albicans being the most frequently isolated species. 
• The study found that 76% of patients had a history of HIV transmission through sexual contact, and 73% of patients with OPC had CD4+ cell counts below 200 cells/mm. 
• Pseudomembranous candidiasis was the most common clinical presentation of OPC, accounting for 52.6% of cases, followed by erythematous, angular cheilitis, and a combination of these forms. 
• The study emphasizes the need for continued awareness of OPC as a major clinical sign in the HIV population, particularly in patients with low CD4+ cell counts, and highlights the importance of antifungal treatment and antiretroviral therapy (ART) in managing the infection.
</summary>

<summary>
• Myosin Va (MyoVa) is a processive molecular motor involved in intracellular cargo transport along the actin cytoskeleton. The motor's directed movement is accomplished by a conformational change in the motor domain following ATP hydrolysis, which is amplified by the lever arms, resulting in the motor's processive motion. The lever arms consist of six tandem-helix motifs, stabilized by calmodulin or calmodulin-like light chains, and calcium is required to activate the ATPase activity of MyoVa. However, high calcium levels can reduce motor processivity and cause calmodulin dissociation from the lever arm.

• The flexural stiffness of MyoVa constructs and subdomains was measured using tethered particle microscopy (TPM), which revealed that the lever arms have a flexural stiffness of 0.0346 pN/nm, while the distal rod domain has a flexural stiffness of 0.0326 pN/nm. The addition of calcium caused a 40% reduction in lever arm flexural stiffness, which is expected to negatively impact interhead communication and gating necessary for force production and processivity. The lever arm/rod junction was found to be highly compliant, contributing to the free diffusive search of the unbound leading head and allowing MyoVa to maneuver through actin-actin intersections. The estimates of flexural stiffness offer direct insight into the structural components of the MyoVa motor that are critical to its functional capacities.</summary>

<summary>
* Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) affects 1 in every 500 to 1 in every 1000 individuals, and it may not be clinically apparent until the third or fourth decade of life. Only about half of the patients will progress to renal failure. Several risk factors, such as hypertension and male gender, have been associated with a more rapid course. In young patients, there is no way to predict whether or when renal failure will develop.

* A 35-year-old full-term primigravida with oligohydramnios was scheduled for emergency lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) due to ADPKD. She was diagnosed with ADPKD in the seventh month of pregnancy and was hospitalized and hemodialyzed thrice a week for the next 2 months. The nephrologists and obstetricians decided to proceed with an emergency LSCS as she was full term. Clinical parameters were within acceptable limits, and preoperative investigations showed mild proteinuria and pus cells in urine.

* The patient's biochemical profile revealed a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 30 mg/dl, serum creatinine 3.7 mg%, and serum potassium 5 mmol/l. Coagulation profile was within normal limits, and arterial blood gas on air showed pH 7.41 and pCO2 30.8 mmHg. Monitoring included pulse oximeter, cardioscope, noninvasive blood pressure (NIBP), central venous pressure (CVP), and urine output measurement. A peripheral line of 18 g in the left arm was used to preload her with 500 ml of normal saline till CVP was 5 cm H2O.

* Spinal anesthesia was successfully given in the L3-4 intervertebral space using 1 ml of 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine (5 mg) with 25 mcg fentanyl in the left-lateral position. Intraoperatively, blood pressure was in the range of 100-120 mmHg systolic, heart rate 70-100/min, CVP 5-6 cm H2O, and urine output of approximately 1 ml/kg/h. A 2.0 kg live male child was delivered with an Apgar score of 9 at 5 min. The patient did not complain of pain for about 4 h; thereafter, she was given intravenous tramadol

* The study analyzed the lactation curve of Karan Fries cows to determine the pattern of milk yield and its association with mastitis. The data was collected from 733 cows over a period of 12 years, and the lactation curve was modeled using a gamma-type function. The results showed that the peak milk yield was attained in the 3rd and 4th fortnights in both normal and mastitis cows. The trend in milk yield suggested that the peak yield duration was not affected by the incidence of mastitis.

* The study found that the initial milk yield was lower in the first parity and increased in subsequent parities, with the highest initial milk yield reaching the 4th lactation. The peak milk yield was also higher in the 4th parity, and the persistency of lactation declined with increasing parity order. The decline in persistency was attributed to the age factor, as older animals started their lactation at a higher level and had a rapid rate of decline in milk production. The results were in agreement with earlier reports in normal cattle and buffaloes.

* The lactation curve parameters, including the ascending slope parameter and descending slope parameter, were estimated for each parity. The results showed that the ascending slope parameter was lower in the first parity and increased in subsequent parities, while the descending slope parameter was higher in the 4th parity. The results were in agreement with earlier reports in crossbred cows, but the values were lower than those reported in Holstein cows. The marginal differences in parameters between normal and mastitis cows were due to disturbed milk secretion and apoptosis of mammary secretory cells.

* The study found that the peak milk yield was lower in the first parity and increased in subsequent parities, with the highest peak milk yield reaching the 4th lactation. The time to attain peak yield was also longer in the first parity than in subsequent parities. The results were in agreement with earlier reports in Norwegian mastitis cows, but the predicted fortnightly peak milk yield was nonsignificantly different in both mastitis and normal cows. The high persistency was associated with a slow rate of decline in milk yield after peak production.

* The study used a gamma-type function to model the lactation curve, which was found to be the best model due to its small error variance and high determination coefficient. The goodness of fit of the model was high, with a coefficient of determination ranging from 84.88% to 98.18% in normal cows and from 83.

* Visceral adipose tissue-derived serine proteinase inhibitor (vaspin) and adiponectin are adipokines that play important roles in metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular diseases. Vaspin has been shown to improve insulin resistance, inhibit inflammation, and progression of atherosclerosis. The study aimed to investigate the serum levels of vaspin and adiponectin in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and renal insufficiency (RI). The results showed that serum vaspin levels were lower in patients with T2DM than in those without T2DM.

* The study found that serum adiponectin levels were higher in patients with RI than in those without RI, regardless of the presence of T2DM. Adiponectin has been reported to have antidiabetic and antiatherogenic effects, and its reduction plays a central role in obesity-linked diseases. The study also found that serum adiponectin levels were higher in women than in men, whether in total subjects or in patients with T2DM. The levels of adiponectin were also found to be correlated with age, systolic blood pressure, and creatinine clearance.

* The study suggests that measuring the levels of adipokines in patients with RI may be beneficial for predicting cardiovascular events and patient survival. The results also suggest that the sex difference and the presence of vascular complications may affect the serum levels of vaspin. The study found that the level of hemoglobin A1c was independently and significantly associated with the vaspin concentration in total subjects. The level of creatinine clearance was also found to be independently and significantly associated with the adiponectin concentration in all subjects.</summary>

<summary>
* Genetic variation plays a crucial role in disease susceptibility and treatment response, and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have enabled the rapid discovery of genetic variants contributing to complex genetic diseases. The use of biomarkers, such as DNA biomarkers, DNA tumor biomarkers, and general biomarkers, is essential in personalized medicine. Biomarkers can be used for diagnosis, prognosis, and prediction of treatment response.

* Biomarkers are characteristics that are objectively measured and evaluated as indicators of normal biological processes, pathogenic processes, or pharmacologic responses to a therapeutic intervention. The Biomarkers Definitions Working Group defines a biomarker as a characteristic that is objectively measured and evaluated as an indicator of normal biological processes, pathogenic processes, or pharmacologic responses to a therapeutic intervention. Biomarkers can be used to determine the diagnosis or severity of a disease.

* DNA biomarkers are generally measured in the blood, while DNA tumor biomarkers are measured in tumor tissue, and general biomarkers may be measured in biofluid, tissue, or cell lines. DNA biomarkers are reproducible and can be measured at any point in time, making them suitable for prospective and retrospective studies. However, DNA biomarkers cannot be used for therapy monitoring, pharmacodynamics, or as surrogate markers.

* The development of diagnostic tests undergoes a similar process to drug development, with phases I-IV. Phase I involves demonstrating the safety and technical properties of the diagnostic test, while phase II involves validating the test in a clinical setting. Phase III involves prospective investigation of the diagnostic test, and phase IV involves post-marketing surveillance.

* The use of biomarkers in clinical trials is becoming increasingly important, and regulatory guidance is still sparse. The FDA has issued a draft guidance for industry on in vitro companion diagnostic devices, which are predictive biomarkers essential for safe and effective use of a corresponding therapeutic product. The guidance anticipates three uses of companion diagnostics: identification of patients most likely to benefit from a particular therapeutic product, identification of patients likely to be at increased risk for adverse reactions, and monitoring treatment response.

* The validation of biomarkers is crucial, and novel strategies must be developed to achieve convincing evidence. The use of biobanks for prospective validation may play a role, but transparency and quality of reporting are essential. Authors of biomarker studies are encouraged to report their work using appropriate reporting guidelines, such as STARD, STROBE-ME, REMARK, or PRISMA.</summary>

<summary>
* The study aimed to determine whether clinical outcomes after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) could be predicted by functional polymorphisms in different proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes. Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the AURKA, ERBB2, MDM2, CDH1, CDKN2A, and TP73 genes were genotyped in a consecutive cohort of 346 esophageal cancer patients.

* The study found that patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous MDM2 (rs2279744) T/G genotype had significantly improved disease-free survival (DFS) compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype. The adjusted hazard ratio (AHR) was 0.63, with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 0.45-0.88.

* Patients with EAC harboring the homozygous CDH1 (rs5030625) GA/GA genotype had a significantly reduced survival as compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype. The AHR was 4.0, with a 95% CI of 1.4-11.

* The study suggests that inter-individual differences in germ-line DNA have an impact on DFS in patients with EAC. The results indicate that the MDM2 T/G and CDH1 GA/GA genotypes confer risk of death in patients with EAC.

* The study's findings could contribute to the identification of patients who are at high or low risk for the development of disease recurrences. Early detection of recurrent disease is desirable because aggressive treatment may result in prolonged tumor-free survival or occasional cure.

* The identification of polymorphisms associated with DFS could serve well as hypothesis-generating for prospective studies that evaluate the prognostic significance of germ-line variants. Patients with a certain genetic constitution that is associated with a high chance of (distant) disease recurrence should be given systemic adjuvant treatment after surgical resection.

* Additional prospective studies are necessary to validate both associations and to study the prognostic significance of both germ-line variants. The study's results indicate that two of six investigated functional polymorphisms are associated with DFS in patients who underwent esophagectomy for EAC.
</summary>

<summary>
* Laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) mesh repair is a standard treatment for inguinal hernia in adults, but it can cause early postoperative pain and chronic pain.
* A study compared the perioperative extent of surgical trauma and its postoperative impact on the abdominal wall after needlescopic TAPP (NTAPP) and single-incision laparoscopic surgery (STAPP) repair.
* The study included 85 patients with a single-sided primary inguinal hernia who underwent NTAPP or STAPP repair between 2009 and 2012.
* The NTAPP procedure required significantly less operating time than the STAPP procedure, with a mean operative time of 54.8 minutes compared to 85.9 minutes.
* The NTAPP group had a significantly shorter mean period of sick leave, with a mean of 11.2 days compared to 24.1 days in the STAPP group.
* The NTAPP procedure was able to further reduce immediate postoperative pain in wound regions, but did not significantly improve the incidence of chronic groin pain.
* Both groups regained equal abdominal wall mobility and satisfactory cosmetic results after an approximate observation time of 30 months.
* The NTAPP procedure has distinct advantages in the immediate postoperative phase, including reduced postoperative wound pain and shorter sick leave.
* However, it offers comparable long-term results in hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction.
* Randomized controlled trials comparing NTAPP, STAPP, and conventional TAPP repairs are still needed to validate the benefits of needlescopic surgery.
</summary>

<summary>
• The incidence of ipsilateral breast tumor relapse (IBTR) in patients previously treated for breast carcinoma is estimated to be less than 6%. IBTR can be classified into two distinct types of lesions: true local recurrence (TR) and new primary tumor (NPT), which have different natural histories, prognosis, and therapeutic management. The classification of IBTR is based on pathologic features, location, and molecular techniques.

• A 35-year-old premenopausal woman with a family history of breast cancer was diagnosed with moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) and received breast-conserving surgery, adjuvant chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. Four years later, she developed inflammatory breast cancer in the same breast, which was treated with chemotherapy, trastuzumab, and surgery. The patient remains in complete clinical remission after 4 years and 8 months of follow-up.

• The risk of developing a second breast cancer is the same whether the patient had previously undergone a mastectomy or breast-conserving therapy (BCT). Patients with NPT generally have a favorable prognosis, and therapeutic decisions concerning systemic therapy should be similar to those in patients with de novo breast carcinoma. The care of breast cancer survivors requires an understanding of relapse patterns, establishing appropriate follow-up visits and screening tests.</summary>

<summary>
• Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with approximately 1.67 million new patients diagnosed annually worldwide, accounting for 25% of all cancer cases. The status of locoregional lymph nodes is important for staging the disease and determining prognosis. Sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) are the first draining nodes from a primary tumor and are most likely to be the first site of lymphatic metastasis. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is the standard method for determining axillary staging in early-stage breast cancer patients.

• The combined technique of radioisotope and blue dye is used for SLNB, but it has drawbacks, including the use of radioisotopes, which is subject to stringent regulations. Many hospitals in the world do not have access to radioisotopes, and only approximately 60% of patients in the Western world and negligible numbers in the rest of the world have access to SLNB. This has led to the search for other techniques, not reliant on the use of radioisotopes. Recently, the use of a magnetic tracer and a handheld magnetometer was evaluated as a radiation-free alternative.

• A superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPION) tracer was administered interstitially in the breast, followed by identification of the SLNs with a handheld magnetometer. The magnetic technique was found to be noninferior to the combined technique with identification rates of 94.4-98.0%. However, there was a discordance in SLNs identified between the magnetic and combined techniques, potentially leading to false-negative staging with the magnetic technique. A smaller study used a similar SPION tracer and different magnetometer, comparing SPION and blue dye only.

• The study evaluated the performance of three different-sized SPION-based formulations licensed for human use within an in vivo porcine model. The tracers were diluted to the same iron concentration of 11.2 mg Fe/ml to facilitate comparison of performance. The hydrodynamic particle size of all tracers was determined by dynamic light scattering using a Zetasizer Nano ZS. Ethical permission for animal experimentation was granted by the Research Institute Against Digestive Cancer (IRCAD) Ethics Review Board.

• A previously developed and validated porcine model that closely resembles human lymphatic drainage was used to evaluate the performance of the different magnetic tracers for SLNB. Mini-pigs were injected with one of the three different magnetic tracers subcutaneously bilaterally into the areolas of the third inguinal mammary glands. Trans

<summary>
• The study analyzed data from two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials to test surrogate variables for neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and explore the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing. The trials included 190 ulcers, with patients receiving intralesional injections of recombinant human epidermal growth factor (rhEGF) or a placebo.

• The study found that granulation tissue development was a strong predictor of complete wound closure, with a high correct classification rate and good diagnostic indicators. The proportion of granulation tissue covering the wound area at the end of treatment was the most efficient predictor.

• The study also analyzed data from an active postmarketing surveillance of rhEGF treatment in 1,440 DFUs in 60 healthcare units. The results confirmed that granulation tissue development at the end of treatment was an early predictor of final healing.

• The study used various statistical methods, including receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis and multivariate regression, to evaluate the performance of the surrogate variables. The results showed that granulation tissue development had a high area under the ROC curve, indicating good discriminatory power.

• The study found that the effect of treatment on healing was largely mediated by granulation tissue development, with a high proportion mediated by this variable. In contrast, the proportion mediated by area change-dependent variables was small.

• The study's results suggest that granulation tissue development can be used as a surrogate endpoint for complete wound closure in clinical trials of advanced DFUs. This can be useful for reducing the duration of clinical trials and improving the efficiency of wound care.

• The study's findings have implications for clinical practice, as they suggest that clinicians can use granulation tissue development as a predictor of wound healing in advanced DFUs. This can help guide treatment decisions and improve patient outcomes.

• The study's results also have implications for healthcare programs managing diabetic foot ulcers, as they suggest that granulation tissue development can be used as a predictor of wound healing in these patients. This can help guide resource allocation and improve patient outcomes.

• Overall, the study provides evidence for the use of granulation tissue development as a predictor of wound healing in advanced DFUs, and suggests that this variable can be used as a surrogate endpoint in clinical trials of these patients.
</summary>

<summary>
• A study demonstrated that diphenhydramine, a first-generation antihistamine, inhibits cough reflex sensitivity in subjects with acute viral upper respiratory tract infection (URI).
• The study compared the effects of diphenhydramine, dextromethorphan, and placebo on cough reflex sensitivity in 22 adult nonsmokers with acute URI.
• The results showed that diphenhydramine significantly inhibited cough reflex sensitivity, while dextromethorphan did not, with both agents administered at standard antitussive doses.
• The study's findings contribute to the initial evidence demonstrating the ability of diphenhydramine to inhibit cough reflex sensitivity in acute pathological cough.
• Further clinical trials are needed to adequately evaluate over-the-counter (OTC) cough and cold products, allowing physicians and consumers to make informed treatment decisions based on proper scientific data.
</summary>

<summary>
• The breathing process is essential for human survival, and it begins at the upper airway, culminating in gas exchange inside the alveoli. When breathing begins through the nose, the air is prepared to reach the lungs with ideal conditions, including warming, moistening, and filtering. This process activates immunological processes that protect the lower airway.

• Mouth breathing, especially in childhood, promotes a pathological adaptation of the structures of the stomatognathic system, leading to morphological and functional growth alterations. The main causes of mouth breathing in childhood include hypertrophy of the pharyngeal and/or palatine tonsil, nasal mucosa and turbinate edema, and nasal septal deviation. These adaptations generate functional changes in the stomatognathic system, observed through alterations in speech, chewing, and deglutition.

• The complexity of the consequences of mouth breathing justifies the participation of several professionals, including otorhinolaryngologists, odontologists, phonoaudiologists, and physiotherapists, in the diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and prevention of mouth breathing in childhood. Multidisciplinary staff integration is essential, and a uniform categorization of mouth breathers is desirable. Accurate diagnosis of the cause of mouth breathing is essential to the effectiveness of treatment.

• Nasopharyngoscopy is a procedure used to visualize the pharyngeal tonsil and its relation to other nasopharyngeal structures, considered by many authors as the most reliable exam in the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal obstruction. Cephalometry is an exam that provides data related to craniofacial growth and the myofunctional status of these structures. This study aimed to establish a correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in the diagnosis of hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils.

• The findings of this study demonstrated a regular and positive correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry, but a perfect correlation was not found. Cephalometry presented a tendency to underestimate the pharyngeal tonsil size in the nasopharynx, and the sensitivity of the cephalometric exam was 35%. The negative predictive value of cephalometry was 72%, suggesting that a negative cephalometric exam might not provide a proper assessment of the nasopharynx.

<summary>
• This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence of aortic aneurysms (AAs) in a population of elderly Korean males with hypertension who had multiple risk factors for coronary heart disease (CHD) and AA. The study used non-contrast computed tomography (CT) to measure the diameter of the entire aorta, from the thoracic aorta to the abdominal aorta.

• The study found that the prevalence of thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) was significantly higher than abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), with 36.5% of patients having TAA and 6.0% having AAA. The prevalence of TAA was associated with older age, larger body surface area, and higher diastolic blood pressure.

• The study also found that AAA was independently associated with dyslipidemia, smoking history, and the presence of TAA. The prevalence of AAA was significantly higher in current/past smokers compared to non-smokers, and none of the non-smokers had a large AAA (> 40 mm).

• The study highlights the need for distinct screening strategies for TAA and AAA according to risk factors and ethnicity, and suggests that the results of this study may not be applicable to females, other ethnicities, or groups with a low-risk of cardiovascular disease. Future research should establish methods for aortic screening and strategies for conservative and surgical management in elderly hypertensive patients.</summary>

<summary>
• Schwannomas of the vidian canal are extremely rare, benign tumors that can present with symptoms such as headaches, facial pain, and nasal dryness, or be found incidentally, and their diagnosis can be confirmed through endoscopic biopsy.
• Treatment options for vidian canal schwannomas include surgical resection, single-fraction stereotactic radiosurgery, and conventional fractionated radiotherapy, with the choice of treatment depending on patient choice, functional status, and tumor characteristics.</summary>

<summary>
* Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of severe vision loss in people aged 55 years and older in developed countries. The neovascular form of AMD accounts for the majority of cases of AMD-related severe central vision loss. Upregulation of angiogenic factors, including vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), has been implicated in the development and progression of AMD. The management of neovascular AMD has been transformed with the development of intravitreal anti-VEGF treatment.

* A study was conducted to determine and evaluate change from baseline to week 12 in Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity (CS) as the primary clinical end point in patients with recalcitrant exudative AMD who were switched to aflibercept therapy. The study included 40 patients with treatment-resistant neovascular AMD who were switched to aflibercept from ranibizumab. The mean CS increased from 1.32 log units at baseline to 1.40 log units at week 12, and the mean central retinal thickness (CRT) decreased by 22 μm from baseline to week 12. There was a statistically significant improvement in CS and a statistically significant reduction in CRT over 12 weeks after treatment switch to aflibercept.

* The study demonstrated that there is a general and immediate decreasing trend in mean CRT after treatment switch to aflibercept, while no statistically significant change from baseline visual acuity (VA) was noted. The fluid reduction seen following a switch to aflibercept was associated with improvement in visual function as measured by CS. The National Eye Institute 25-item Visual Function Questionnaire (NEI VFQ-25) score improved from baseline to week 12 in two-thirds of the anti-VEGF switch population. The observed positive correlation between improvement in CS and reduction in CRT supports the argument that measurement of CS may provide a more complete understanding of the benefits of anti-VEGF treatment.

* The study results suggest that CS measurement may provide a better understanding of visual performance challenges faced by individuals with vision impairment. An extended study duration involving a larger patient population would allow for further investigation and potential validation of results with regard to improvement in CS and other visual functioning parameters. Further analyses exploring multiple measures of visual function as efficacy end points in treatment studies of diabetic macular edema and other retinal diseases are warranted. Switching of anti-VEGF agents in neovascular AMD patients is a viable treatment strategy to improve outcomes among initial nonresponders or for patients

<summary>
• The global population is aging, and this trend is predicted to continue, leading to an increased prevalence of cardiovascular diseases, which are the most common cause of death among the elderly.
• Endothelial dysfunction, characterized by reduced vasodilator substance output and increased endothelium-derived contracting factors, is a key feature of cardiovascular disease and is influenced by oxidative stress and inflammation.
• Oxidative stress, an imbalance between the production of oxidizing agents and antioxidant systems, interferes with endothelial function, reducing nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability and promoting atherosclerosis.
• Inflammation, mediated by monocyte-derived macrophages, plays a critical role in the development of atherosclerosis, and markers of inflammation, such as high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP), can provide insights into the biological status of atherosclerotic lesions.
• Exercise training can prevent and restore age-related impairment of endothelial function by restoring NO availability, preventing oxidative stress, and alleviating inflammatory processes.
• Regular exercise can also reduce systemic inflammation, increase anti-inflammatory substances, and improve cardiovascular health by reducing the production of proinflammatory cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) and interleukin-6 (IL-6).
• The benefits of exercise on cardiovascular health are well-established, and regular physical activity can reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease, disability, and mortality among the elderly.</summary>

<summary>
• Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, causing severe cognitive and physical impairments. It is a chronic disease that affects young adults, with most patients diagnosed between the ages of 20 and 40. The exact reason for MS is unknown, but genetic and environmental factors, such as viruses, are involved in its pathogenesis. Researchers are trying to improve symptoms of MS by altering the behavior of MS patients, including exercise.

• The study aimed to evaluate the association between the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene and MS in an Iranian population. IL-25 is a cytokine that plays a key role in stimulating and developing T helper 2 (Th2) responses, which can regulate Th1 and Th17 responses involved in the pathogenesis of MS. The study used a case-control design, recruiting 80 patients with MS and 75 healthy controls. The occurrence of MS was confirmed based on McDonald's criteria and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) results.

• The study found that the frequency distribution of the genotypes was not statistically different between patients with MS and the controls. The logistic regression model revealed that the odds ratio (OR) of MS development in patients with the AC and AA genotypes compared to patients with the CC genotype was not statistically significant. The study also found that the frequencies of A and C alleles were not statistically different between the two groups. The OR of MS development in patients with the A allele versus patients with the C allele was not statistically significant.

• The study's results suggest that the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene is not associated with MS in the Iranian population. This is consistent with a previous study that found no association between this polymorphism and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, another study found that other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene, except c424c/a, were associated with MS. This suggests that other polymorphisms may regulate IL-25 expression.

• The study's findings have implications for the understanding of the pathogenesis of MS. IL-25 may play a significant role in the regulation of immune responses during inflammatory diseases, including MS. However, the c424c/a polymorphism is not important in the pathogenesis of these diseases. Further studies are needed to evaluate the roles of other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene and serum levels of IL-25 in MS.

• The study's limitations include the small sample size and the lack of evaluation of other

<summary>
* Breast cancer is the most common cancer worldwide among women, with nearly 1.7 million new cases in 2012, and the highest incidence rates are in Europe and North America. The highest incidence rates by country are in Belgium, Denmark, and France.

* Screening mammography has been associated with an up-to-50% reduction in mortality rate, and digital mammography (DM) is now the most commonly performed procedure for breast cancer detection. DM is less likely to be lost or damaged and has slightly higher sensitivity than screen-film mammography (SFM).

* However, conventional mammography has limitations, including the problem of overlapping tissue, which can obscure tumors, and the challenge of detecting cancers in women with dense breast tissue. Digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) is a 3D procedure that may help solve this problem.

* DBT uses x-rays like conventional mammography but creates image slices of a tissue volume, decreasing the problem of confusing overlapping tissue. DBT is a mammography-based technique using breast compression similar to 2D DM.

* Studies have shown that adding DBT to standard mammography improves the accuracy of interpretation of mammograms, increases cancer detection, and reduces recall rates. The additional cancers detected are invasive malignancies missed by conventional mammography.

* DBT also may decrease the necessity to perform extra mammogram views to identify the exact location of a breast lesion, benefiting radiation dose and patient comfort. With the overall need for compression decreased for tomosynthesis, some studies found that DBT can be done with more patient satisfaction.

* The radiation dose for the combined examination of conventional mammography and DBT is slightly more than twice the dose of mammography alone, but synthetically reconstructed 2D images can be made from the DBT data, eliminating the need for double exposures. This eliminates the need to do an exposure for a DM and drops the radiation dose to that of conventional mammography.

* The cost of a DBT system is substantially greater than that of a DM system, but compared with breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), DBT is a relatively low-cost innovation, and cost savings may result from fewer biopsies and recalls.
</summary>

<summary>
• The axillary lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor in breast carcinoma, and the prognosis worsens with an increasing number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• The lymph node ratio (LNR) provides more useful prognostic information compared to nodal disease classification according to the number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• The study found that the most significant LNR threshold value separating patients in low- and high-risk groups with significant survival difference was 0.20 for disease-free survival (DFS), 0.30 for locoregional recurrence-free survival (LRFS), and 0.15 for distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS).
• The LNR had independent prognostic significance for DMFS, while the number of removed lymph nodes did not, indicating that LNR can be used to separate patients with n1 disease into low- and high-risk groups regardless of the total number of lymph nodes removed.
• The study suggests that n1 disease does not constitute a homogenous prognostic group, and LNR can provide more detailed and useful prognostic information than TNM nodal disease classification.
• In patients having 10 or more lymph nodes removed, the number of removed and metastatic lymph nodes and LNR did not have prognostic significance for LRFS, indicating that removal of at least 10 lymph nodes may be sufficient to obtain locoregional control.
• The LNR is a useful tool in separating breast carcinoma patients with 1-3 metastatic lymph node(s) into low- and high-risk prognostic groups, and it may be useful to standardize adjuvant therapy for patients operated in hospitals with different axillary dissection widths and median number of removed lymph nodes.</summary>

<summary>
• Endometrial cancer has become the most common invasive malignancy of the female genital tract in developed countries, surpassing cervical cancer. Early screening methods for cervical cancer have made significant progress, and a similar approach is needed for endometrial carcinoma.

• Endometrial complex hyperplasia with atypia and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) are considered precursors of type I endometrioid adenocarcinoma. A certain period is required for these lesions to develop into carcinoma.

• Traditional methods for obtaining endometrial samples include dilation and curettage (D&C) or hysteroscopic biopsy, which are considered reliable for evaluating the endometrial condition. However, the adequacy of specimens obtained using the SAP-1 device compared to these methods is unknown.

• The aim of this study was to investigate whether liquid-based SurePath preparation for endometrial cytology test (ECT) can maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium. Histology is the gold standard for evaluating the accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, positive prediction value (PPV), and negative prediction value (NPV) of ECT.

• The study was performed from November 2011 to May 2014 at the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department of Peking University First Hospital and was approved by the hospital ethics committee. The study included 1514 patients with endometrial carcinoma risk factors who underwent SAP-1 sampling.

• The patients' characteristics, including age distribution, menstrual status, and symptoms and signs, are presented in the study. Most patients were over 40 years of age, and the percentage of postmenopausal women was 69% and 63.5% in the two groups.

• The study found that SAP-1 can provide more sufficient materials for cytology than D&C or hysteroscopic biopsy for histology. The accuracy of cytology for detecting endometrial precursor and carcinoma was estimated at 91.7%, sensitivity at 73.6%, specificity at 94.9%, PPV at 71.9%, and NPV at 95.3%.

• The increased morbidity of endometrial carcinoma is attributed to changes in lifestyle, such as a lack of exercise and increasing fat intake leading to obesity and high BMI. Obesity triggers several pathways, including hormonal imbalance and hyperactive proliferative pathways, to involve in the pathogenesis of endometrial carcinoma.

<summary>
• The traditional method of activating hydroxy groups involves the use of strong acids and leaving groups, but this approach has poor atom economy and generates large amounts of waste. In contrast, nature uses enzymatic phosphorylation to activate hydroxy groups, which is a more efficient and environmentally friendly process. However, this method requires the use of cofactors, which can be problematic for large-scale applications. Researchers have been exploring alternative methods, including the use of phosphatases, which can transfer phosphate groups from inorganic polyphosphates to hydroxylated compounds.

• Phosphatases have been shown to be efficient catalysts for the phosphorylation of various alcohols, including primary and secondary alcohols, and sugars. The enzymes phonsf, phonse, and piacp were found to be particularly effective, with phonsf delivering the highest product titers with primary alcohols as acceptors. The substrate scope of these enzymes was investigated, and it was found that they can phosphorylate a range of alcohols, including diols and cyclic substrates. However, the presence of a negatively charged phosphate group in the proximity of the reacting hydroxy moiety can affect the phosphorylation reaction.

• The chemoselectivity of the enzymes was also investigated, and it was found that they exclusively furnish the O-phosphate monoester, with no reaction observed with N- or S-nucleophiles. The enzymes were also found to be regioselective, with a preference for primary over secondary hydroxy groups. The enantioselectivity of the enzymes was also investigated, and it was found that phonsf and piacp show non-enantioselective phosphorylation, while phonse shows a marginal enantiopreference. The results suggest that the enzymes can be used for the synthesis of phosphate monoesters with high regio- and chemoselectivity.

• The effect of reaction parameters, such as pH and phosphate donor, on the phosphorylation reaction was also investigated. It was found that the use of high amounts of phosphate donor and low pH values can increase the product titers and reduce product hydrolysis. The results suggest that the choice of phosphate donor and pH is crucial for achieving high product titers and minimizing product hydrolysis. The use of a continuous flow reactor was also found to be an efficient tool for maintaining high product levels and scaling up the reaction.

<summary>
• The study aimed to compare the stiffness of short-segment pedicle fixation using either monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws placed at the level of fracture in an unstable burst fracture model. Twelve fresh-frozen calf lumbar specimens were used, and the specimens were randomly divided into monoaxial pedicle screw (MPS) group and polyaxial pedicle screw (PPS) group. The addition of an intermediate screw decreased the range of motion (ROM) of the L2-L4 segments in both the MPS and PPS groups. A smaller ROM due to the use of an intermediate screw represents enhanced stability of the construct.

• The short-segment construct in the PPS group had significantly greater ROM in flexion and extension when compared with the MPS group. The addition of intermediate screws at the level of a burst fracture significantly increased the stiffness of the short-segment pedicle fixation, irrespective of whether monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws were used. However, this increase was more significant for the MPS construct, as the PPS already had significantly increased stiffness as compared to the MPS. The intermediate screw provides a 3-point fixation of the fractured segment.

• The study suggests that the addition of intermediate screws at the level of a burst fracture significantly increases the stability of a short-segment pedicle fixation, using either monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws. However, the short-segment MPS fixation group was significantly more stable in flexion and extension than the short-segment PPS fixation group. The study provides a biomechanical rationale for using an intermediate screw at the level of fractured vertebrae with posterior short-segment fixation, especially when using monoaxial screws for fixing the unstable burst fractures of the lumbar region. The results of this study can be used to guide clinical decision-making in the management of unstable burst fractures.</summary>

<summary>
• The discovery of electrochemical self-assembly (ESA) of nanostructured hybrid thin films has opened a new route for obtaining photoanode materials for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). This method bypasses the high-temperature sintering needed for nanoparticulate TiO2 electrodes, allowing the use of conductive plastic substrates. The ESA of ZnO structures has been demonstrated for the construction of photoanodes.

• The ESA of CuSCN-based hybrid thin films has been explored as a counterpart to ZnO-based hybrid systems, using rhodamine B (RB) as a structure-directing agent (SDA). The addition of RB to the bath causes a change in the crystallographic orientation of CuSCN, and the loaded RB molecules can be almost completely removed by soaking the film in dimethylacetamide (DMA). This process creates highly porous CuSCN thin films with controlled crystallographic orientation.

• The porous crystalline CuSCN thin film has been utilized as a dye-sensitized photocathode, exhibiting a clear photocathodic action under visible light illumination. However, the lack of a suitable redox electrolyte and stable hole-injecting dye remains a challenge for efficiency improvement. The successfully constructed efficient dye-sensitized CuSCN photocathode can be combined with existing dye-sensitized photoanodes to achieve high-efficiency tandem DSSCs in a simple structure.</summary>

<summary>
* The concept of non-native biological invaders has been noted for centuries, with examples such as the phylloxera that destroyed grapevines in Europe in the 1860s and the chestnut blight that devastated North America in the early 20th century. Charles Elton's book in 1958 brought attention to the issue, but it wasn't until the 1980s that research on invasions gained momentum. The Scientific Committee on Problems of the Environment (SCOPE) project triggered an explosion of research on invasions, recognizing it as one of the great ongoing global environmental changes. This surge of research included studies on how non-native invaders eat, compete with, or infect native species.

* Two new lines of research have become increasingly prominent, indicating that impacts of introduced species are more varied and widespread than previously thought. Peter Vitousek described impacts at the ecosystem level, affecting nutrient cycles and other ecosystem-level processes. Research on such impacts has increased, showing how a single introduced species can change processes or the physical structure of an ecosystem. This has led to a greater understanding of the complex interactions between introduced and native species.

* Molecular genetic research has revealed a great number of cases of the "stealth" impact of invaders, hybridization, and introgression with native species. This phenomenon was previously detected almost exclusively phenotypically, but many phenotypic responses are subtle and hidden amidst normal variation. Introgression can cause substantial evolution of native species, and hybridization between native and introduced species can produce new, more invasive species. The best-known example is common cordgrass, Spartina anglica, an invader that arose in England from hybridization between native S. maritima and North American S. alterniflora.

* Molecular genetic features such as microsatellites, mitochondrial DNA, and single-nucleotide polymorphisms have been used to trace sources and routes of invasions. A major finding is that introduced populations often combine genes derived from multiple source populations, producing novel genetic combinations. Some introduced populations arising from multiple sources have more genetic variation than any single source population. Environmental DNA (eDNA) is increasingly used to detect invaders and played a key role in showing the great advance of Asian carp toward the Great Lakes.

* The burst of research in the wake of the SCOPE project also revealed an increasing number of cases of "invasional meltdown," in which two or more introduced species facilitate one another's establishment or enhance one another's impact on native species. An increasing number of "lag effects

<summary>
• This study found no significant association between objectively measured physical activity levels and sedentary behavior with levels of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) and intrahepatic lipid (IHL) in adults with overweight or obesity.
• The findings suggest that traditional risk factors such as waist circumference, triglycerides, fasting glucose, or fasting insulin may predict the incidence of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) or high levels of VAT, but physical activity levels and sedentary behavior do not.</summary>

<summary>
• The nasopharyngeal bursa originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut, specifically the pharyngeal endoderm. It is believed to be a remnant of embryonic communication between the notochord and the roof of the pharynx that normally disappears during the second month of intrauterine fetal development. A tornwaldt's cyst develops if the embryonic remnant becomes obstructed, and if crusts adhere to the orifice without obstruction, this will form the crust type.

• The cystic type of nasopharyngeal bursitis is more common and should form part of the differential diagnosis of nasopharyngeal abscesses and cysts. Although most patients are symptom-free, some will develop bursitis, a cyst, or an abscess. The symptoms are of either a space-occupying lesion or rhinitis, including nasal obstruction, eustachian tube obstruction with secretory otitis media, dysphagia, cranial nerve paralysis, choanal discharge, halitosis, pharyngitis, laryngitis, and bronchitis.

• The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is approximately 4% in adults, but it can appear at any age. The peak incidence occurs between 15 and 30 years, with a Caucasian predominance and no gender predilection. Most of the published literature comprises selected case reports and describes the cystic type.

• A two-year clinicoanatomical audit of nasopharyngeal bursitis at a rhinology practice in a university unit during 2008-2009 was conducted. All patients diagnosed to have nasopharyngeal bursitis confirmed by endoscopic examination of the nasopharynx and computed tomography scan/magnetic resonance imaging were asked carefully about symptoms of Tornwaldt's syndrome. A surgical technique combining an endonasal and transoral approach in the form of disruption of the bursa with electrocauterization was performed to patients presenting with either the cyst type or the crust type.

• The results of the current audit indicated that six patients were diagnosed to have nasopharyngeal bursitis, with an incidence of less than 1% of all rhinitis patients seen during the study period. Two patients with classical Tornwaldt's cyst and one with a fibrosed Tornwaldt's cyst were identified, while three patients with crust

<summary>
* The incidence of melanoma skin cancer has been increasing over the past few decades, with an estimated 76,250 new cases diagnosed in the USA in 2012, resulting in 9,180 deaths. Australia has one of the highest rates of skin cancer in the world. Early diagnosis of melanoma is crucial for prognosis, but dermoscopy, a non-invasive diagnostic technique, can be subjective and dependent on the expertise of the dermatologist. Dermoscopy enables better diagnosis compared to the unaided eye, with an improvement in diagnostic sensitivity of 10-30%.

* Dermoscopy images often contain artifacts such as uneven illumination, dermoscopic gel, black frames, ink markings, rulers, air bubbles, and intrinsic cutaneous features that can affect border detection. Preprocessing steps are necessary to remove these artifacts and facilitate the segmentation process. Image resizing, masking, cropping, hair removal, and conversion from RGB color to intensity grey image are common preprocessing techniques. These techniques can help reduce the ill effects of artifacts and enhance the image.

* Segmentation refers to the partitioning of an image into disjoint regions that are homogeneous with respect to a chosen property such as luminance, color, and texture. The goal of segmentation is to simplify and/or change the representation of an image into something that is more meaningful and easier to analyze. Manual border detection is better than computer-detected borders in order to separate the problems of feature extraction from the problems of automated lesion border detection. However, for the development of automated diagnostic systems, it is essential to develop automatic segmentation algorithms.

* Feature extraction is a critical step in the image analysis process, where the purpose is to reduce the original data set by measuring certain properties or features that differentiate one input pattern from another. Feature extraction is performed by measurements on the pixels that represent a segmented object, allowing various features to be computed. Different feature extraction methods found in the literature include statistical and model-based and filtering-based methods. Multichannel filtering is the most efficient and accurate method.

* The ABCD-E system, 7-point checklist, 3-point checklist, pattern analysis, and Menzies method offer alternative approaches in deciding the differentiating features that need to be extracted. The automatic extraction of characteristics that take into account the rule ABCD is computationally less expensive than the ones that take into account 7-point checklist or the Menzies method. However, ABCD is more prone to over-classification of atypical melanocytic nevi as melanomas. The Men

<summary>
* Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a chronic disease characterized by high blood glucose levels, resulting from insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency. The International Diabetes Federation (IDF) reported that 366 million people worldwide have diabetes, and this number is expected to rise to 552 million by 2030. T2D is a significant burden on society, with complications such as cardiovascular disease, renal failure, and blindness. Approximately 90% of patients with diabetes have T2D, which is often caused by a combination of lifestyle and genetic factors.

* The peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor coactivator 1 (PGC-1) gene is a multifunctional regulatory factor involved in mitochondrial biosynthesis, fatty acid oxidation, and glucose transport. Genetic association studies have shown that PGC-1 loci are associated with T2D in different populations. The estrogen-related receptor-alpha (ESRRa) protein binds to PGC-1 and regulates the expression of the mitofusin-2 (MFN2) gene. ESRRa is an orphan nuclear receptor that plays a vital role in regulating cell functions such as mitochondrial biogenesis and carbohydrate metabolism.

* MFN2 is a mitochondrial fusion protein that regulates mitochondrial morphology and distribution. Tissues with high energetic requirements, such as skeletal muscle and heart, show high expression of MFN2. MFN2 plays a crucial role in oxidative metabolism and ER-mitochondria juxtaposition, and its repression reduces glucose oxidation and mitochondrial membrane potential. The MFN2-dependent mechanism of mitochondrial control is disturbed in skeletal muscle in animal or human obesity and in patients with T2D.

* This study aimed to evaluate the associations between MFN2 and ESRRa genetic polymorphisms and T2D in Han Chinese populations. The study included 1204 unrelated subjects, comprising 555 patients with T2D and 649 non-diabetic control subjects. The clinical characteristics of the subjects were summarized in Table 1. The study used tagging single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to capture common variations across the MFN2 and ESRRa gene regions.

* The study found that the A allele and C allele frequencies of rs873458 and rs2878677 in the MFN2 gene were lower in the diabetic group than in the control group. The genotype distributions of rs873458 and rs2878677 were significantly different in case-control subjects. Replicating the two associated SNPs in stage 2 populations, the study

<summary>
* Oral health is crucial for the quality of life of individuals of all age groups, and oral lesions can lead to discomfort, pain, and interference with daily activities. The World Health Organization (WHO) considers a population aging more than 60 years old to be an elderly population.
* A study was conducted to find the prevalence of oral mucosal lesions in 5,100 geriatric patients in India, with 3,100 men and 2,000 women aged 60 to 98 years participating. The study found that 64% of the patients presented with various oral lesions, with males being more affected than females.
* The most common oral lesions found in the study were nicotinic stomatitis (43%), denture stomatitis (34%), and oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF) (30%). The hard palate was the most commonly affected site, followed by the tongue and gingiva.
* The study's findings were compared to other studies, which showed varying prevalence rates of oral mucosal lesions in the elderly population. The study's results highlighted the importance of considering socioeconomic differences, medical and dental history, and treatment expenditure when assessing oral health in the elderly.
* The study's conclusions emphasized the need for community programs to educate the elderly population about oral health and the importance of screening for oral mucosal lesions. Further research is needed to investigate the associations between denture-related lesions, systemic diseases, and medication use.</summary>

<summary>
* A retrospective study conducted in a tertiary eye care hospital in North India found that fireworks-related eye injuries during the Diwali festival resulted in significant ocular morbidity and visual loss, with 13.2% of eyes having vision worse than 3/60.
* The study emphasizes the need for public awareness, strong legislation, and regulation of consumer fireworks to reduce the preventable cause of ocular morbidity, especially in younger populations, and suggests promoting firework displays at public places by professionals as a safer alternative.</summary>

* The study aimed to assess the impact of PON1 (Q192R) and CYP2C19*2 polymorphisms on clopidogrel platelet inhibition in a North American study population of mixed racial background. The study included 151 patients with established coronary artery disease who were on dual antiplatelet therapy with clopidogrel and aspirin. The patients were genotyped for CYP2C19*2, CYP2C19*3, and PON1 (Q192R) single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). The study found that PON1 QQ192 was not associated with increased platelet aggregation induced by adenosine diphosphate (ADP) at various concentrations during clopidogrel therapy.

* The study also found that PON1 QQ192 was not associated with increased VN-P2Y12 reactivity, and there was a trend towards lower platelet reactivity in PON1 QQ192 individuals. Carriers of CYP2C19*2 alleles had higher platelet aggregation and higher VN-P2Y12 reactivity with significantly lower VN platelet inhibition than noncarriers. The study suggests that PON1 Q192R polymorphisms may not be predictive of clopidogrel response when measured by light transmittance aggregometry (LTA) and VN-P2Y12 assay in patients with coronary artery disease.

* The study confirms the previously reported impact of reduced-function CYP2C19*2 polymorphism on platelet inhibition by clopidogrel. CYP2C19*2 carrier status was associated with reduced platelet inhibition, as measured by VN-P2Y12 assay and LTA 10 mol/L, and increased on-treatment platelet reactivity, as measured by both LTA and VN-P2Y12 assay. The study suggests that CYP2C19*2 polymorphism is a strong determinant of reduced active clopidogrel metabolite formation, increased on-treatment ADP-induced platelet reactivity, and clinical ischemic events after coronary stenting. The presence of one reduced-function allele was associated with a hazard ratio of 2.67 and the presence of two reduced-function alleles was associated with a hazard ratio of 3.97 for the occurrence of stent thrombosis.

* The study found that there were no significant differences in platelet inhibition among homozygous carriers of reduced-function PON1 (QQ192) and QR192 and RR192 genotypes

* Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii, which can be transmitted to humans through contact with infected cat feces or contaminated food and water. Most people with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic, but it can cause serious health problems in pregnant women and individuals with weakened immune systems. Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when the parasite is transmitted from the mother to the fetus during pregnancy, and it can cause a range of health problems, including seizures, hydrocephalus, and mental retardation. In some cases, congenital toxoplasmosis can cause mesial temporal lobe epilepsy, a type of epilepsy that is resistant to medication.

* A 34-year-old woman with congenital toxoplasmosis presented with medically intractable seizures, hydrocephalus, and decreased visual acuity. She had a history of seizures since childhood and had been taking anti-epileptic medication, but her seizures were not well controlled. She underwent a series of tests, including MRI, EEG, and SPECT, which showed evidence of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy and a calcified nodule in the perihippocampal area. The patient's seizures were characterized by psychic aura, anxiety, and secondary generalized seizures.

* The patient's diagnosis was confirmed by a toxoplasma-specific serologic test, which showed positive IgG and negative IgM results, indicating a chronic infection. The patient's mother reported that her seizures started with psychic aura and anxiety, followed by secondary generalized seizures. The patient's seizures were not well controlled with medication, and she was referred to an epilepsy clinic for further evaluation and management. The patient underwent video-EEG monitoring, which showed evidence of complex partial seizures and secondary generalized seizures.

* The patient's brain MRI showed multifocal encephalomalacic changes, left hippocampal sclerosis, and left amygdala hypertrophy, which are characteristic findings in mesial temporal lobe epilepsy. The patient's SPECT and SISCOM results showed ictal hyperperfusion in the bilateral frontotemporal areas, more pronounced on the left side. The patient's FDG-PET results showed focal hypermetabolism in the left medial temporal cortex, compatible with postictal status. The patient's Wada test results showed right hemisphere language and memory dominance, predictive of good outcome after left anteromesial temporal resection.
