• Approximately 20 million people in the US have gallstones, and 1 million new patients are diagnosed with cholelithiasis every year, making it the most costly digestive disease with an estimated annual cost of over $5 billion. The National Institute of Health convened a consensus development conference in 1992 to discuss the treatment of cholelithiasis and laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The panel concluded that laparoscopic cholecystectomy offered substantial advantages over traditional open cholecystectomy with no apparent increase in morbidity or mortality. This reduction in pain and disability led to the conclusion that treatment costs would be equal to or slightly less than the cost of open cholecystectomy.

• The disability and loss of income following standard open cholecystectomy further increase costs, but these items are generally not measured by traditional appraisal methods. This convalescent period and, consequently, costs have been greatly reduced by laparoscopic cholecystectomy. This example of cost analysis should be requested by business and possibly patients, as they are impacted the most. Indeed, charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy often surpass those of open cholecystectomy.

• Surgeons at Maricopa Medical Center identified excessive length-of-stay and charges by comparing the cholecystectomy DRG with 16 other hospitals in the region. The remainder were either old patients with complications or young patients with advanced disease and complicated courses. Little could be done to reduce charges except to either lessen the conversion rates or costs for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. In order to get a precise estimate of laparoscopic charges, match pair comparisons from the same data base of charges between open cholecystectomy and converted laparoscopic cholecystectomy were accomplished.

• Since the comparisons matched age, sex, and similar diagnosis, many confounding variables could be eliminated. This suggested that the only reasons for the increased charges were the charges for laparoscopy. Other reasons for conversion, such as intraoperative complications, were eliminated because none of the matched pairs had serious complications or concomitant disease. Therefore, this comparison provided a relatively straightforward technique for statistical comparison to determine the charges for laparoscopy.

• A retrospective review of 70 cholecystectomy patients was conducted from a four-year data base of 633 patients who had undergone cholecystectomy. Thirty-five patients with converted laparoscopic cholecystectomies and thirty-five patients with open cholecystectomies were selected from

<summary>
* Subclinical hypothyroidism (SCH) is a common disorder characterized by elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with normal free thyroxine (FT4) levels. It is often associated with chronic autoimmune thyroiditis and can lead to various adverse health outcomes, including cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality. SCH can also lead to impaired systolic and diastolic cardiac function, increased vascular stiffness, and endothelial dysfunction. The prevalence of SCH varies according to population, age, sex, and region, and its clinical significance is still a topic of debate.
* The treatment of SCH is considered only for patients who are pregnant, infertile, exhibit associated symptoms, or have a high risk of progression to overt hypothyroidism. However, the evidence supporting screening for SCH and the benefits and risks of its treatment remain controversial. Some studies have shown that T4 replacement therapy can improve cardiovascular function, endothelial function, and carotid intima-media thickness in patients with SCH. The European Commission has funded a trial, the TRUST study, to assess the multimodal effects of thyroid hormone replacement in older adults with persistent SCH.</summary>

<summary>
• Type 1 diabetes is characterized by the progressive autoimmune destruction of pancreatic cells, leading to insulinopenia and symptoms. The administration of exogenous insulin can restore glucose homeostasis, and some patients experience a reduction in daily insulin requirements, known as partial remission (PR) or the "honeymoon period." PR is variable in intensity and duration, and its underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. Restoration of residual β-cell mass activity in an insulin-sensitive environment is believed to account for the condition.

• The definition of PR was recently revised based on insulin-dose-adjusted A1c (IDAA1c) levels, which correlate with stimulated C-peptide levels. The study aimed to evaluate the characteristics and potential determinants of PR according to the new definition and its impact on long-term type 1 diabetes evolution. The study included 242 children with type 1 diabetes, followed up from diagnosis to adulthood. The patients were divided into three age subgroups: 0-4 years, 5-9 years, and >10 years.

• The study found that PR occurred in 56.2% of patients, without any case of complete remission. The proportion of girls and boys was comparable among remitters and non-remitters. Mean age at diagnosis was 8.8 years, with no difference between subgroups. Height and BMI z-scores were similar between subgroups and comparable to the distribution of healthy Belgian children.

• The study found that the absence of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) at diagnosis was significantly higher in PR patients than in non-PR patients. Multivariate logistic regression analysis showed that the chances of PR were higher when there was no DKA at diagnosis. The study also found that lower A1c levels at diagnosis were associated with higher chances of PR. However, A1c levels at diagnosis did not correlate with PR duration when analyzed for all patients.

• The study found that A1c levels at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months after diagnosis were strongly associated with PR duration. Low A1c levels were associated with longer PR durations, while high A1c levels were associated with shorter PR durations. The study also found that C-peptide secretion was significantly different in PR versus non-PR patients, from diagnosis until 3 years after diagnosis. Higher baseline C-peptide concentrations were observed in patients entering PR compared to patients without PR.

• The study found that PR duration or A1c+2y levels did not correlate with the occurrence of

<summary>
• Chondroblastoma is a rare osseous tumor that accounts for less than 1% of all primary bone tumors, typically affecting the epiphyseal regions of tubular bones. It can also occur in the head and neck region, particularly in the temporal bone or temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

• Chondroblastoma in the temporal bone can cause various symptoms, including occlusal abnormalities, trismus, clicking of the TMJ, hearing impairments, dizziness, and otorrhea. These symptoms can be challenging to diagnose due to their similarity to other conditions.

• Malignant changes in chondroblastoma have been observed after irradiation, making radiation therapy an unsuitable treatment option. Instead, complete surgical removal is recommended for the curative treatment of chondroblastoma.

• A 41-year-old male patient presented with a history of chronic hearing loss, trismus, and TMJ disorder, which were initially misdiagnosed as otitis media and giant cell tumor. The patient underwent several unsuccessful treatments before being referred to the department.

• Imaging analysis, including CT scans and MRI, revealed a tumor mass in the middle cranial fossa, including the TMJ and cochlea. Histopathologic examination showed extensive proliferation of multinucleated giant cells, indicating chondroblastoma.

• The patient underwent a generous C-shaped postauricular incision, followed by neck dissection, total parotidectomy, and radical mastoidectomy. Subtotal resection of the temporal bone and skull base dissection with resection of the TMJ was also performed.

• Reconstruction of the facial tissue was carried out using the sternocleidomastoid muscle flap, which allowed the patient to open his mouth to 40 mm without pain. The patient had no clinical evidence of tumor recurrence four and a half years after surgery.

• The study highlights the importance of accurate diagnosis, especially for masses in the temporal bone, as tumors like chondroblastoma can become malignant under inappropriate treatment. A combined radiotherapeutic-surgical approach may provoke neoplastic transformation in the residual tumor tissues of chondroblastoma.

• The presence of S-100 protein in tumor cells differentiates chondroblastoma from giant cell tumor, chondrosarcoma, and aneurismal bone cysts, favoring the diagnosis of chondroblastoma. The presence of associated aneurismal bone cysts is a supplemental criterion for

<summary>
* The study explores the metabolic interactions between pairs of E. coli auxotrophs, which are strains that lack the ability to synthesize certain essential metabolites. The researchers found that certain pairs of auxotrophs can complement each other's growth in minimal media by cross-feeding essential metabolites, a relationship referred to as synthetic mutualism in trans (SMIT).
* The study used a combination of experimental and computational approaches to analyze the SMIT interactions and found that the growth of a given strain relates to its level of cooperation, as inferred from the growth of its partner strain. The researchers also developed a quantitative and predictive theoretical model that reveals the extent to which complex metabolic interactions emerge from the relatively simple topology of the biochemical reaction network.
* The study's findings have implications for our understanding of metabolic interactions in microbial communities and the evolution of cooperation. The researchers suggest that the metabolites most readily exchanged are those of little value to the secreting strain, consistent with proposals that byproduct cooperation evolves more readily than other forms of cooperation.</summary>

<summary>
• Brooke-Spiegler syndrome (BSS) is a rare genodermatosis characterized by the progressive formation of adnexal skin tumors in the scalp and face, mainly trichoepiteliomas, cylindromas, and spiradenomas.
• BSS is due to mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CYLD (cylindromatosis gene) on chromosome 16q12q13, with around 93 different mutations identified so far.
• The study of the CYLD gene in patients and their relatives can provide molecular diagnosis and appropriate genetic counseling.
• A 71-year-old woman was evaluated for progressive development of asymptomatic lesions in her head, which were diagnosed as spiradenomas and cylindromas.
• The patient's family history revealed an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern of the disease, with multiple affected relatives.
• Genetic testing revealed a heterozygous mutation c.1628_1629delct in the CYLD gene in the patient and her two affected daughters.
• The mutation is associated with a low risk of malignancy, but patients require long-term follow-up due to the risk of salivary gland neoplasms and other tumors.
• The case highlights the importance of correct diagnosis, periodic follow-up, and genetic counseling for patients with BSS and their family members.</summary>

<summary>
* The study evaluated the diagnostic accuracy and impact of the Xpert vanA/vanB assay on infection control decision-making in a setting with vanA Enterococcus faecium outbreaks. The assay was performed directly on rectal swabs and results were available within 1 hour, allowing for rapid implementation of infection control measures.
* The study found that the vanA PCR had a high diagnostic accuracy, with a sensitivity of 87.1% and specificity of 99.7%, and had a considerable impact on infection control decision-making, saving 141 isolation days and 292 transmission risk days. The vanB PCR, however, had a low specificity and positive predictive value, likely due to the presence of vanB-positive anaerobic bacteria.
* The study also found that the use of the Xpert vanA/vanB assay led to faster control of VRE outbreaks and reduced the need for isolation precautions, resulting in cost savings and reduced psychosocial consequences for patients and staff. The assay's official price in Denmark was 661 DKK (approximately 89 USD) per sample, which was considered worth the cost given the benefits.
* The study's findings suggest that the Xpert vanA/vanB assay is a valuable tool for infection control in settings with VRE outbreaks, and that its use can lead to improved patient outcomes and reduced healthcare costs. However, further studies are needed to confirm the generalizability of the results and to evaluate the assay's performance in different settings.</summary>

<summary>
* Biological scaffold materials derived from dermis, pericardium, and small intestine submucosa have been used for soft tissue repair applications, but they are expensive and exhibit substantial variability.
* Permanent synthetic polymer mesh materials are not typically used in contaminated settings due to the risk of infection, but biological scaffolds can be used as an alternative.
* Early designs of absorbable polymer scaffolds, such as Dexon and Vicryl, have been developed, but they lose mechanical strength and are resorbed quickly, making them less ideal for hernia repair applications.
* More recent absorbable scaffold designs, such as Gore Bio-A, Tigr Matrix, and Phasix Mesh, have been developed to utilize long-lasting polymers that degrade more slowly.
* Phasix Mesh is a fully resorbable polymer monofilament that is knitted into a flat sheet configuration, and it has been evaluated in a porcine model for hernia repair applications.
* The study found that Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug repairs demonstrated similar burst strengths and relative stiffness at all time points, and they were significantly greater than the native abdominal wall.
* The molecular weight of Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug decreased significantly over time, but significant material resorption did not correspond with a significant drop in mechanical strength at the repair site.
* Histological analyses revealed a comparable and mild inflammatory response and mild to moderate granulation tissue/vascularization associated with the P4HB material regardless of its configuration as a mesh or a plug.
* The study suggests that Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug can provide durable scaffolds for soft tissue repair in a porcine model, with significant mechanical strength and a mild foreign body response.
</summary>

<summary>
* The anaerobic gram-positive bacillus Clostridium difficile is a leading cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, and its diagnosis is often based on enzyme immunoassay (EIA) results. However, EIA has low detection sensitivity for C. difficile toxins, which can lead to false-negative results.
* A study was conducted to investigate patients with EIA toxin-negative stool specimens and toxin-positive isolates, and to compare their clinical characteristics with those of patients with toxin-positive stool specimens. The study found that patients with toxin-negative stool specimens had shorter diarrhea duration and milder symptoms.
* The study included 68 patients who underwent EIA testing for C. difficile toxins, and were divided into three groups based on their EIA results: toxin-positive stool, toxin-negative stool/toxin-positive isolate, and toxin-negative stool and isolate. The study found that patients with toxin-negative stool specimens had shorter diarrhea duration and were less likely to receive treatment.
* The study also found that there were no significant differences in clinical characteristics, such as comorbidities, malignant tumors, and recent history of transplant, among the three groups. However, patients with toxin-positive stool specimens were more likely to receive vancomycin or metronidazole treatment.
* The study suggests that patients with toxin-negative stool specimens may be colonized with non-toxigenic C. difficile, or may have toxin concentrations below the detection sensitivity of EIA. Further studies are needed to determine the genetic characteristics of C. difficile isolates from patients with toxin-negative stool specimens.
* The study highlights the limitations of EIA testing for C. difficile toxins, and suggests that nucleic acid amplification tests may be more sensitive for detecting toxigenic C. difficile. However, these tests do not evaluate toxin production, and may not accurately reflect the patient's disease status.
* The study concludes that patients with EIA toxin-negative stool specimens may not require treatment for C. difficile-associated diarrhea, and that further studies are needed to determine the optimal treatment approach for these patients. However, these patients may still be at risk of transmitting the bacteria to others, and require care from the perspective of preventing hospital infection.
</summary>

<summary>
• The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) plays a crucial role in cardiovascular diseases, and local tissue RAAS has been implicated in the pathology of these diseases.
• Aldosterone activates its mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) in the heart, leading to structural and electrical remodeling, fibrosis, oxidative stress, inflammation, and arrhythmias.
• MR antagonists have shown significant benefits in patients with left ventricular dysfunction and myocardial infarction, but their effects in diabetes are unclear.
• Inhibitors of RAAS, such as angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin type-1 receptor blockers (ARBs), have been shown to protect against hypertension and diabetes-induced end-organ damage.
• However, ACEIs and ARBs do not completely block end-organ damage in diabetes and hypertension, and clinical trials have shown that combining them does not offer added benefits but rather leads to greater adverse effects.
• The study aimed to characterize and compare the effects of RU28318 (RU, a selective MR antagonist), captopril (CAPT, an ACEI), and losartan (LOS, an ARB) alone or in combination on ischemia/reperfusion-induced cardiac dysfunction in isolated hearts from normal and diabetic rats.
• The results showed that triple therapy (CAPT + LOS + RU) was the most effective treatment in preventing or reversing ischemia-induced cardiac dysfunction in normal and diabetic hearts.
• In diabetic hearts, CAPT + LOS dual therapy was the most effective therapy, consistent with the known diabetes-induced overactivity of the ACE/ang II/AT1 signaling cascade.
• The study suggests that MR antagonists, such as RU, may represent a novel class of RAAS inhibitor that could overcome the limitations observed with ACEI and ARB combinations.
• The findings have important clinical implications for the administration of these drugs in cardiac dysfunction, particularly in diabetic patients, and suggest that local administration of MR antagonists may be an effective therapy or preventative measure in cardiac ischemia/reperfusion injury.
</summary>

<summary>
* The DREAM trial was a large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial designed to determine whether ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay the development of type 2 diabetes in people with impaired fasting glucose (IFG) or impaired glucose tolerance (IGT). The trial included 5,269 participants with these disorders who were recruited and randomized to either ramipril and/or rosiglitazone.

* A substudy of 982 participants attending Canadian study centers had oral glucose tolerance tests (OGTTs) at baseline, after 2 years, and at the end of the study, with blood samples drawn fasting as well as 30 and 120 minutes after the glucose challenge. The primary outcome variable was change in β-cell function over the course of follow-up.

* β-cell function was assessed using two measures: the insulinogenic index (IGI) and proinsulin (PI) concentration, with IGI defined as (30-min insulin - fasting insulin)/(30-min glucose - fasting glucose). Both indexes have previously been validated against gold-standard measures of insulin secretion.

* Rosiglitazone significantly increased IGI/IR and reduced PI/C by 86 and 42%, respectively, in people with IFG and/or IGT. These findings were consistent across glucose tolerance subgroups (IIFG, IIGT, and IFG+IGT), although there was the suggestion of a more modest effect in the subgroup with IIFG.

* The impact of rosiglitazone on diabetes prevention persisted after adjustment for baseline β-cell function. The demonstration that an agent that reduces diabetes incidence also improves β-cell function invites the hypothesis that measures of change in β-cell function in response to therapy are indexes of that therapy's ability to reduce the incidence of diabetes.

* Ramipril did not significantly affect adjusted IGI or PI concentrations, and its glucose-lowering effects may operate through other metabolic mechanisms. The improvement in β-cell function in the placebo arm of the ramipril marginal group analysis may be explained by the fact that under the factorial design of the DREAM trial, half of the participants on ramipril placebo were receiving active rosiglitazone.

* The major strengths of the present study include the large sample size, the randomized, double-blind design, and the completeness of follow-up (92.6%). The major limitation of the present study is the lack of detailed measures of β-cell function, such as those obtained from the hyperglyc

<summary>
* Modern nasal surgery aims to improve both the cosmetic appearance and natural functions of the nose. Objective measurement of airway patency is crucial in modern respiratory medicine. Acoustic rhinometry (AR) is a common method used to measure nasal cavity geometry, which has proven to be a great challenge for researchers. AR has demonstrated a close correlation with the cross-sectional area of the nasal airway measured by rhinomanometry.

* The study evaluated changes in nasal dimensions of healthy Iranian volunteers who underwent cosmetic rhinoplasty using AR. The cases were all healthy, without any prior history of nose surgery, fracture, allergy, or asthma, and had no complaint about nasal obstruction. All cases were Iranian, aged at least 18, and visited the ENT clinic of Rassul-e-Akram Teaching Hospital between 2006 and 2008. The surgeries were open rhinoplasty with or without septoplasty.

* The device used in the measurements consisted of a sound source and a microphone, and all measurements were performed after a short period of acclimatization in a relatively quiet room. The measurements were performed during a breathing pause while patients were in a sitting position. The nosepiece used in the measurements was 5 cm in length and was anatomically sculptured. A small amount of ultrasound transmission gel was applied to the edge of the nosepiece to ensure a tight connection.

* The study found that bilateral d2 and volume did not change significantly postoperatively, while bilateral d1 and both minimum cross-sectional areas (MCA2) decreased significantly. A significant increase was observed in MCA1 postoperatively. The study also found that cases with septoplasty would experience more increase in MCA1 and less constriction in MCA2 postoperatively. The effect of osteotomy on patency of the nose in cases with septoplasty was more prominent at the level of MCA1.

* Placing a columellar strut in group of cases of rhinoplasty plus septoplasty had a significant effect both at MCA1 and MCA2 levels. In cases of rhinoplasty alone, placing a columellar strut caused a greater amount of increase in MCA1. MCA2 after decongestion significantly increased in group without columellar strut, but it did not change in group with replacing a columellar strut. Regression analysis of difference after surgery in MCA1, MCA2, and volume revealed no fix significant effect for septoplasty, osteotomy, and

<summary>
• Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in many economically developed nations, accounting for about 30% of all deaths, and its incidence is still increasing. Ongoing research aims to investigate and prevent the early development of cardiovascular risk factors such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance. The beneficial effects of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) were proved in several observational and experimental studies. The lipid-lowering action of n-3 PUFAs was detected at the beginning, so these nutrients were used for the treatment of dyslipidemic disorders.

• Low-grade chronic inflammation is now recognized as a prominent process in the development of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease. The induction of inflammation may well provide a link between hyperlipidemia and atherogenesis. Atherosclerosis is now considered a systemic disease featured by low-grade arterial inflammatory lesions that can develop through the disease progression. In physiological conditions, endothelial cells synthesize and release adequate amounts of nitric oxide (NO) and prostaglandins.

• Unsaturated fatty acids are referred to as PUFAs when two or more double bounds are present. There are two PUFAs families, omega-3 (n-3) and omega-6 (n-6) fatty acids. They differ in location of the last double bond relative to the terminal methyl end of the molecule. The human body can produce almost all fatty acids, except linoleic acid (LA, C18:2 n-6, precursor to the n-6 series of fatty acids) and α-linoleic acid (ALA, C18:3n-3, precursor to the n-3 series of fatty acids).

• These two PUFAs are named essential fatty acids because the body cannot synthesize them. Endogenous conversion (elongation and desaturation) of the initial C18 PUFAs precursors results in the synthesis of longer-chain counterparts such as eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in the n-3 family and dihomo-γ-linoleic acid (DGLA) and arachidonic acid (AA) in the n-6 family. In humans, the biochemical pathways converting ALA to EPA and EPA to DHA are limited. Results from pilot studies suggest that ALA conversion is also limited to function as a surrogate for fish consumption.

<summary>
• The understanding of H. pylori-induced inflammation leading to cancer is built on the work of three pioneering pathologists: Rudolf Virchow, Pelayo Correa, and Robin Warren. Virchow is widely regarded as the father of modern pathology and proposed that cancer arises from initially normal cells in response to chronic irritation or inflammation.

• Correa developed a model for gastric cancer development, hypothesizing that the development of intestinal-type gastric cancer results from a stepwise process beginning with chronic atrophic gastritis and progressing to intestinal metaplasia and cancer over 30-50 years. The initial changes were postulated to occur in the first decade of life, which is now known to be when H. pylori colonization occurs.

• Warren and Barry Marshall discovered H. pylori and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, and they were aware of the relationship between gastritis and cancer. Marshall speculated that H. pylori may have a part to play in other poorly understood gastritis-associated diseases, including gastric cancer.

• Initial investigations into a possible association between H. pylori and gastric cancer provided weak evidence for a link, but subsequent studies, including three large cohorts with nested case-controls, found that evidence of prior H. pylori infection was significantly more common in those who developed gastric cancer. The World Health Organization declared H. pylori a definite carcinogen in 1994.

• Research has confirmed and expanded upon the early epidemiologic studies, finding that cardia cancers are not strongly associated with H. pylori infection, and that H. pylori is a risk factor for both intestinal-type and diffuse-type gastric cancer. Measuring H. pylori exposure by ELISA underestimates prior exposure, and CagA-positive H. pylori strains increase the risk of gastric cancer.

• H. pylori eradication can reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer, and recent meta-analyses have found that eradication decreases the risk by approximately 40% in studies of primary prevention and by 54% as a tertiary prevention strategy. However, it is not known whether there is a point of no return along the Correa pathway beyond which H. pylori eradication will not prevent progression to gastric cancer.

• The results of recent intervention studies have prompted renewed interest in screening for H. pylori and eradicating the organism as a potentially cost-effective strategy, especially in parts of the world with high H. pylori and gastric cancer prevalence. Pilot studies have shown promising results, including

<summary>
• Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (NAMD) is a leading cause of visual loss among the elderly population, and intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) agents have been effective in treating the condition. Before the introduction of anti-VEGF agents, treatment options were limited, and only a few patients achieved prevention of visual acuity loss. The introduction of bevacizumab and ranibizumab has led to significant improvements in visual acuity and prevention of visual loss.

• This study aimed to compare the functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab therapy to ranibizumab therapy on an as-needed treatment regimen for NAMD in Turkish patients. The study included 79 patients in the bevacizumab group and 74 patients in the ranibizumab group, with similar baseline characteristics. The patients were followed up for a minimum of 12 months, and the mean follow-up time was approximately 18 months.

• The results showed that both groups had significant improvements in visual acuity and central retinal thickness (CRT) at all time points. However, there was no statistically significant difference between the two groups in terms of change in visual acuity and CRT. The mean number of injections at month 12 was similar between the two groups, with 4.8 injections in the bevacizumab group and 4.7 injections in the ranibizumab group.

• The study found that 86.1% of patients in the bevacizumab group and 86.5% of patients in the ranibizumab group had stable or improved visual acuity after a mean follow-up time of approximately 18 months. The visual and anatomical outcomes and the number of injections were similar between the two drugs. The patients with NAMD treated with as-needed bevacizumab or as-needed ranibizumab showed significant improvements in visual acuity throughout at least 1.5 years compared to baseline visual acuity.

• The study's findings are consistent with previous studies, including the CATT study, which found that bevacizumab and ranibizumab had similar efficacy and safety profiles. However, the safety issue remains a debate, and further studies are needed to address this issue. The study's strengths include the fact that patients in both groups had received no other forms of treatment and had similar baseline characteristics.</summary>

<summary>
* Preeclampsia (PE) is a leading cause of maternal and neonatal mortality and morbidity, complicating 25% of all pregnancies. The presence of proteinuria in women with gestational hypertension is clinically diagnosed as PE. However, several studies have shown that proteinuria is not a significant predictor of adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes. The incidence of the disease increased in China after the implementation of the two-child policy.

* Hypoalbuminemia occurs mainly due to systemic small vessel spasm, increased secretion of angiotensin, and damaged and increased permeability of vascular endothelial cells. This leads to a large number of proteins and liquid leaking in tissue clearance and a loss of a large number of plasma proteins, causing intravascular dehydration. Intravascular dehydration may accelerate the appearance of intravascular lesions, which is thought to be a predisposing factor of the hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet (HELLP) syndrome and acute fatty liver of pregnancy. The reduction of hepatic blood flow due to the production of albumin is decreased.

* The aim of the study was to evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE, according to the different value of albumin (25 g/l and <25 g/l). The study included 299 women from the Maternal and Child Health Hospital of Anhui Province, enrolled between January 2014 and June 2015. The Anhui Medical University Ethics Committee provided ethics approval, and written informed consent was obtained from all participants. The study was a retrospective cohort study.

* The study found that women with severe hypoproteinemia (SHP) were delivered almost 1.5 weeks earlier than the mild hypoproteinemia (MHP) group. The percentage of cesarean section (CS) was higher, and the rate of spontaneous delivery was lower in the SHP group. Severe hypertension was more frequent in the SHP group than in the MHP group. Women with SHP were more likely to present with abnormal liver or renal function, ascites, and abruptio placenta.

* Neonatal outcomes were worse in the SHP group, with a lower average birth weight and a higher incidence of fetal growth restriction (FGR), neonatal intensive care unit admission, and preterm deliveries. The study found that SHP was a significant risk factor for CS, poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes in PE women. The odds ratio for CS was 2.99, and the

<summary>
* Researchers investigated the use of immunoglobulin G (IgG) responses to a panel of prostate tissue- and prostate cancer-associated antigens as a diagnostic tool to evaluate immune responses elicited following immune-active therapies.
* The study found that antigen-specific IgG responses could be detected, likely elicited as a result of therapy, and the patterns of response differed with respect to the individual therapy.
* Using a machine learning Bayesian belief network (ML-BBN) model, the researchers prioritized a cohort of antigens, immune responses to which were most associated with prostate-specific antigen (PSA) decline.
* The study suggests that, with data from larger populations of subjects, models could be developed to assist in the detection of potentially therapeutic immune responses resulting from immune-based therapies.</summary>

<summary>
• A study was conducted to estimate the serum level of L-fucose, a tumor marker, among various TNM stages in oral cancer patients and compare them with healthy individuals.
• The study consisted of 90 individuals, divided into a study group of 60 oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) patients and a control group of 30 healthy volunteers.
• The results showed a significant difference in serum L-fucose levels between OSCC patients (10.85 mg/dl) and healthy controls (3.47 mg/dl), with a difference of 7.38 mg/dl.
• Serum L-fucose levels progressively increased with the stage of cancer, with the highest level found in stage IV.
• The study found no significant correlation between serum L-fucose levels and age, gender, or histopathological tumor differentiation.
• The results suggest that serum L-fucose levels can be used as a non-invasive, cost-effective biochemical indicator of cancer detection, staging, therapeutic success, prognosis, and post-treatment evaluation.
• Elevated serum L-fucose levels have also been reported in other pathological states, such as cirrhosis, tuberculosis, and cardiovascular disorders, emphasizing the need to exclude other degenerative and proliferative diseases.
• Further investigation on a large scale is needed to prove serum L-fucose as an effective tumor marker in the diagnosis and management of oral cancer.
</summary>

<summary>
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of inherited autosomal recessive disorders that cause a deficiency in an adrenal enzyme, resulting in altered cortisol and aldosterone secretion. The most frequent CAH variant is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, accounting for 95% of all affected patients.

• The study investigated the frequency of white matter changes and temporal lobe structures dysgenesis in 26 patients with CAH due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The patients underwent neurological examination and brain MRI, and the results showed that 11 patients (42.3%) had MRI abnormalities, including white matter hyperintensities and temporal lobe atrophy.

• The mechanisms that could explain MRI lesions in CAH remain poorly understood, but hormonal imbalance and exogenous glucocorticoids may play a role in the destabilization of the myelin molecule and the alteration of neuronal maturation and myelination. Chronic hyperandrogenism, a result of non-compliance with treatment, may be the main mechanism involved in the genesis of brain MRI abnormalities.

• The study suggests that brain MRI abnormalities are an interesting finding in CAH patients and could be the consequence of hormonal imbalance during brain development and corticosteroid treatment. More extensive studies are required to define better the relationships between brain involvement and different CAH phenotypes and treatment regimens.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study explores the use of piezoelectric materials and the converse piezoelectric effect to stimulate bone growth at the bone-implant interface. The researchers used polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) films as a substrate for MC3T3 cells and found that the films can produce effective osteoblast mechanical stimulation. The study was conducted in a 4-year-old merino ewe, with the actuator device implanted in the left hind limb and a control device in the right hind limb. The results showed that the total bone area around the actuators was significantly higher than around the static controls.

• The study found that the increment of bone-occupied area was due to new bone formation, and the area occupied by woven bone and osteoid was higher in actuators than in static devices. The mineral apposition rate was also significantly higher around actuated devices than around static devices. The researchers observed a fibrous capsule surrounding both actuators and static devices, with no significant differences in capsule thickness between the two groups. Immunohistochemistry failed to detect differences in tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) expression between the two groups.

• The study suggests that piezoelectric materials and the converse piezoelectric effect can be used to effectively stimulate bone growth at the bone-implant interface, eliciting an early response. However, the researchers note that the material used (PVDF) may not be biocompatible, and further studies are needed to develop a material with improved biocompatibility. The study was performed in one animal only, but the results are clear in evidencing qualitative and quantitative statistically significant differences between static and actuated films. The researchers conclude that piezoelectric materials are excellent candidate components of actuators for clinical purposes.</summary>

<summary>
* Male Wistar rats were used to study the development of non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH), with 22 rats given lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and methylprednisolone to promote ONFH development. The rats were divided into weight-bearing (WB) and non-weight-bearing (NWB) groups, with the NWB group undergoing hindlimb unloading to prevent weight-bearing on the hindlimbs.
* The femur and humerus were harvested from each rat and processed for histopathological examination, with ONFH defined as the presence of empty lacunae or pyknotic osteocyte nuclei in the bone trabeculae, accompanied by surrounding bone marrow cell necrosis. ONFH was observed in 63.6% of WB rats and 54.5% of NWB rats, with no significant intergroup difference.
* Histopathological examination of the femoral head showed similar changes in both WB and NWB groups, including empty lacunae and decreased hematopoietic cells in the medullary space. In contrast, no humeral head osteonecrosis was observed in either group.
* The study suggests that weight-bearing does not contribute to the development of non-traumatic ONFH in rats, and that the rat model may be useful for elucidating the pathogenesis of ONFH, but may not be suitable for studying the mechanism of femoral head collapse. The aetiology, pathogenesis, and prognosis of non-traumatic ONFH remain unclear.
</summary>

<summary>
• The development of a humanized monoclonal antibody (mAb) that inhibits the interaction of VEGF-A with its receptors VEGFR-1 and VEGFR-2 has provided avenues to explore the efficacy of targeting the VEGF-A signaling pathway in cancer. The success of Avastin (or bevacizumab) in treating various human cancers has highlighted the potential of anti-angiogenic treatments.

• However, the recent withdrawal of Avastin for treating breast cancer in the United States has highlighted the limitations of anti-angiogenic treatments and the need for a careful cost-benefit analysis. The development of resistance to Avastin and the pre-existing refractoriness of some tumors suggest the role of other growth factors in sustaining tumor angiogenesis.

• Alternative ligands for the angiogenic receptor VEGFR-2, such as VEGF-C and VEGF-D, and other angiogenic factors from distinct growth factor families, are logical candidates for promoting resistance to Avastin. These factors may contribute to the development of resistance to anti-angiogenic treatments.

• Targeting VEGF-D signaling in cancer could involve mAbs specific to the VHD of VEGF-D, PTK inhibitors that block VEGFR-2 and VEGFR-3 signaling, or mAbs to VEGFR-2 and VEGFR-3. These approaches may inhibit both tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, restricting solid tumor growth and metastatic spread.

• Further studies are required to strategize effective targeting of growth factors, receptors, and PTKs, and to identify specific cancer indications in which clinical benefit can be achieved with mAbs targeting VEGF family members and their receptors. Genome-wide functional approaches, such as those using siRNA technology, may help identify effective targets for anti-cancer therapy.</summary>

<summary>
* A prototype was developed to measure the bracket debonding force in vivo, using a strain gauge connected directly to the extremity of the pliers where the bracket debonding occurs.
* The prototype was tested and compared to a universal testing machine, showing no statistically significant difference in bond strength values between the two methods.
* The results suggest that the prototype might be a useful tool for measuring bond strength in vivo, and that debonding with the prototype is a safe method for preserving the enamel surface.
* The study highlights the importance of determining bracket bond strength values in vivo, as in vitro studies may not accurately represent clinical situations.</summary>

<summary>
• Malaria remains a significant public health concern in many countries, including Iran, particularly in the south and southeast regions. Despite a substantial reduction in malaria incidence in recent years, Iran still reports cases, with Plasmodium vivax responsible for the majority of infections. The country has entered the malaria pre-elimination program since 2009, with interventions such as preventing strategies, active case detection, and timely treatment.

• The study aimed to detect low parasite and asymptomatic malaria infections using three diagnostic tests (microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR) in a low transmission region of Bagh-e-Malek in Minab district, Hormozgan province, southern Iran. The results would help further case surveillance strategies in the region and contribute to achieving malaria elimination in the country. The study was conducted as a cross-sectional survey in Bagh-e-Malek, which is located in Minab district, southeast of Hormozgan province.

• A total of 200 healthy volunteers participated in the study, with 62 males and 138 females, and their age range was from 3 to 60 years old (mean age 27.2). The entire 200 thick and thin Giemsa-stained blood smears were inspected to detect Plasmodium parasite by a well-trained microscopist, and no Plasmodium parasite was detected in any examined sample. Additionally, none of the samples was diagnosed to have any malaria parasite during the 60-days follow-up protocol, while all samples remained symptomless.

• RDTs were tested as a complementary analysis for all 200 samples using monoclonal antibody-coated sticks, and no positive result was discovered for either P. falciparum and/or non-falciparum species in the performed tests. Nested-PCR amplification was performed as a sensitive and specific method to find parasite genome in extracted DNA from asymptomatic samples. Interestingly, 3 P. vivax positive samples (1.5%) were discovered by nested-PCR using specific primers, although they were considered uninfected using microscopic and RDT tests.

• All positive cases were female, and only one of them had a malaria history 20 years prior to the time of this investigation. Moreover, no Plasmodium falciparum infection was detected by this technique for all examined samples. All infected subjects were treated after diagnosis by standard anti-malarial drugs according to the CDMC of Iran protocol and reevaluated after treatment by means of molecular method

<summary>
* Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are a common problem in infants and young children, with varying frequencies, symptoms, and causative organisms depending on sex, age, and gender. Neonates often present with non-specific signs and symptoms, requiring a complete sepsis workup and antibiotic therapy. The early choice of antibiotics is challenging due to emerging patterns of resistance.

* A study was conducted at the Bahrami Children's Hospital in Tehran, Iran, to investigate the frequency of UTI causative organisms in neonates over an eight-year period. The study included 73 cases, with a mean age of 14.14 days and a mean birth weight of 3055.85 grams. Boys constituted 69.9% of the study population, with a boys-to-girls ratio of 2.32.

* The most prevalent organism causing UTI in neonates was Escherichia coli (E. coli), accounting for 64.4% of cases, followed by Enterobacter with a relative frequency of 19.2%. Other isolated organisms included Klebsiella and Staphylococcus epidermidis. No cases of Proteus, Pseudomonas, Serratia, or Staphylococcus aureus were found.

* E. coli was found to be mostly resistant to ampicillin (93.6%), cefixime (85.7%), and cephalexin (77.3%). The most sensitivity of E. coli was towards cefotaxime (63.6%), norfloxacin (100%), and ciprofloxacin (100%). Enterobacter showed high resistance to amikacin (100%) and ampicillin (92.8%).

* Klebsiella and S. epidermidis were found to be completely resistant to ampicillin. The study's findings are in agreement with most past studies, which have reported E. coli as the leading cause of UTI in neonates. The study's results also highlight the importance of continuous assessment of uropathogen epidemiology in the neonatal period.

* The study's strengths include its large sample size, long study period, and accountability of urine samples. However, limitations include its retrospective nature, which may have led to missing cases due to incomplete records. The study's results suggest that a third-generation cephalosporin plus an aminoglycoside may be a better choice than ampicillin plus an aminoglycos

<summary>
* Lcn2 mice were generated by gene targeting in embryonic stem cells from mouse strain 129 and were backcrossed onto the B6 background for 10 generations. The mice were fed either a high-fat diet (HFD) or a regular chow diet (RCD) and were used for experiments at 14-15 weeks of age. The mice were housed in a specific pathogen-free facility at the University of Minnesota.

* Lcn2 mice gained more body weight and increased adiposity, particularly when fed an HFD or aged. The weight of white and brown fat pads was significantly higher in HFD-fed mice than in wild-type mice. Both HFD-fed and aged Lcn2 mice showed a significantly higher weight of liver, heart, kidney, and spleen.

* An analysis of indirect calorimetry measurements showed that food intake, ambulatory activity, VO2, and RQ were not significantly different between RCD-fed wild-type and Lcn2 mice at 18 weeks of age. However, Lcn2 mice displayed cold sensitivity and could not survive when exposed to 4°C for >10 hours. Lcn2 mice (seven of seven) died after being exposed to 4°C for 12 hours, while all of the wild-type mice (n = 7) in the experiment survived.

* To explore the possible mechanisms for cold intolerance in Lcn2 mice, uncoupling protein (UCP)-1-mediated thermogenic activity and capacity of brown adipose tissue (BAT) were examined. Lcn2 mice expressed significantly lower levels of UCP-1 and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR) coactivator (PGC-1) genes in BAT than wild-type mice. However, UCP-1 and PGC-1 expression in BAT were markedly stimulated at an even higher level in Lcn2 mice after exposure to 4°C for 5 hours.

* The protein expression levels of adipose triglyceride lipase (ATGL) in white adipose tissue (WAT) were slightly reduced in Lcn2 mice under the HFD and cold condition compared with wild-type mice. However, cold-induced hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) gene expression in BAT and WAT was completely diminished in Lcn2 mice. The mitochondrial oxidative capacity of BAT was also investigated, as this function of BAT is critical for providing the energy for thermogenesis.

<summary>
* The study examined the involvement of nurses in national health policy processes in Kenya, revealing that nurses were not adequately involved in policy development. The majority of nurses felt that their representation was inadequate, and they were often involved after policies had been formulated. Nonnursing decision-makers emphasized the limitation of nurse leaders' singular focus on nursing issues, while nurse leaders described the problem of inadequate representation of nurses on national policy committees. The Public Health Act, which allows doctors to be the heads of ministerial departments, affords doctors a dominant role in policy-making.

* The findings revealed that nurse leaders' participation in policy meetings was uneven, and many final policy decisions were made without nurse leaders being present. Frontline nurses and nurse managers at district levels described their primary policy role as being implementers of national policies, but they felt that their contribution could be important since nurses better understood the care environment. Nurses should be consulted before policies are started, but they lack the chance to air their views. Nurses have the education and brains, but they lack the opportunity to contribute to policy-making.

* The study identified several reasons for nurses' lack of engagement in policy formulation, including a top-down approach to policy-making, lack of knowledge about the policy-making process, and lack of skills to engage in this process. Nurse leaders concurred that nurses did not generally understand the broader issues outside nursing that were necessary to influence policies. The nursing profession was blamed for its tradition of being a "closed" professional group, concerning themselves only with professional issues and not broader issues affecting the health care system. Nurses were also perceived as being isolated from other professionals.

* The study suggested several ways to enhance nurses' participation in policy processes, including creating more opportunities for nurses to contribute to policy processes, increasing nurses' representation on policy-related structures, and reviewing the Public Health Law to allow nurses to compete for leadership positions. National policy-makers should consult frontline nurses when developing national policies, and nurse leaders should come to the ground more often and get views from frontline nurses to include in policies. Nurses should be empowered through training to enable them to better understand and participate in policy formulation. Nurses need to have general knowledge, including how the government operates, to contribute to policy-making.

* The study concluded that nurses in Kenya have not been adequately involved in national policy development, and that policy-makers should address hierarchies, domination, and gender issues inherent in the health care system. Mechanisms should be established to allow nurses' views to get to national-level decision-makers when policies are being formulated.

<summary>
• A study on the Iberian wall lizard (Podarcis hispanica) found that different populations within a small geographical area in central Spain differed in morphology and chemical signals, which could lead to premating reproductive isolation and cryptic speciation.
• The results showed that males and females from different populations could recognize and discriminate between scents of individuals from their own and other populations, suggesting that chemical signals may play a role in reproductive isolation and speciation processes.</summary>

<summary>
• The tubularized incised plate (TIP) repair is a recommended technique for distal penile hypospadias, with excellent results in primary, redo, distal, and proximal hypospadias. This study aimed to examine the role of the plate character in the success of TIP repair among 100 children with primary anterior penile hypospadias in Yemen.

• The study found that patients with a urethral plate width of less than 8 mm had a statistically significant higher fistula rate and failed 8 Fr calibration compared to those with a plate width of more than 8 mm. The results suggest that a narrow plate may be inadequate for creating a neourethra, leading to a higher fistula rate.

• The study also categorized the urethral plate character as flat, cleft, and deeply grooved, with a higher fistula rate noted in patients with flat urethral plates, although the result was not statistically significant. The findings are in agreement with previous reports, which found no significant relation between urethral plate depth and incidence of fistula.

• The study concludes that TIP urethroplasty has good cosmetic and functional results, with advantages including preservation and utilization of the urethral plate, single suture line of the neourethra, and low complication rate. However, patients with flat and narrow urethral plates may require augmentation with free grafts, such as buccal mucosal grafts, to improve outcomes.</summary>

<summary>
• The completion of the human genome draft sequence promises significant biomedical advances, but biologists must navigate the vast genomic data to uncover its secrets. To achieve this, biologists need to adopt universal vocabularies to communicate effectively across different communities. The concept of homology is crucial in annotating genes, as it allows for the prediction of protein functions based on evolutionary relationships.

• There are two common ways of annotating genes: empirical observations and predicted evolutionary relationships. Empirical annotations are essential but currently restricted to a minority of human genes, while homology-based annotations can provide approximate directions for future empirical determination of function. However, homology assignment should be treated with caution, as it may not always indicate similarities in molecular mechanism.

• Domains are homologous portions of sequences that have survived the evolutionary tests of time without fragmentation. They represent the finite vocabulary of protein evolution and can be used to annotate genes based on their component parts. Resources such as Pfam, Smart, and InterPro provide domain lexicons that can be used to annotate genes.

• The annotation of individual proteins or complete proteomes using domains is achieved automatically rather than by manual curation. This is relevant, as a newly sequenced genome's proteome is generally in a high state of flux. Automatic annotation allows for the rapid identification of domain architectures and their associated functions.

• The contribution of domain identification to gene-function prediction will remain significant until reliable results from high-throughput studies on closely related organisms are available. Comparative proteomics has played a major role in understanding the evolution of chordates, and domain architectures have been used to study the evolution of human proteins. However, the question of whether the number of representatives of a domain family is directly related to its contribution to cellular and organismal function remains open.

• Web-based resources such as LocusLink, GeneCards, and Ensembl provide views of genomes from multiple vantage points, from protein tertiary structure to human disease. These resources often fail to distinguish between experimentally derived and predicted annotations, but they are a significant boon to biologists. As biological sciences progress, the cartography of the human genome will become more complex, with numerous different functional characteristics being assigned to a growing fraction of human genes.

• The Gene Ontology project has created an initial hierarchy of defined terms that encompasses many of the flavors of 'function' commonly described in biology. Orthology prediction and the partitioning of a domain family into subfamilies with distinct functions will also guide the efficient navigation of genomes. Sophisticated web forums will accumulate

<summary>
* Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a severe form of epilepsy characterized by multiple seizure types, including tonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures, and is often associated with cognitive impairment and behavioral disorders. The syndrome is difficult to treat, and patients often experience a poor prognosis. Treatment options are limited, and many anticonvulsant medications have been shown to be ineffective or have significant side effects. Valproic acid is currently considered the most useful initial medication for LGS, but its use is limited by the risk of hepatotoxicity.
* Rufinamide is a novel anticonvulsant medication that has shown promise in the treatment of LGS, with studies demonstrating a significant reduction in seizure frequency and severity. Rufinamide has a good safety profile and is well tolerated, with minimal expected side effects. However, further studies are needed to establish its role in the treatment of LGS and to define its relationship to other medications. Additionally, patient and caretaker satisfaction data need to be obtained to fully evaluate the effectiveness of rufinamide in the treatment of LGS.</summary>

<summary>
* Heart rate monitors have been widely used in sports and sports science over the last 25 years, with the development of handy heart rate monitors and flexible chest belts allowing for easy measurement of heart rate and heart rate variability. The validity and reliability of these tools have been shown to be high compared to ECG measurements. Recent technical development has focused on real-time monitoring, and several different systems are available on the market. The present study aimed to compare four commercially available systems: Polar Team Pro, Acentas Team Monitoring System, Suunto Pro Team Pack, and Activio Sport System.

* The study involved 12 active people, including 11 men and 1 woman, who participated in various tests to evaluate the systems. The tests included a field test during a real soccer match, a comparison against a commercially available ECG, and a distance measurement test. The systems were evaluated based on their measurement, software, and hardware, with a quality rating system used to assess their performance. The rating system was subdivided into three main categories, with the core area of the study focusing on the adequate online measurement of heart rate.

* The results of the study showed that Acentas and Polar led the field in terms of hardware, with both systems reaching high scores for their storage capacity and data safety. However, the wearing comfort of the chest belts was a concern, with Polar's chest belt decreasing wearing performance. The software evaluation showed that Activio offered a harmonious concept, while Acentas had the easiest installation procedure. Polar and Activio provided more developed software tools, but Acentas did not focus on extensive statistical analysis.

* The ECG comparison test showed that Acentas gave the reference value, followed by Activio and Suunto. However, the results should be regarded with caution as only one subject's data were included in the analysis. The distance measurement test showed that Acentas had the widest range of data acquisition, followed by Activio and Suunto. Polar reached a range of 102m, which corresponded to the manufacturer's information.

* The failure quota test showed that Acentas had the lowest average downtime, followed by Polar and Activio. Suunto had a total breakdown during competition measurements and could not be reactivated. The results of the study showed that each system had its advantages and disadvantages, depending on the using purpose, location, and weather. The study concluded that no single system could be recommended, but rather the strengths and weaknesses of each system should be considered.

<summary>
* In the 1960s, McCulloch and Till proposed three functional characteristics that define stem cells, including self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency. These characteristics support the hypothesis that a specific population of cells is responsible for propagation and sustained growth in a hierarchical manner. This theory was first proposed by Virchow in the 19th century.

* Stem cells have the ability to make identical copies of themselves, and their ability to proliferate extensively and self-renew requires the induction of these behaviors. To classify a cell as a stem cell, it must be isolated and the behaviors induced in vitro. Cell surface proteins unique to stem cells can be used to isolate and track them.

* Advances in stem cell biology have provided insight into the role of stem cells in the lung, despite the relative quiescence of the lung epithelia. Populations of stem cells have been identified throughout the lung by their role in responding to injury of the airway. The functional characteristics of stem cell behavior have been observed in these populations.

* A growing body of evidence suggests that the earliest stages of lung malignancies may be related to a deregulation of the stem cell-based repair mechanism. The epithelial lining of the adult airway progresses from proximal to distal in a stereotyped fashion, with different types of epithelium in different regions. Multiple studies indicate that cells capable of stem-like behavior are present throughout the airway.

* In proximal airways, studies have identified populations of tracheal basal cells that are pluripotent and express specific markers such as keratin-5 (K5) and keratin-14 (K14). These cells are capable of proliferating to give rise to cells of multiple phenotypes in response to airway injury. Squamous cell carcinoma frequently arises from the more proximal tracheobronchial airways.

* In middle airways, a rat model of nitrogen dioxide/ozone inhalation injury revealed that mature rat Clara cells could proliferate into phenotypically diverse progeny. These cells are capable of but not limited to behavior indicative of a stem cell, and are therefore referred to as facultative progenitor cells. Small cell lung carcinomas have been shown to contain fractions of cells expressing cell surface markers associated with mid-airway stem cell subpopulations.

* In the most distal airway, there is no consensus on the cell surface marker phenotype of representative lung stem cells. However, studies have identified pluripotent cells in the bronchoalveolar

<summary>
* Pancreatic cancer is a highly lethal disease with a low five-year survival rate, and pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is the most aggressive subtype. The survival of PDAC patients varies significantly depending on demographic and clinical factors, as well as the type of treatment performed. Cox proportional regression models have been used to estimate the relative impact of these factors on survival.

* A new web-based prognostic tool has been developed using data from 18,352 pathologically confirmed cases of PDAC diagnosed between 2004 and 2009. The tool estimates survival and conditional survival probabilities, as well as their corresponding standard errors, for patients with PDAC. The reliability and generalizability of the tool have been proven by its calibration and discrimination abilities.

* The tool has several advantages over existing models, including its applicability to the vast majority of PDAC patients, its ability to predict conditional and unconditional survival probabilities in real-time, and its consideration of time period effects. The tool also provides standard errors for predicted survival probabilities, which is not available in other calculators. Clinicians can use the tool to compare the predicted impacts of possible treatments on survival and make more informed decisions.</summary>

<summary>
• The scientific activity of a group of researchers is manifested through published papers, which are validated and legitimized by their peers and serve as indicators of their scientific knowledge development.
• Major international databases for health science publications include Medline/PubMed, the Web of Science, Embase, and Current Contents, with Medline/PubMed being the most often searched.
• The controlled vocabulary known as Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) allows researchers to retrieve information using a more exact, standardized description of the document in question.
• The journals selected for publication reflect the level of productivity of a research group and the institution to which they belong, with journals with high Impact Factors (IFs) considered more relevant to the scientific field.
• The evaluation of scientific production from a university is complex, involving different areas of knowledge, each with its own peculiarities, and analysis of smaller units like university departments or disciplines can be made more easily.
• A study analyzed the scientific production of full professors at the Faculdade de Medicina da Universidade de São Paulo (FMUSP) during the period of 2001 to 2006, revealing a total of 1,960 published articles.
• The study found that 68.7% of the articles were published in international journals, and 31.3% were published in Brazilian journals, with an average publication rate of five articles per year per professor.
• The qualitative analysis based on the number of times an article was cited by peers found that almost half of the total published articles (45%) were cited, amounting to a total of 9,335 citations.
• The study's results can be useful in analyzing the scientific production of a group of professors from the FMUSP and for establishing a basis for comparison with other institutions in Brazil.</summary>

<summary>
* Trichomonas vaginalis infection is a common curable sexually transmitted infection, with the World Health Organization estimating 173 million new cases annually. The infection has been associated with adverse reproductive health outcomes, including pelvic inflammatory disease, low infant birth weight, and premature delivery. Furthermore, trichomoniasis has been shown to increase the transmission and acquisition of other sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV infection.

* The frequency of trichomonal infection is not monitored in most countries, and control programs do not exist. Peruvian STI guidelines do not include Trichomonas diagnostic testing, and the syndromic management of suspected vaginal trichomoniasis is the current standard for clinical care. Trichomonal infection is likely more common among women and men than is generally understood, and long-standing, asymptomatic infections may lead to continued community-level transmission.

* This study was a cross-sectional analysis of the behavioral and biological data from the baseline assessment of a cohort subsequently enrolled in the NIMH Collaborative HIV/STD Prevention Trial collected from 2003 to 2005 in Peru. The study enrolled participants from low-income neighborhoods in three coastal Peruvian cities: Lima, Trujillo, and Chiclayo. Eligible women were recruited by outreach workers from venues such as volleyball fields, hair salons, parks, bars, and street corners.

* Participants were invited to a temporary project office in their neighborhood, where they privately administered a 30-minute structured survey in Spanish. The survey instrument collected sociodemographic information as well as detailed sexual risk behavior with the last five sex partners, number of sex partners, STI-related symptoms, alcohol and drug use, and HIV status. Upon completing the survey, participants underwent pretest counseling for STIs, including HIV infection.

* The study found that women with T. vaginalis infection were more likely to be older, with the highest prevalence found in the oldest age group, 36-40 years. Those with less education were three times more likely to have trichomonal infection compared to those who completed high school, and being single was also associated with a higher prevalence. Women with HSV-2 infection and syphilis infection were twice as likely to have trichomonal infection.

* The prevalence of trichomonal infection among women with vaginal discharge and painful urination in the prior six months was lower than the prevalence among those who did not report vaginal discharge during the same period, although the difference was not statistically significant. <summary>
• The study aimed to investigate the prevalence of internet addiction and its association with psychopathology among college students in Mumbai, India. The study found that 0.7% of the participants were classified as internet addicts, 24.8% as possible addicts, and 74.5% as moderate users based on Young's original criteria.

• The study revealed that males were more likely to be addicted to the internet than females, and addicts used the internet mostly in the evening and nights, often accessing it from their workplaces. The study also found that addicts had poor mental, physical, and social health scores, with high anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression scores.

• The findings of the study suggest that internet addiction is a significant issue among college students in India, and it is essential to formulate interventions to detect early warning signs of underlying psychopathology and set boundaries for internet use. The study's results are consistent with previous studies, which have reported a higher prevalence of internet addiction among males and its association with psychopathology.</summary>

<summary>
• According to the World Health Organization (WHO) experts, if rubella infection occurs during the early stages of pregnancy, the potential of passing the virus through the placenta and reaching the fetus is about 90%. The most important complication of rubella is congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), which directly relates to a lack of immunity during pregnancy. By vaccinating all susceptible people or women in reproductive age, it is possible to prevent the disease in mothers and its possible serious complications in their fetus. The primary purpose of rubella vaccination is to prevent congenital infection with the rubella virus and CRS.

• The disease is spread globally, and before the vaccination era, the maximum of its attacks had been between February and April in countries without effective policies for childhood vaccination. In closed populations such as military camps or prisons, however, in those who had suffered from this disease or vaccinated before, the possibility of infection is minimized. The disease is usually rare in infants born from IgG-positive mothers due to antibody transfer, and they will be immune for the first 46 months of their life. In general, the spread of the disease among children has been seriously decreased by extensive vaccination.

• The most commonly used vaccine globally is derived from the RA27/3 virus strain, which makes more immunity in comparison with other vaccines, and the immune response is more similar to the immunity after natural infection. One dose induces seroconversion in 95% of vaccinated persons. A variety of seroepidemiological studies have been done globally to evaluate the situation of protective antibodies and need assessment to vaccinate against the rubella virus. For example, in Australia, the rubella vaccination was established for schoolgirls since 1971, and CRS was significantly decreased thereafter.

• In Iran, the national immunity of the measles-rubella program was commenced in December 2003, with the target of vaccination of 33,579,082 people of 5 to 25 years old Iranians, and 98% of the target population were vaccinated. Such successful proceeding resulted in a decrease in the appearance of measles and rubella for less than one case per million. The main goal of this survey was to evaluate and compare the susceptibility and resistance of Kermanshahi girls at marriage, before and after mass rubella vaccination. The samples were randomly selected from the population referred to the main marriage consultancy center in Kermanshah city, west of Iran.

<summary>
• The use of quantum dots (QDs) in whole-mount in situ hybridization (WISH) has been explored as a means to improve the sensitivity and resolution of RNA detection in vertebrate embryos. QDs have ideal optical properties for use in biology, including strong fluorescent signal emission and resistance to photobleaching. However, commercially available QDs are quite large and may encounter penetration issues in embryos. To overcome this, proteinase K treatment was used to render Xenopus embryos permeable to QDs.

• The QD-based WISH protocol was tested using various RNA probes, including those specific for Xenopus latent transforming growth factor binding protein 1 (LTBP1), amylase, endodermin (EDD), xbra, and myod. The results showed that QDs can penetrate deep into the embryo and stain structures independently of their proximity to the free QDs in solution. The use of QDs for in situ staining could result in more accurate determination of transcript expression patterns. The QD labeling survives the clearing protocol used to render Xenopus and other embryos transparent.

• The QD-based WISH protocol was also used to detect two or more transcripts simultaneously, which is a time-consuming and stepwise process using chromogenic protocols. The results showed that QDs can be used to detect two or more transcripts simultaneously, with high resolution and strong signal intensities. The resolving ability of this method is substantially better than that of amplified protocols. The QD labeling of transcripts is of extremely high resolution and enables distinction of intracellular localization patterns of mRNA.

• The QD-based WISH protocol has several advantages over traditional methods, including the ability to provide macroscopic and intracellular data regarding the distribution of mRNAs in vertebrate embryos. The ideal optical properties of QDs provide unprecedented resolution and strong signal intensities that have not been possible to attain using traditional fluorophores. The method is also capable of remaining localized and fluorescent for more than an hour after the embryo is cleared. This has not been possible using traditional chromogenic or fluorescent methods.

• The study demonstrates that QD-based WISH is a viable alternative to current ISH protocols and expands the uses of QDs in biology. The QD in situ protocol can do both amplified and non-amplified detection of RNA probes, making it a valuable tool for studying mRNA localization. The results suggest that QDs could be introduced as alternative fluorophores in other fluorescent in situ hybridization assays where their spectral properties can offer significant advantages.
